<ex>[Restaurant-Pizzeria Dante|Part] [counts|Target] [among the few restaurants of Florence where you can find good typical Tuscan and fish dishes and a first-class pizza|Total].</ex>

name: Be_translation_equivalent
description:
A #Target_symbol in a #Target_representation  system is presented as equivalent to a #Source_symbol in a #Source_representation system in the ability to express a particular #Content.

<ex>[The term employment area|Target_symbol] [translates|Target] [the French zone d'emploi|Source_symbol].</ex>
<ex>The term employment area [translates|Target] [the French|Source_representation] zone d'emploi.</ex>

<ex>[The term|Target_symbol] [translates|Target] [the Russian raznorechie (literally ""different-speech-ness"")|Source_symbol].</ex>
<ex>The term [translates|Target] the [Russian|Source_representation] raznorechie (literally ""different-speech-ness"".</ex>

name: Billing
description: A #Billing_authority communicates in written form that the #Debtor owes the #Owed_party (often the same as the #Billing_authority) some amount of #Money for certain #Goods (including services) provided by the #Owed_party or to clear a debt for a #Bad_action by the #Debtor against the #Owed_party.

name: Biological_area
description:
This frame contains words that denote large ecological areas as well as smaller locations characterized by the type of life present--in other words, geography locations as defined by biota.

<ex>I've spent a long time in the [rugged|Descriptor] [[prairies|Target]|Locale] [of northern Llorwyn|Container_possessor].</ex>

name: Biological_classification
description:
This frame has to do with scientific taxonomy.  The lexical units in this frame include the seven major classifications in which organisms are grouped based on common biological characteristics.  These classifications are labeled #Rank in this frame.  The #Members or #Subtype of the #Rank is often expressed with the use of the target-denoting noun.
<ex></ex>
<ex>[[Phylum|Rank]|Target] [Arthropoda|Sub] <m>contains</m> [crustaceans, insects, spiders and other creepy-crawlies|Mem].</ex>
<ex></ex>
<ex>[The snow leopard|Mem] <m>belongs</m> to the [[kingdom|Rank]|Target] [Animalia|Sub].</ex>

name: Biological_entity
description:
The LUs in this frame refer to biological entities labeled by the FE #Organism. An #Organism is described as something that can be alive, or have naturally occuring biological processes and functions; however the concept of life is often used metaphorically for non-organic entities which resemble or act as if they have organic life.

<ex>NASA may someday discover a [new|Descriptor] [[lifeform|Target]|Organism] [from another planet|Origin].</ex>

name: Biological_entity_by_eating_habits
description: Biological_entity_by_eating_habits

name: Biological_mechanisms
description:
A trigger mechanism brings about a change in a biological system.

<ex>[The reflex|Trigger] [increases|Target] [cardiac output|Systemic_effect].</ex>

name: Biological_urge
description:
An #Experiencer is in a #State where a biological urge is signaling the need to perform a certain action such as eating, drinking, stopping exertion, sleeping, regurgitating, or having sex.
The #Duration, #Time, #Place, or #Degree of intensity associated with the occurrence of the urge may also be indicated.  In this frame, the #Experiencer does not necessarily want to perform the action that would fulfill the urge, and there is no specific focus associated with the urge.

<ex>[Mike|Experiencer] <m>feels</m> [hungry|Target].</ex>
<ex>[Sam|Experiencer] <m>was</m> [thirsty|Target] [after dinner|Time].</ex>

name: Birth_scenario
description: An #Offspring is born to a #Mother and #Father, collectively referred to as #Parents. This event happens at a particular #Time and #Place.

name: Board_vehicle
description:
A #Traveller boards a #Vehicle that they intend to use as a means of transportation either as a passenger or as a driver.

<ex>On the 5th of December, 1834, [we|tra] [embarked|Target] [on board the merchant ship Hellespont|Vehicle].</ex>

<ex>[She|Traveller] [boarded|Target] [the train|Vehicle] [ahead of him|Time].</ex>

<ex>[On 19 September|Time] [the battalion|Traveller] [embussed|Target] and headed southward into the Swordfish training area some 40 miles away.</ex>

name: Body_decoration
description:
This frame concerns the decorations that human beings have on or apply to their bodies.
<ex>[Abby|Dec_ind] rarely wears [[lipstick|Target]|Decoration].</ex>

name: Body_description_holistic
description:
This frame covers descriptions of an entire human body, viewed as a gestalt (as opposed to descriptions based on salient body parts).  The Frame Elements are #Individual and #Figure.

<ex>[Chuck|Ind] <m>is</m> [muscular|Target].</ex>

<ex>[Chuck|Ind] has a [muscular|Target] body.</ex>

name: Body_description_part
description:
This frame is concerned with words that describe a person based on a salient part of their body.
<ex>He was a [blonde|Target] [guy|Individual].</ex>
<ex>[He|Individual] was a [peg-leg|Target].</ex>

name: Body_mark
description:
In this frame a #Body_mark is present on a #Possessor's body.  It may be located at an #Attachment and have a #Descriptor.  A #Cause may also be indicated. It may be a temporary condition or a permanent one.

<ex> [Mark|Possessor] has a [cancerous|Descriptor] [[mole|Target]|Body_mark] [on his back|Attachment].</ex>

name: Body_movement
description:
This frame contains words for motions or actions an #Agent performs using some part of his/her body. Most words that evoke this frame have a specific motion of a specific #Body_part associated with them, but a few are more general (e.g. <m>move.v</m>).

A number of words in this frame occur as blends with Communication, in which the action has an #Addressee.  For example,

<ex>Pat [nodded|Target] [at Kim|Addressee].</ex>

These examples differ from Communication.Gesture in that no specific message need be expressed, as in
<ex>She [nodded|Target] to him to sit down.</ex>

Since this frame involves a particular type of motion, it contains the frame elements #Source, #Path, #Goal and #Area, which originate in the motion frame.  All of these frame elements are generally expressed in PP Complements.
<ex>The boy [swung|Target] his legs [from under the table|Source].</ex>

name: Body_parts
description:
This frame covers words for #Body_parts belonging to a #Possessor, which may be characterized by a #Descriptor. The location of the #Body_partmay be identified in terms of  its #Attachment or its #Orientational_location.  A #Subregion of a #Body_part may also be indicated.
<ex></ex>
<ex>He had to brace [his|Possessor] [right|Orientational_location] [[arm|Body_part]|Target] against his leg in order to fight the roll.</ex>

<ex>The dog measured [its|Possessor] [blond|Descriptor] [[belly|Body_part]|Target] in the mud.</ex>

<ex></ex>

name: Bond_maturation
description:
A #Financial_instrument (a bond or insurance) fulfills a condition at a certain #Time after which the #Issuer of the #Financial_instrument is legally obligated to pay the #Holder a monetary #Value, based on the instrument's original #Principle and the #Interest rate.

<ex>[The bond|Financial_instrument] had [matured|Target] [to its full value|Value] [at 30 years|].</ex>

name: Borrowing
description:
The #Borrower takes possession of a #Theme with the knowledge that the #Borrower will have to give the #Theme back to the #Lender after a #Duration of time.  This frame differs from the Lending frame in that this frame profiles the Borrower in active sentences, whereas the Lending frame profiles the Lender.
<ex></ex>
For the time being, this frame includes both the transfer event itself and the end state of the event, as shown in the first two examples following:

<ex>[I|Borrower] am [borrowing|Target] [the book about modal particles|Theme] [from the professor|Lender].</ex>

<ex>[I|Borrower] [borrowed|Target] [the book|Theme] [from him|Lender] and returned it [a long time ago|Time].</ex>

<ex>Not only did [I|Borr] have to [borrow|Target] [a gown|Theme], but I was also lent a jacket!</ex>

<ex>[The girl|Borr] [borrowed|Target] [the car|Theme] [from her sister|Lender] [for a couple days|Duration].</ex>

Along with other ways of temporarily taking possession (e.g. ""putting something in your pocket for a while""), this frame is used non-literally to refer to Stealing.  In this use, the #Borrower is a thief, the #Lender is a Victim, and the #Theme is the Goods:

<ex>Were n't nobody lookin' so [I|Borrower] [borrowed|Target] [it|Theme] [off her|Lender] .</ex>

name: Boulder
description:
This is an abstract frame for events which allows annotation of verbal targets according to the reduced, general set of frame elements proposed by the Boulder group.
<ex>[Belli 's clients|Eq1] have [included|Target] [Jack Ruby ... and Jim and Tammy Baker|Eq2].</ex>

name: Boundary
description:
This frame contains words that describe a #Boundary between two #Entities.  In many cases, the #Boundary is the border between an #Entity and some unnamed space, generally conceived of as empty.

<ex>[The canyon|Boundary] is the [border|Target] [between the two states|Entities].</ex>

name: Bounded_entity
description: This is an abstract frame for bounded areas, used mostly for FE inheritance.

name: Bounded_region
description: An #Exterior, #Surface, #Boundary, and #Interior are picked out relative to the #Ground.  This #Ground may either occupy only the #Boundary (in which case the #Interior is negative space) or the #Ground may fill the #Interior.

name: Bragging
description:
A #Speaker talks about a #Topic, which may be an action performed by the #Speaker or an entity or state of affairs that they are associated with in order to suggest that the #Speaker is worthy of admiration. The Speaker may give an explicit #Explanation for why the #Topic redounds to their credit. Alternatively, a #Message frame element can be used to directly describe what the #Speaker says, leaving the more specific #Explanation for admirability to be inferred. Instead of the #Speaker, the action may be attributed metonymically to the #Medium, or possibly the #Expressor.

<ex></ex>


<ex>[Turkish officials|Speaker] [boasted|Target] [of giving 'tens of thousands of dollars in surreptitious payments' to a prominent American politician|Topic].</ex>

<ex>[He|Speaker] [then|Time] [vaunted|Target] [his own clan|Topic], but failed to mention Emanuel Ungaro, who described the omission as ''lamentable''.</ex>

<ex>[The press release|Medium] [boasts|Target] [that ""a direct connection between the cartridge and the system"" means no more having to blow dust out of game cartridges|mes].</ex>

<ex>[70's comics like Chevy Chase and Steve Martin|Speaker] over-stated their egotism and [preened|Target] [over their superiority|Topic].</ex>

name: Breaking_apart
description:
A Whole breaks apart into Pieces, resulting in the loss of the Whole (and in most cases, no piece that has a separate function).

<ex>[The plane|Whole] [violently|Manner] [broke apart|Target] [in mid-air|Place].</ex>

<ex>And then, I finally realized that it must have been the case that [a meteorite|who] [broke apart|Target] [into at least 3 large pieces|Pieces].</ex>

Many of these verbs can also refer metaphorically to the breaking apart of institutions. (See the frame for ""schism"".)

name: Breaking_off
description:
An single #Subpart breaks off from a #Whole.

<ex>[The original sword|sub] may have [chipped|Target] [off of the statue|Whole] [long ago|Time].</ex>

name: Breaking_out_captive
description:
An #Agent brings about the end of a #Theme's captivity at a #Location_of_confinement in contravention of the plans or desires of a captor.

<ex>[His accomplice|Agent] [freed|Target] [him|Theme] [from Sing Sing prison|Location_of_confinement] [thanks to his disguise|Means].</ex>

name: Breathing
description:
An #Agent causes #Air to move in a direction, usually specifying either in or out of the body.

<ex>[Lee|Agent] [breathed|Target] [the hot desert air|Air].</ex>

name: Bringing
description:
This frame concerns the movement of a #Theme and an #Agent and/or #Carrier.   The #Agent, a person or other sentient entity, controls the shared #Path by moving the #Theme during the motion. In other words, the #Agent has overall motion in directing the motion of the #Theme.  The #Carrier may be a separate entity, or it may be the #Agent's body. The #Constant_location may be a subregion of the #Agent's body or (a subregion of) a vehicle that the #Agent uses.

<ex>[Karl|Agent] [carried|Target] [the books|Theme] [across campus|Path] [to the library|goa] [on his head|CL].</ex>
<ex>[Karl|Agent] [carried|Target] [the books|Theme] [across campus|Path] [to the library|goa] [in his truck|CL].</ex>
<ex>[Karl|Agent] [carried|Target] [the books|Theme] [across campus|Path] [to the library|goa] [by truck|Carrier].</ex>
<ex>[The truck|Carrier] [carried|Target] [the books|Theme] [across campus|Path] [to the library|goa] [in specially designed boxes|CL].</ex>
The  FEs include #Path, #Goal, and #Source.  #Area is an area that contains the motion when the path is understood as irregular.
This frame emphasizes the path of movement as opposed to the FEs Source or Goal as in Filling or Placing.

name: Building
description:
This frame describes assembly or construction actions, where an #Agent joins #Components together to form a #Created_entity, which is profiled, and hence the object of the verb.

<ex>[Jack|Agent] [built|Target] [a new house|CrEnt] [out of bricks|Cmpnt].</ex>
<ex>We [glued|Target] the airplanes [together|Result].</ex>

name: Buildings
description:
This frame contains words which name permanent fixed structures forming an enclosure and providing protection from the elements.


<ex>The [baroque|Type] [church|Target], built in 1635, has a very rich interior</ex>
<ex>The city tour includes the [16th-century|toc] [monastery|Target] of the Transfiguration and Church of Elijah the Prophet</ex>
<ex>An ancient [stone|Mat] [church|Target] stands amid the fields</ex>

<ex>Jack <gov>built</gov> <x>his [house|Target]</x> in the style of the day.</ex>

name: Building_subparts
description:
This frame includes words that name subparts of buildings that can be occupied by people.

<ex>Mary left the [[room|Target]|Building_part] in a huff.</ex>

name: Bungling
description:
An #Agent performs an #Action incorrectly, resulting in some undesirable result or, at best, achieving some part of the desired result but not in a desirable way.  The affected #Patient may be mentioned metonymically for the #Action.  In place of both of these, a #Topic can describe some general field in which an #Agent makes an error or errors.

<ex>[Mickey|Agent] [botched|Target] [that swing|Action].</ex>
<ex>[Julia|Agent] [bungled|Target] [the cake|Patient].</ex>

name: Burying
description:
An #Agent or #Cause places a #Theme under a surface (often the ground) into a #Goal location.

<ex>[The suspect|Agent] [buried|Target] [his gun|Theme] [in the ground|Goal] [while fleeing the police|Time].</ex>

name: Businesses
description:
A #Proprietor owns or runs a #Business which provides a #Product (which may be goods or services).

<ex>The [consumer electronics|Product] [[company|Target]|Business] [Apple|Business_Name] has exploded with popularity in recent years.</ex>

name: Business_closure
description:
A business locale, the #Entity, ceases to provide services and closes.

<ex>[Exxon|ent] [went under|Target].</ex>

name: Cache
description:
A hidden #Cache of a #Resource is kept safe and available for later #Use. The existence, location, and other information about the #Cache is kept secret by the #Possessor.

<ex>They no doubt had to move [their|pos] [arms|res] [cache|Target] after several members defected.</ex>

<ex>Do you have a [stash|Target] [of money|res] somewhere?</ex>

name: Calendric_unit
description:
Words in this frame name the different parts of the calendric cycle, both man-made and natural. The #Unit (e.g. <m>Tuesday</m>) specifies some time period as part of a specific larger temporal #Whole (Tuesday <m>of next week</m>), or may be resolved to an exact time span by a #Relative_time (<m>next</m> Tuesday).
<ex>Jo's mother will visit on [this coming|Relative_time] [[Tuesday|Target]|Unit].</ex>
<ex></ex>
Very frequently, the #Whole or #Relative_time are left out (i.e., DNI), and often should be interpreted as a time period overlapping with the communication, but more generally must be understood from context.  So, for example, in the first sentence below, we can imagine that the #Whole refers to a year (e.g., 1983) that was already mentioned or established in context.  In the second example below, the most likely interpretation is the nearest April, whether in this year or the next, and this interpretation is best indicated by indicating the #Relative_time is DNI.

<ex>On [[April|Unit]|Target] 2 , she finally found her mother . [DNI|Whole]. </ex>
<ex>I 'll come back in [[April|Target]|Unit] .[DNI|Relative_time]</ex>
<ex></ex>
Most members of this frame can be used with iterative events, either with a plural #Unit (<m>on Tuesdays</m>), or marked with <m>every</m> (<m>every April</m>).
<ex>On [Tuesday and Thursday|Whole] [afternoons|Target] , we have tea .</ex>
In this use, when the #Whole is omitted, the #Whole should be marked INI.
<ex>On [Tuesdays|Target] , we have tea . [INI|Whole] </ex>
<ex></ex>
Words of this frame often occur in a non-lexical construction that uses some Calendric_unit expressions to establish when an event occurred.  To capture this information, we use the extra-thematic FEs #Landmark_period and #Trajector_event (see Temporal_collocation) on the second layer, as in the following:
<ex>[Last|Relative_time] [[Tuesday|Unit]|Target] she said I 'd have to come back .</ex>
<ex>[Last [Tuesday|Target]|Landmark_period] [she said I 'd have to come back|Trajector_event] .</ex>
We do not use these FEs for cases where the temporal relationship is introduced by an overt word of the Temporal_collocation frame (like <m>on</m>, <m>in</m>, <m>at</m>, <m>before</m>, etc.).  Most lexical units of this frame occur in this construction, with or without requiring a #Relative_time, while some idiosyncratically do not, so information on the use with the extra-thematic FE #Trajector_event is lexically specific.
<ex></ex>
There are a number of non-lexical constructions that evoke this frame, including date constructions (<m>the third</m>, <m>May 5</m>), decade constructions (<m>the oughts</m>), year constructions (<m>1975</m>, <m>24 BCE</m>, <m>10 AH</m>, <m>year 19</m>, etc.), and time-of-day constructions. Although not annotated in this frame, examples such as the following show that the FEs #Unit and #Whole are quite appropriate:
<ex>The [4th|Unit] [of April|Whole] dawned clear and cold .</ex>
<ex>[December|Whole] [11|Unit] was when Alix finally left .</ex>
<ex>The [23rd|Unit] will be snowy . [DNI|Whole] </ex>
<ex>Nothing much happened in the [90s|Unit] , did it ? [DNI|Whole] </ex>
As described above for the lexical targets that evoke this frame, some non-lexical versions of the frame may also occur in a non-lexical Temporal_collocation construction:
<ex>No-one has forgotten what happened the [5th|Unit] [of November|Whole] !</ex>
<ex>No-one has forgotten [what happened|Trajector_event] [the 5th of November|Landmark_period] !</ex>
<ex></ex>

Words in this frame figure into a variety of temporal schemas, realized as constructions, primarily cases in which the Calendric_unit serves as a Landmark_period in the Temporal_collocation frame. There are families of constructions in which these words occur, including ones in which weekday names combine with day part names using particular prepositions (e.g. <ment>on Wednesday morning</ment>, cf. <ment>on Wednesday</ment>, but  <ment>in the morning</ment>) and ones in which  calendric terms fill the slots in multi-word expressions such as  N-after-N (e.g. <ment>day after day</ment>),  N-by-N (e.g. <ment>week by week</ment>),  N-to-N (e.g. <ment>month to month</ment>), etc. More can be found on these in Fillmore (2002).  Note, also, the connection between this frame and Frequency, specifically that many iterative adjectives and adverbs are based on calendric terms (e.g. <ment>daily</ment>, <ment>weekly</ment>, <ment>monthly</ment>, etc.).

name: Candidness
description:
This frame contains adjectives and nouns that describe the truth or sincerity of communication. These words, analogously to behaver-evaluating words, can apply either to #Speakers or to the #Messages they produce. They can occur with <ment>about</ment>-PPs expressing #Topic.

<ex>[Evelyn|Speaker] was [candid|Target] [with me|Addressee] [about the party|Topic].</ex>

name: Capability
description:
An #Entity meets the pre-conditions for participating in an #Event.  A #Degree modifier may be included to indicate by how much the #Entity exceeds or falls short of the minimum requirements.

<ex>Conductor software gives [us|Entity] the hands-on [capability|Target] [to provide updates immediately|Evt]</ex>

<ex>The GOP is afraid that [it|Ent] might not <m>be</m> [capable|Target] [of keeping the seat vacated by Dunn.|Evt]</ex>

<ex>[NASA|Ent] <m>is</m> [unable|Target] [to communicate with Mars rover|Evt].</ex>

<ex>[He|Ent] [can|Target] [fly a kite|Evt].</ex>

name: Capacity
description:
An #Entity has the ability to contain a #Theme.

<ex>[Our facility|ent] [seats|Target] [up to 500 people|the].</ex>

name: Capital_stock
description:
This frame concerns #Stock, a purchasable and sellable asset representing a #Shareholder's share in a company (the #Issuer). #Stock entitles the #Shareholder to profits of the #Issuer company, as determined by the governing board of the #Issuer company. LUs in this frame can denote the type of capital stock investment into a business (common or preferred) or the investment itself.  Common stock is also known as ordinary stock or voting stock.

<ex>[My|Shareholder] [ten|amt] [preferred|Type] [[shares|Target]|Stock] [in Google|Issuer] are worth more than your ten common shares in Apple.</ex>

name: Cardinal_numbers
description:
This frame presents a situation where there is a certain #Number of instances of an #Entity or a certain #Number that quantifies a #Unit. Numbers are used to count any kind of #Entity that has distinct individuals, or alternatively, to count #Units whose own function is to quantify some property, with the #Number associated with each word of this frame differentiating groups, individuals, parts of individual #Entitys of different sizes, or to differentiate the quantity of the #Units. A countable #Entity prototypically occupies its own space separately from other instances of the #Entity, and each instance of the #Entity has specific kinds of parts or substance or characteristics as specified by the kind of #Entity it is described as.   #Units (e.g., hours, inches, dozens) have the function of quantifying some property and as a result, naturally occur with a #Number to say how the current property compares to the standard quantification of the #Unit.  Less prototypical numbers, which occur much more frequently with #Units rather than #Entitys, describe situations with less than a whole #Unitor #Entity (half.n), or the lack of a #Unit or #Entity (zero.num).
<ex></ex>
There is also a #Precision associated with the #Number. In most cases, there is a certain amount of imprecision in the #Number that is assumed, especially for so-called ""round"" numbers like twenty.num or hundred.num, and for the class of approximate numbers, like couple.n; for other numbers, e.g. two.num, the expected precision is very high. Separately from this inherent possibility of precision or imprecision, numbers may be modified by an explicit specification of their #Precision, with phrases like ""about"", etc.

<ex>Only [[two|Target]|Number] [senators|Entity] voted in support of the president .</ex>
<ex>Dr. Malik has confined [almost|Precision] a [[score|Target]|Num] [of such unfortunates|Entity] in his basement, you know.</ex>
<ex>We endured [[forty|Target]|Number] [days of snow|Entity] .</ex>
<ex>There were [[thirty|Num]|Target] [of the little blue creatures|Entity] staring up at him.</ex>
<ex>She had only two pieces of Halloween candy left, but I still had [[ten|Target]|Number]! [DNI|Entity]</ex>
<ex>The ship was [[three|Target]|Number] [degrees|Unit] off course .</ex>

<ex></ex>
This frame includes extrathematic FEs for a set of non-lexical constructions that put together quantifying expressions.  Firstly, a #Number may itself be quantified by having a certain #Multiplier, e.g. ""three hundred"".  Secondly, a sequence of numerical expressions may be strung together, with or without ""and"", to produce a #Composite_number representing a #Number that is the sum of the constituent numbers and that collectively modifies the #Entity or #Unit.

<ex>Stephen has more than [five|mul] [[hundred|Number]|Target] in his closet! [DNI|Entity]</ex>
<ex></ex>
<ex></ex>
As can be seen in the first of the next two examples, when the target is a number in front of another number in the function of a #Multiplier, we consider the number it is modifying to be a #Unit:

<ex>There are just over [[six|Target]|Number] [billion|Unit] people in the world today.</ex>
<ex>There are [just over|deg] [six|Multiplier] [[billion|Num]|Target] [people|Entity] in the world today.</ex>

The relationship between numbers, as lexical units in this frame, and the broader category of numbers is a complex one.  In particular, there is a semiotic system that arranges the tiny set of numeral symbols (0, 1, 2 ... 9), with some additional symbols (commas, decimal points, fraction lines, scientific notation of exponents) to generate a standard representation for numbers that, while not universal, is at least language independent.  Our description of numbers is focused on the English system of numbers, as would occur in the spoken language or in pronunciations (actually decodings) of written numerals in English.  Since numerals are well-understood by virtually all speakers of most languages, and are well-processed by computers, we do not view the description of these structures in FrameNet as necessary.  As a convenience, we include numerals as wordforms when they coincide with a basic number word of English (e.g., ""3"" is a wordform of three.num).
<ex></ex>
Of more interest for the FrameNet Project is the large number of idiosyncrasies in the constructions that use numbers, very few of which will be well-exemplified in our annotation.  These include indications of range (from ... to), approximation (in the neighborhood of), and descriptions of group properties (""A whopping [three|Target] singers showed up"")

<ex></ex>

Technical note: The frame as currently devised does not distinguish between ""six apples"" and ""six of the apples"".  It is clear that in the first case, we are talking about six entities that fit whatever properties apples have.  In the second case, however, there is a specific set of apples that was already under discussion, and the six apples are members of this set.  There is a way of understanding this second case in terms of the first, namely, that ""six of the apples"" is interpreted as six entities with the property of being members of the given set of apples.  Since understanding the second case involves an additional notion of set membership, this could be indicated with a different FE than any we currently have in this frame, perhaps *Set, which is in an exclusion relation with Entity.  However, the major semantic distinction between these two types of #Entity is whether there is a definite set, and this distinction is independently indicated by the definite article in examples like ""six of the apples"".

name: Carry_goods
description:
A Distributor sells, lends, or otherwise distributes a class of Goods. In the prototypical case, the Distributor is a retailer who generally keeps some type of Goods on site for the purpose of selling it to a buyer. Extensions include lending Goods (e.g., libraries, movie rental outlets), organization-internal distribution (as in a hospital), or other non-commercial distribution centers. The Goods are constrained to be a type of item (e.g., <ment>canned goods</ment>, <ment>antique dressers</ment>) rather than a particular or unique item (e.g., <ment>Smith's last self-portrait</ment>, <ment>that guitar I saw here last week</ment>). Note that a Distributor may <ment>carry</ment> some particular goods, but may not have it <ment>on hand</ment> at that exact moment.

<ex>[Trader Joe's|Distributor] [carries|Target] [a wide variety of foods, drinks, and househole necessities|Goods].</ex>

name: Catastrophe
description: The words in this frame involve an #Undesirable_event which affects the #Patient negatively.  No agent need be involved. <ex></ex> <ex>The first [calamity|Target] <m>was</m> [a disastrous trade war with Holland|Undesirable_event].</ex>  <ex>It is sad to have to make a living by grubbing around in the dirt of a [national|Patient] [[calamity|Undesirable_event]|Target].</ex>  <ex>[The result|Undesirable_event] has been [catastrophic|Target].</ex>

name: Catching_fire
description:
A #Fuel, some flammable object or substance, ends up on fire.  In this frame, the cause of the fire is not the primary concern, but rather the fact that a fire started.  In rare cases, only the #Fire is mentioned and the associated #Fuel is not.

<ex></ex>
This frame does not include phrases like ""a fire broke out"" or ""the conflagration started in the bedroom"" as these are deemed to be compositional (see Process_start and Fire_burning).

name: Categorization
description:
A #Cognizer construes an #Item as belonging to a certain #Category.  In this process, the #Cognizer may either passively perceive the #Item and note that it fits the #Criteria for a #Category, or, alternatively, actively examine the #Item for certain #Criteria that define a #Category (or set of #Categorys).

Most members of the frame can also describe a resulting cognitive state of the #Cognizer with respect to the #Item and #Category which no longer requires the current perception or consideration of the #Item.  A few LUs (e.g. <ment>peg.v, pigeonhole.v</ment>) do not readily allow stative interpretation, and a few LUs (e.g. <ment>deem.v, regard.v</ment>) only allow stative interpretation.

<ex>[You|Cognizer] 've already [stereotyped|Target] [me|Item] [as a bimbo|Category], have n't you?</ex>

name: Causation
description:
A #Cause causes an #Effect.  Alternatively, an #Actor, a participant of a (implicit) #Cause, may stand in for the #Cause.  The entity #Affected by the Causation may stand in for the overall #Effect situation or event.
<ex></ex>
Those frames that inherit the Causation frame have as their background the idea that some event is responsible for the occurrence of another event (or state).  In the  inheriting frame, typically an FE like Agent or Causer is proposed in the place of the #Actor, but in the daughter frames, as in this frame, the #Actor is semantically dependent on the idea of a #Cause (an event or state-of-affairs) that the #Actor is a participant in.  Similarly, most inheriting frames profile only the #Affected entity, not the full #Effect situation which is often incorporated into the frame or the particular target.  So, for example, paint.v in the Filling frame entails the final situation of something (the #Affected) being covered in paint (the #Effect).

<ex>[He|act] [made|Target] [me|Effect] [angry|Effect].</ex>

<ex>If [such a small earthquake|Cause] [causes|Target] [problems|Effect], just imagine a big one!</ex>

<ex>[The strange mutations of the rumor mill|Cause] [in the end|Time] [led|Target] [to it being said that he was actually a woman|Effect].</ex>

<ex>[You|Actor] 've [made|Target] [it|Effect] [impossible to continue|Effect]!</ex>

<ex>[The ending|Cause] [left|Target] [me|Effect] [feeling kinda empty|Effect].</ex>

name: Causation_scenario
description:
A #Cause brings about an #Effect that would not have occurred otherwise, simultaneously preventing an #Averted_situation, which is what would have occurred without the #Cause.  The #Effect and the #Averted_situation are thus mutually exclusive alternatives prior to the #Cause event.  In most cases, either the #Effect or the #Averted_situation is clearly most prominent; this is especially true in the case where the #Cause is the action of an Agent, who normally conceives of their action as either bringing about a desirable #Effect or avoiding an undesirable #Averted_situation.
<ex></ex>
In frames that inherit from this one, the #Cause is either an event, or an entity that plans or directly causes the #Effect may metonymically stand in for the #Cause event.

name: Cause_benefit_or_detriment
description:
A #Beneficial_situation causes an improvement in a #Benefitted_situation.  In many cases, a #Beneficiary (an individual postively affected by the #Benefitted_situation) is mentioned instead of or in addition to the #Benefitted_situation.  In some cases, a #Benefactor brings about the #Beneficial_situation and is mentioned in its place. Some lexical units of this frame are marked with the semantic type ""Negative"", indicating a disimprovement of the #Benefitted_situation.
<ex></ex>

<ex>[These tax cuts|Beneficial_situation] [benefit|Target] [the poor|Beneficiary] .</ex>
<ex>[The Chinese group|Benefactor] probably [benefitted|Target] [us|Beneficiary] [with their quick action|Means] [more than the other way round|Degree] .</ex>
<ex>[Most petrochemicals|Beneficial_situation] are [detrimental|Target] [to human health|Benefitted_situation] .</ex>

In many cases, a #Beneficial_situation FE also contains a mention of a #Benefactor, in which case we use dual FE-layer annotation to indicate both FEs:

<ex>[The foundation's 50m donation|Beneficial_situation] [benefits|Target] [the country's educational system|Beneficiary] [immensely|Degree].</ex>
<ex>[The foundation's|Benefactor]</ex>

<ex>[His presence|Beneficial_situation] at the summit was [massively|Degree] [detrimental|Target] [to diplomatic relations|Beneficiary] .</ex>
<ex>[His|Benefactor]</ex>


<ex></ex>


Unlike in Commerce_scenario, the recipient is not presented as paying for the good or service that they receive.
<ex></ex>
Targets from the Cause_harm frame (e.g., injure.v) and from the Damaging frame (e.g. damage.n) are very frequently used metaphorically to indicate the opposite of the Conferring_benefit frame.  These should be annotated in the Cause_harm and Damaging frames and marked with the Metaphor sentence tag.

name: Cause_bodily_experience
description:
An #Agent or #Cause affects a #Body_part of an #Experiencer so that the quality of the #Experiencer's perceptual experience of the #Body_part is qualitatively changed.

<ex>[Chandra|Agt] [massaged|Target] [Liliana's wrist|Body_part] [because it was injured|Explanation].</ex>
<ex>Chandra [massaged|Target] [Liliana|Experiencer]'s wrist because it was injured.</ex>

name: Cause_change
description:
An #Agent or #Cause causes an #Entity to change, either in its category membership or in terms of the value of an #Attribute. In the former case, an #Initial_category and a #Final_category may be expressed, in the latter case an #Initial_value and a #Final_value can be specified.

<ex>Our storylines follows the saga outlined by the Ultima Series, but [we|age] have [modified|Target] [it|ent] [in order to make our writing more cohesive|pur].</ex>


<ex>I don't think [you|Agent] can [turn|Target] [that rabbit|ent] [into a hat|finc].</ex>

<ex>How can [a guy that|age] [changed|Target] [his name|att] [from Bob Craft|iniv] [to Jack Ass|finv] declare anyone defamed his character?</ex>

<ex> [At this juncture|tim], [a new development|cau] [changed|Target] [the political situation on the island|ent].</ex>

<ex>[She|age] had [at some time earlier|tim] [completely|deg] [changed|Target] [her clothing and appearance|att] and now stood in front of me dressed like a garden gnome.</ex>

<ex>Hence, when [(Hg 0 )|ent] is [converted|Target] [to Hg 2+|finc] , it can be rapidly taken up in rain water, snow, or adsorbed onto small particles</ex>
<ex>Hence, when [(Hg 0 )|inic] is [converted|Target] to Hg 2+ , it can be rapidly taken up in rain water, snow, or adsorbed onto small particles</ex>

name: Cause_change_of_consistency
description:
In this frame an #Agent or #Cause changes the consistency of a #Patient from its #Initial_state to a #Result.  This may take place under certain #Circumstances for a #Purpose or #Explanation in a certain #Manner.  A #Change_agent can also be used.  Note that this frame contrasts with Cause_change_of_phase in that this frame describes causation of a change in a #Patient <ment>within</ment> a particular phase.

<ex>[Donna|Agent] [thinned|Target] [the soup|Patient] [with chicken broth|Change_agent]. </ex>
<ex>[The high temperatures|Cause] [curdled|Target] [the milk|Patient].</ex>

name: Cause_change_of_phase
description: A #Cause or #Agent causes a #Patient to undergo a change of phase.  The #Result of the change may be given, along with the #Initial_state and the #Circumstances under which the change can occur.  Note that this frame contrasts with Cause_change_of_consistency in that this frame describes causation of a change of a #Patient <ment>between</ment> different phases (i.e. solid to liquid or frozen to ""unfrozen"").  <ex> [Bob|Agent] [melted|Target] [the butter|Patient]. </ex>   <ex>[Sally|Agent] [defrosted|Target] [the chicken|Patient] [to eat for dinner|Purpose]. </ex>

name: Cause_change_of_position_on_a_scale
description:
This frame consists of words that indicate that an #Agent or a #Cause affects the position of an #Item on some scale (the #Attribute) to change it from an initial value (#Value_1) to an end value (#Value_2). The direction of the change (#Path) can be encoded as well as the magnitude of the change (#Difference).
The rate of change of the value (#Speed) can optionally be indicated as well as a second scale (#Correlated_variable), which the values are correlated with.
<ex></ex>
<ex>[The company|Agent] is [raising|Target] [the final dividend|Attribute] [from 4.34p|Value_1] [to 4.57p|Value_2], to boost the total by 5.3 percent to 6.36p.</ex>

<ex>Similarly, a consumer boom will encourage [the authorities|Agent] to [increase|Target] [interest rates|Attribute] [in order to keep money supply on target|Purpose].</ex>

<ex>[United Way of Central Indiana|Agent] [adds|Target] [value|Attribute] [to your investment|Item].</ex>

name: Cause_change_of_strength
description:
An #Agent causes a #Patient to be more strong, often resulting in something that is more secure and safe.

<ex>[Local Serbs|Agent] are [strengthening|Target] [their grip on a narrow corridor along the Sava River between two large Serbian areas|Patient].</ex>

name: Cause_emotion
description:
An #Agent acts to  cause a #Experiencer to feel a certain emotion.

<ex>[I|Experiencer] was [so|Degree] [offended|Target] [by her behaviour towards me|Agent].</ex>

<ex>It does not matter if [the cartoon|Agent] <m>is</m> [insulting|Target] [to men|Experiencer].</ex>

name: Cause_expansion
description:
An  #Agent or non-human #Cause causes an #Item to change its physical size.  The #Size_change of an #Item may be explicitly indicated or characterized in terms of #Initial_size and/or #Result_size.  In the default case, expansion is along all dimensions, but sometimes the #Dimension of expansion is incorporated or made explicit.

<ex>If the design crashes too often, then try [lengthening|Target] [the wings|Item] [by a few centimeters|Size_change], [to perhaps 30cm total|Result_size].  [CNI|Agent] [INI|Dimension] </ex>

<ex>As the juice churned with natural process of changing into wine, [the gas it created|Cause] would [expand|Target] [the balloon|Item], and when the balloon eventually deflated, it was ready to drink.</ex>

name: Cause_fluidic_motion
description:
An #Agent or a #Cause causes a #Fluid to move from a #Source to a #Goal along a #Path or within an #Area.

<ex>[I|Agent] [splattered|Target] [red paint|Fluid] [nearby|Area].</ex>

name: Cause_harm
description:
The words in this frame describe situations in which an #Agent or a #Cause injures a #Victim. The #Body_part of the #Victim which is most directly affected may also be mentioned in the place of the #Victim.  In such cases, the #Victim is often indicated as a genitive modifier of the #Body_part, in which case the #Victim FE is indicated on a second FE layer.
<ex></ex>
<ex>Rod saw [his father|Agent] [beating|Target] [his mother|Victim].</ex>

<ex>In the end Wormtongue is fed up with being beaten so [he|Agent] [cuts|Target] [Saruman's throat|Body_part] [to free himself|Purpose].</ex>

<ex>[A mother|Victim] [stabbed|Target] [to death|Result] [by her husband|Agent] made a secret will stating that he must never be allowed to care for their son.</ex>

name: Cause_impact
description:
An #Agent causes an #Impactor to make sudden, forcible contact with an #Impactee, or manipulates two (or more) #Impactors so that they make mutual forcible contact.

<ex>[He|Agent] [slammed|Target] [his fist|Impactor] [down|Result] [on the table|Impactee] and bellowed something unintelligible.</ex>

name: Cause_motion
description:
An #Agent causes a #Theme to move from a #Source, along a #Path, to a #Goal.  Different members of the frame emphasize the trajectory to different degrees, and a given instance of the frame will usually leave some of the #Source, #Path and/or #Goal implicit. The completion of motion is not required (unlike the Placing frame, see below), although individual sentences annotated with this frame may emphasize the #Goal.
<ex></ex>
This frame is very broad and contains several different kinds of words that refer to causing motion.  Some words in this frame do not emphasize the #Manner/#Means of causing the motion (transfer.v, move.v).  For many of the others (cast.v, throw.v, chuck.v, etc.), the #Agent has control of the #Theme only at the #Source of motion, and does not experience overall motion.  For others (e.g. drag.v, push.v, shove.v, etc.) the #Agent has control of the #Theme throughout the motion; for these words, the #Theme is resistant to motion due to some friction with the surface along which they move.

<ex>[She|Agent] [threw|Target] [her shoes|Theme] [into the dryer|Goal] .</ex>
<ex>[The mechanic|Agent] [dragged|Target] [the jack|Theme] [out from under the car|Source] .</ex>
<ex>[We|Agent] will [move|Target] [the sofa|Theme] [out of the room|Source] [through the french doors|Path], [down the stairs|Path], and [onto the sidewalk|Goal] .</ex>
<ex></ex>
<ex></ex>

This frame is used in a very large number of productive metaphors, not all of which can be outlined here.  The most salient types include causing an entity, construed as a #Theme, to change state from an initial state (#Source) via an intermediate state (#Path) to a final state (#Goal):
<ex>[Hillary|Theme] was [catapulted|Target] [to stardom|Goal] and his life has never been the same since . [CNI|Agent]</ex>
<ex>[She|Theme] felt as though [flung|Target] [from health|Source] [to illness|Goal] and [back|Goal] [by the day , by the hour|Time] .</ex>
<ex>[Once our parents are dead|Time] , [we|Theme] are [catapulted|Target] [into becoming the older generation ourselves|Goal] . [CNI|Cause]</ex>
<ex>[Croquet|Theme] was [pushed|Target] [out|Source] [by tennis|Cause] .</ex>
<ex></ex>

A particularly divergent subtype casts changing someone's intentions as changing their location:
<ex>[Democrats|Agent][forced|Target] [the Senate|Theme] [into a rare closed door session|Goal] .</ex>
<ex>[He|Agent] [nudged|Target] [Mrs Thatcher|Theme] [towards acceptance of a unified Germany|Goal] .</ex>
<ex></ex>

Another subtype is specifically about causing a change in quantity (the #Theme) through some sequence of values (#Source, #Path, and #Goal):
<ex>Bonus payments would be handed out for [pushing|Target] [up|Path] [voting levels|Theme] [CNI|Agent] .</ex>
<ex></ex>

Another type, with many subtypes, involves causing an action or state (construed as a #Theme) to have an effect on another person or location or conceptual domain. In such cases, the#Goal is used for the final affected domain, and #Source for initial affected domain, #Path for an intermediate affected domain, and #Distance for degree of difference between original application of the action and final:
<ex>[Jake|Agent] had been [hurling|Target] [these same insults|Theme] [at her|Goal] [now|Time] [for years|Duration]</ex>
<ex>[One|Agent] can not [press|Target] [this argument|Theme] [too far|Distance] .</ex>
<ex>[She|Agent] [shoved|Target] [the thought|Theme] [to the very back of her mind|Goal] .</ex>
<ex>[She|Agent] [flung|Target] [him|Goal] [a savage little smile|Theme] .</ex>
All of the foregoing metaphorical uses are annotated in this frame and marked ""Metaphor"", since they seem to be semantically motivated and not lexically idiosyncratic.
<ex></ex>
<ex></ex>

This frame contrasts with the following frames which talk about an #Agent changing a #Theme's position with respect to a landmark (either #Source or #Goal):
<ex></ex>

In Placing, the figure (#Theme) is profiled as the object, and ends up on the ground (#Goal).  The focus is on the final stage of motion, in which the #Theme ends up at the #Goal, and usually stably remains there.
<ex>Joyce [placed|Target] [the flowers|Theme] [onto the bed|Goal].</ex>
<ex></ex>

In Filling, the ground (#Goal) is profiled as the object, and the figure (#Theme) ends up on the ground (#Goal).
<ex>John [filled|Target] [the box|Goal] [with old toys|Theme].</ex>
<ex></ex>

In Removing, the figure (#Theme) is profiled, and is removed from the ground (#Source).
<ex>Jennifer [removed|Target] [the flowers|Theme] [from the bed|Source].</ex>
<ex></ex>

In Emptying, the ground (#Source) is profiled and the figure (#Theme) is removed from it.
<ex>Jason [emptied|Target] [the box|Source] [of the old toys|Theme] .</ex>
<ex></ex>

Words of this frame also differ from the words of the Bringing frame in that they are more general:  either the #Agent has a momentary interaction with the #Theme that causes its motion, unlike the continuous causation of Bringing, or the #Agent continuously acts on the #Theme, but there is no supporting object that helps with the motion like the Carrier of the Bringing frame.

name: Cause_proliferation_in_number
description:
An #Agent (or inanimate #Cause) affects a #Set so that the number of entities that make up the #Set changes from an #Initial_number to a #Final_number. Alternatively, the situation can be described in terms of an #Initial_state and a #Final_state. In some cases the #Attribute (i.e., number) or #Difference in number may be mentioned.

<ex>More and more resources have been devoted to halting [rogue nation's|Agent] [proliferation|Target] [of controlled nuclear technology|Set].</ex>

name: Cause_temperature_change
description:
In this frame, an #Agent changes the temperature of an #Item.  A #Temperature_goal can specify the desired temperature.  A #Temperature_change can also be indicated.  The #Temperature_start indicates the initial temperature.

<ex>[Margaret Anne|Agent] [chilled|Target] [the salad|Item] [to 30 degrees|Temperature_goal].</ex>
<ex>[Heat|Target] [the water|Item] [30 degrees|Temperature_change].</ex>

name: Cause_to_amalgamate
description:
These words refer to an #Agent joining #Parts to form a #Whole.  (The #Parts may also be encoded as #Part_1 and #Part_2.)  There is a symmetrical relationship between the components that undergo the process, and afterwards the #Parts are consumed and are no longer distinct entities that are easily discernable or separable in the #Whole.

<ex>[Chuck|Agent] [merged|Target] [the corpora|Parts].</ex><ex>
[Chuck|Agent] [merged|Target] [the corpora|Parts] [into a database|Whole].</ex>
<ex>[Chuck|Agent] [merged|Target] [the BNC|Part_1] [with the AP Corpus|Part_2] [into a database|Whole].</ex>
<ex>[The two forces|Parts] [merged|Target] [into a single, undifferentiated mass of murderous mayhem|Whole].(Sense 2)</ex>
<ex>Melt the butter, then [blend|Target] [it|Part_1] [with the room temperature milk|Part_2]. [CNI|Agent]</ex>

name: Cause_to_be_dry
description:
An #Agent causes a #Dryee (either a surface or an entire entity, inside and out) to become dry. This should not include examples like ""drying tears"" or ""drying spills"" as these are in the Removing frame.

<ex>[Michael|Agent] [dried|Target] [the clothes|Dryee].</ex>
<ex>[Abby|Agent] [dried|Target] [out|Target] [the room|Dryee] [with a dehumidifier|Instrument].</ex>

name: Cause_to_be_included
description:
An #Agent or #Cause makes a #New_member part of  #Group. The #Group may be represented by an individual #Existing_member if it implies the existence of a set of members.

<ex>[I|Agent] [added|Target] [a new rock|New_member] [to my collection|Group].</ex>
<ex>He decided he needed to [add|Target] [a red tie|New_member] [to the blue tie in his closet.|Existing_member]</ex>

name: Cause_to_be_sharp
description:
An #Agent or Cause makes a #Patient sharper or duller.  An #Instrument or #Means may be mentioned.

<ex>[John|Agent] is in the basement [sharpening|Target] [his axe|Patient].</ex>

name: Cause_to_be_wet
description: An #Agent causes a #Patient to be wet with a #Liquid.  In this frame, the #Liquid can be a liquid or gas.  #Patients are porous objects, but not hollow (like containers).  <ex>[Jo|Agent] [soaked|Target] [the dog|Patient] [with water|Liquid].</ex> <ex>[Ellen|Agent] [wet|Target]  [the sponge|Patient] [with water|Liquid].</ex>

name: Cause_to_burn
description: A #Cause event brings about and potentially maintains the burning of #Flammables.  Often, an #Agent stands in for the intentional action the brings about the fire, or an Actor stands in for the action that brings about the fire unintentionally.

name: Cause_to_continue
description:
An #Agent or #Cause causes a #Process or #State to continue.

<ex> [The goaltenders|agt] [kept|Target] [the game|pro] going [with terrific saves|mns].</ex>

name: Cause_to_end
description:
An #Agent or #Cause causes a #Process or #State to end.


<ex>[Bush|age] may [lift|Target] [sanctions|sta] on his own, despite opposition.</ex>

name: Cause_to_experience
description:
An #Agent intentionally seeks to bring about an internal mental or emotional state in the #Experiencer.  This frame in closely related to  Experiencer_obj.
<ex> [Samantha|Agent] [terrorized|Target] [the children|Experiencer] [into screaming|Resulting_action]. </ex>

name: Cause_to_fragment
description:
An #Agent suddenly and often violently separates the #Whole_patient into two or more smaller #Pieces, resulting in the #Whole_patient no longer existing as such.  Several lexical items are marked with the semantic type Negative, which indicates that the fragmentation is necessarily judged as injurious to the original #Whole_patient.

Compare this frame with Damaging, Render_non-functional, and Removing.

<ex>[He|Agent] [ripped|Target] [up|Target] [the letter|Pat] [faster than you can say ""Jack Robbins""|Manner]. [INI|Pieces]</ex>
<ex>Don't go in there or [you|Pat] 'll be [torn|Target] [to bits|Pieces]! [CNI|Agent]</ex>
<ex>[She|Agent] [shattered|Target] [the vase|Pat] [with a casual backhand blow|Means] [to make it look like there had been a struggle|Purp]. [INI|Pieces]</ex>
<ex>[Tear|Target] [into 6"" strips, each about one inch wide|Pieces], then bake at 400. [CNI|Agent] [CNI|Pat]</ex>

name: Cause_to_land
description:
An #Operator maneuvers onto land a #Vehicle which typically does not operate on land, e.g., an airplane or boat.

<ex>[The terrified pilot|ope] [landed|Target] [the passenger-filled airplane|veh] [into the river|Goal].</ex>

name: Cause_to_make_noise
description:
An #Agent manipulates a #Sound_maker or a #Cause causes the #Sound_maker to emit a sound.
<ex>[The monks|Agent] would [ring|Target] [the bell|Sound_maker] until sundown.</ex>

name: Cause_to_make_progress
description:
An #Agent works on a #Project so that it reaches a more advanced and desirable state.

<ex>[I|Agent] [improve|Target] [FrameNet|Project].</ex>

name: Cause_to_move_in_place
description:
An #Agent causes a #Theme to move with respect to a certain #Fixed_location, generally with a certain #Periodicity, without undergoing unbounded translational motion or significant alteration of configuration/shape.
<ex>[Paul|Agent] [shook|Target] [the remote control|Theme] [frantically|Manner].</ex>

name: Cause_to_perceive
description:
An #Agent, #Actor, #Entity, or #Medium causes a #Phenomenon to be perceived by a #Perceiver.  With an #Actor, #Entity, or #Medium, the #Perceiver is usually unspecified.

<ex>[Aileen|Agent] [showed|Target] [Rob|Perceiver] [the book|Phenomenon].</ex>
<ex>[He|Actor] [exhibited|Target] [great interest in the project|Phenomenon].</ex>
<ex>[The second scene|Medium] [depicts|Target] [ Dad |Phenomenon] [holding the ball for a place kick|Phenomenon].</ex>
<ex>[The economy|Entity] is [showing|Target] [signs of growth|Phenomenon].</ex>

NB: This may change in the future, but as of now this frame subsumes three closely-related cause/perceiver alternations:  a.) perception of a specific #Perceiver caused by an #Agent, b.) perception of some implicit audience caused, possibly unintentionally, by an #Actor, and c.) perception of some implicit audience caused by a #Medium or #Entity. Perhaps this frame is too broad - the different subject FEs seem to all indicate different ways of ""showing.""

name: Cause_to_resume
description:
An #Agent acts so as to cause some process to begin again after an interruption or suspension.

<ex>[The two countries|Agent] [revived|Target] [diplomatic relations|Process] [after a lull of five years|Hiatus].</ex>

name: Cause_to_rot
description: An #Patient, which is an organic substance, undergoes the natural process of decay due to a #Cause (or #Agent).  <ex>[Moisture|Cause] [rotted|Target] [the bread|Patient].</ex>

name: Cause_to_start
description:
A #Cause, animate or inanimate, causes a process, the #Effect, to begin.

<ex>[The murder of Sergei Kirov|Cause] [set off|Target] [a chain of events that culminated in the Great Terror of the 1930s|Effect].</ex>

<ex>[Space email|Cause] [sparked|Target] [astronaut jealousy|Effect].</ex>

<ex>[A crime surge in a former coal town|Cause] [prompted|Target] [a crackdown on illegal immigrants|Effect]</ex>.

name: Cause_to_wake
description:
An #Agent or #Cause causes a #Sleeper to transition from the #Sleep_state to wakeful consciousness.

<ex>[The earthquake|Cause] [woke|Target] [me|Sleeper] [from a nightmare|Sleep_state].</ex>

name: Ceasing_to_be
description:
An #Entity ceases to exist.

<ex>[Entire platoons|Entity] have [mysteriously|Manner] [vanished|Target] [from battle|Place], leaving enemy weapons to slice through empty air.</ex>

name: Ceremonies
description: There are three types of olympic ceremonies: the opening ceremony, the closing ceremony and the medal ceremony.

name: Certainty
description:
This frame concerns a #Cognizer's certainty about the correctness of beliefs  or expectations.
It only includes uses where a #Cognizer is expressed.

<ex>[Lermontov|Cognizer] <m>was</m> [certain|Target] [he would come to the party|Content].</ex>

name: Change
description: Change

name: Change_accessibility
description:
An #Agent causes a #Useful_location to become accessible (or non-accessible) to a #Theme to a certain #Degree. Instead of the #Useful_location, the scene may be described with reference to a #Portal (or part of the #Portal, e.g., a door) to the #Useful_location.

<ex>[They|age]'ve [blockaded|Target] [the entrance|por] -- no one can get in or out.</ex>

<ex>[Police|age] have [cordoned off|Target] [the area where the crime occurred|use].</ex>

<ex>[The area|use] has been [barricaded|Target] [to anyone but law enforcement officials|the].</ex>

name: Change_direction
description:
A #Theme that is in motion assumes a new #Direction in which it moves.


<ex>[We|Thm] took our chances and [turned|Target] [right|dir] [by a petrol station|Place] and, bingo, there she was--Fir Park.</ex>

<ex>Molly followed silently as [Desmond|Thm] left the large paneled hall and [turned|Target] [right|Direction] [through a swing door|Path] [into a long, bare corridor|Goal].</ex>

<ex>Cross O'Connell Bridge and continue along D'Olier Street, <m>make</m> a [right|Direction] [turn|Target] [onto College Street|Goal]. [CNI|Theme]</ex>

<ex>Go past the unattended guardhouse, and <m>take</m> a [sharp|ang] [left|Direction] [turn|Target] [down the ramp|Path]. [CNI|Theme]</ex>

<ex>Take the elevator to the sixth floor and <m>make</m> [two|Frequency] [[lefts|dir]|Target]. [CNI|Thm]</ex>

name: Change_event_duration
description:
In this frame, an #Agent or #Cause changes the duration of an #Event. The #Event will then take place for a #New_duration, rather than the #Initial_duration. This can be done with by certain #Means, in a certain #Manner or to a certain #Degree.

<ex>Don't let [him|Agent] [prolong|Target] [the discussion|Event] [to an absurd length|New_duration].</ex>

<ex>Harsh weather made it necessary to [cut|Target] [the tour|Event] [short|Target] [from its original four months|ini] [to three|new]. [CNI|Agent]</ex>

name: Change_event_time
description:
In this frame, an #Agent or #Cause changes the timing of an #Event. The #Event will then take place at the #Destination_time or with respect to a #Destination_event. This can be done with by certain #Means, in a certain #Manner or to a certain #Degree.

<ex>[The rain|Cause] [delayed|Target] [the baseball game|Event].</ex>

name: Change_of_consistency
description: In this frame a #Patient changes its consistency.  There may be a #Initial_state and a #Result.  Note that this frame contrasts with Change_of_phase in that this frame describes a change in a #Patient within a particular phase (solid, gas, liquid).  <ex>[The blood|Patient] [congealed|Target].</ex> <ex>[The liquid|Patient] [gelled|Target] [into a semi-solid mass|Result].</ex>

name: Change_of_leadership
description:
This frame concerns the appointment of a #New_leader or removal from office of an #Old_leader.  The #Selector brings about the change in leadership, for example, by electing or overthrowing a leader. There are two particular situations described by words in this frame: 1. making a #New_leader fill a #Role whether or not there was someone in the role previously (e.g., <ment>crown.v</ment>), and 2. successfully removing an #Old_leader from office (e.g. <ment>depose.v</ment>, <ment>oust.v</ment>).

<ex>On March 17 , [Mamedov|Selector] [appointed|Target] [Rakhim Gasiyev|New_leader] [as Defence Minister|Role] .</ex>

This frame should be compared to the Reject_leadership frame, in which there is only an attempt to change the power structure.  Compare also to the Appointing frame, which is used for words that refer to officially empowered agents designating entities to fill a particular function.  In the Appointing frame, the function may or may not be a leadership role, unlike targets in the Change_of_leadership frame.

name: Change_of_phase
description: In this frame a #Patient undergoes a change of phase.  Note that this frame contrasts with Change_of_consistency in that this frame describes a change of a #Patient between different phases (i.e. solid to liquid or frozen to ""unfrozen"").  <ex>[The water|Patient] [froze|Target].</ex> <ex>[The rock|Patient] [solidifies|Target] [from its molten state|Initial_state].</ex> <ex>[The lake|Patient] [froze|Target] [solid|Result].</ex> <ex>[The lake|Patient] [froze|Target] [into ice|Result].</ex> <ex>[The lake|Patient] [froze|Target] [to depths of 30 feet|Degree].</ex>

name: Change_of_phase_scenario
description: The sequence of events in which the #Patient begins as one state of matter and ends up as another.

name: Change_of_quantity_of_possession
description:
This frame describes a general situation in which an #Owner either increases or decreases their amount of a #Possession.  The increase or decrease may either be physical or metaphorical.
<ex>[The plant|Owner] [lost|Target] [water|Possession] [as the the temperature increased|Explanation].</ex>
<ex>[Gaining|Target] [leadership experience|Possession] is one of the benefits of being a camp counselor. [CNI|Owner]</ex>

name: Change_of_temperature
description:
In this frame, the temperature of an #Item changes.  An #Initial_temperature, #Final_temperature, or #Temperature_change can also be indicated.

<ex>[The house|Item] had [cooled|Target] [off|Target] [by a few more degrees|Temperature_change] [by midnight|Time], and we finally managed to eat a bite.</ex>

name: Change_operational_state
description:
A #Device or machine is put in (or out of) service either by a volitional #Agent or by a #Cause event or force acting on the #Device. The #Time when and the #Place where the #Device is put in or out of use may be specified, as may be the #Purpose of the human #Agent in changing the operational state of the #Device.

<ex>The laborer realized that [he|age] [activated|Target] [the machine|Device] but did not know how to stop it.</ex>

name: Change_position_on_a_scale
description:
This frame consists of words that indicate the change of an #Item's position on a scale (the #Attribute) from a starting point (#Initial_value) to an end point (#Final_value). The direction (#Path) of the movement can be indicated as well as the magnitude of the change (#Difference).  The rate of change of the value (#Speed) is optionally indicated.  Another scale (#Correlated_variable), which the values are correlated with, is indicated if it is not the default correlate (namely, absolute time).

<ex></ex>
The distinction between #Attributes and #Items is not always an easy one. The clear cases involve the expression of the
#Attribute in an <ment>in</ment>-PP.

<ex>[Hawke's Bay winery|Item] [doubled|Target] [in size|Attribute] [last year|Time].</ex>

<ex>The amount you can deduct, then, depends on whether or not [the stock|Item] has [increased|Target] [in value|Attribute] [during the period you have owned it|Time].</ex>

Other clear cases of #Attributes involve NP's like <ment>size, quality, number, value</ment> that denote abstract attributes rather than events or classes of things.


<ex></ex>
The analysis is more complicated when an event-denoting noun phrase occurs as the subject and the sentence has no <ment>in</ment>-PP. In the simplest cases, where the #Attribute is the number of occurrences of the event, the #Attribute is usually left implicit, as in exx. 1 and 2, the #Attribute below.

<ex>(1)[Accidents|Item] [increased|Target] [20%|Difference] [to 345|val2].</ex>
<ex>(1--second FE layer)Accidents [increased|Target] 20% [to 345|Attribute].</ex>
<ex>(2) [Attacks on civilians|Item] [decreased|Target] [over the last 4 months|Time]
[DNI|Attribute].</ex>

In cases  like (1), we will tag the #Attribute on the second layer below the #Final_value label, as that FE makes
it clear that the #Attribute is simply cardinality. In cases like (2), we tag it as DNI because in context the hearer has
to understand a particular #Attribute rather than just some or any appropriate #Attribute of the
#Item.  Note that the above pattern can be compared to cases involving tangible #Items, where the #Attribute may similarly be missing when the incidence or frequency of the #Item is specified.

<ex>(3) [Woodland birds|Item] [increased|Target][to their highest level since 1990|val2] [DNI|Attribute].</ex>

A more complicated case involving event-denoting subjects is when the #Attribute measured is not the incidence of the type of event specified but rather an #Attribute of an event-participant. In (4), it is not the <ment>number of times</ment> that turbot was caught that has changed but the <ment>amount</ment> of fish caught.

<ex>(4) [Turbot catches|Item] [increased|Target] [from around 100 tonnes in the 1960s|val1] [to around 1,200 tonnes in the mid 1990s|val2].</ex>
<ex>(4-second FE layer) Turbot catches [increased|Target] [from around 100 tonnes in the 1960s|att] [to around 1,200 tonnes in the mid 1990s|att].</ex>

(Note the 2nd layer annotation of the #Attribute below the #Initial_value and #Final_value FEs, since they indicate that the #Attribute is implicitly <ment>weight</ment>.)

Similarly, in (5), the report is (in context) about the total monetary value of the gifts, not about the number of donations made.

<ex>(5)[Overall Giving by Church Members|Item] [increased|Target]  from 2000 to 2001</ex>

As can be seen from the above examples, we consider the event nouns in uses such as (4) and (5) to also specify #Items. Note that in cases like (4), we do not want to treat the subject NP ""turbot catches"" as an #Attribute that includes information about the #Item, since it would not make sense to restate (4) as follows:

<ex>*Turbot [increased|Target] in catches.</ex>

Two more complications arise. First, certain nouns that do not, by their etymology, denote abstract attributes have a second sense in which they do denote an #Attribute.

<ex>(6) The population of Smallville [increased|Target] fourfold to 807.</ex>


Under one reading, (6a), the population could be understood as referring to ""the people"", in which case the #Attribute <ment>cardinality</ment> is understood as unexpressed, as in (1),  (2), and (3).  The #Attribute could be overtly specified:

<ex>(6a) [The population of Smallville|ite] [increased|Target] [fourfold|Diff] [in size|att] [to 807|val2].</ex>

Under another reading, (6b), population is an #Attribute that habitats or locations possess. In this case, the whole NP ""the population of Smallville"" is treated as the #Attribute and on the second layer ""of Smallville"" is tagged as #Item.

<ex>(6b) [The population of Smallville|att] [increased|Target] [fourfold|Diff] [to 807|val2].</ex>
<ex>(6b-second FE layer) The population [of Smallville|ite] [increased|Target] fourfold to 807.</ex>
Support for the possibility of this second reading comes from the fact that you can also state the facts as in (6c).

<ex>(6c) [Smallville|ite] [increased|Target] [fourfold|Diff] [in population|att] [to 807|val2].</ex>


The last complication is that #Initial_value expressions can also function as the subject, which superficially look like expressions of #Attribute.

<ex>(7) [The 1999 price|val1] had [increased|Target] [to $3400|val2] [by 2001|Time].</ex>
<ex>(7--second layer) The 1999 [price|att] had [increased|Target] to $3400 by 2001.</ex>

There is no #Attribute ""1999 price"" here (though the concept is plausible in certain special statistical contexts where prices are indexed to prices of a particular year). (7) simply reports that the value of the price-#Attribute changed from whatever it was in 1999 to the new value of $3400 by 2001. For sentence (7), #Attribute would only be indicated as ""price"" on the 2nd layer.

name: Change_post-state
description:
The frame represents the result state of the #Entity after an event represented by the Undergo_change frame.

<ex>The original , [unaltered|Target] [version|Entity] of the story had been used initially as a sample exercise.</ex>

name: Change_posture
description:
A #Protagonist changes the overall position and posture of the body.

<ex>[Smithers|Protagonist] [leaned|Target] [forward|Direction] [to grab the folder on the far side|Purpose].</ex>

name: Change_resistance
description:
An #Agent changes a #Patient's ability to resist literal or figurative attack. This frame differs from Cause_change_of_strength only in that the #Patient is restricted to acting as a defensive force, i.e., it can resist but not exert force.

<ex>[We|Agent] [bulwarked|Target] [the castle|Patient] [against the oncoming horde|Attack].</ex>

name: Change_tool
description:
An #Agent changes #Tools, from the #Old_tool to a #New_tool.  The #Tools may include vehicles, services providers, or more proto-typical implements.

<ex>If this happens one more time, [we|age] 're going to [switch|Target] [operating systems|tos].</ex>

<ex>[Stephen|age] had to [transfer|Target] [five times|ite] [by the time he got to Lincolnville|tim]. [DNI|tos].</ex>

This frame should be compared to the Replacing frame.  Words of the Change_tool frame portray a change in the #Agent and which tool they interact with, while the Replacing frame portrays a manipulation of New to occupy the position of the Old.

name: Chaos
description:
The lexical units in this frame have to do with an #Entity being in a #State of order or disorder.  Often the #Entity is unexpressed in this frame and is, therefore, marked as a null instantiation.
<ex></ex>
<ex>Soon [the system|Ent] was <m>in</m> [total|Degree] [[chaos|St]|Target].</ex>
<ex></ex>
<ex>Fifa had already fined the Brazilians a minor sum for [crowd|Ent] [[disorder|St]|Target].</ex>
<ex></ex>
<ex>He had a hammer and banged it against the walls to restore [[order|St]|Target] but nobody took any notice of him. [INI|Ent]</ex>

name: Chatting
description:
A group of people (the #Interlocutors or #Interlocutor_1 and #Interlocutor_2 together) have a conversation.  No person is construed as only a speaker or only an addressee. Rather, it is understood that both (or all) participants do some speaking and some listening--the process is understood to be symmetrical or reciprocal.  In this frame, the purpose of the conversation is generally social, rather than specifically to decide something or exchange information, or to quarrel (see Discussion and Quarreling).

<ex>If you ain't got nothin' better to do, [I|Interlocutor_1] 'd like to [shoot|Target] [the|Target] [breeze|Target] [with you|Interlocutor_2] [for a couple|Duration].</ex>
<ex>[We|Interlocutors] used to [chat|Target] [about everything|Topic].</ex>

name: Chemical-sense_description
description:
This  frame covers the descriptions of tastes and smells, and has one main frame element, #Perceptual_source. The frame element #Sensory_attribute occurs mainly with the words taste, flavour, and smell.

<ex>The almonds had a [bitter|Target] [taste|Sensory_attribute].</ex>
<ex>[The almonds|Perceptual_source] <m>are</m> [bitter|Target].</ex>

name: Chemical_potency
description: This frame contains words that describe how potent a chemical is.

name: Choosing
description:
A #Cognizer decides upon the #Chosen (either an item or a course of action) out of a set of  #Possibilities .  The #Cognizer may have an #Inherent_purpose or a #Larger_purpose for the #Chosen.
Often an #Explanation, which serves as the basis of the choice, is given.

<ex>[The council|Cognizer] [picked|Target] [you|Chosen] [out of all the pilots available|Possibilities] [to head this mission|Inherent_purpose].</ex>
<ex>[No one|Cognizer] would [choose|Target] [to live in such squalor|Chosen].</ex>
<ex>If [no judge|Chosen] was [unanimously|Manner] [selected|Target] [in the previous round|Time], play rock-paper-scissors pairwise. [CNI|Cognizer]</ex>

name: Circumscribed_existence
description:
An #Entity is understood to be experienceable within a particular set of delimited #Circumstances, which may be more narrowly expressed by a #Time, #Place.

<ex>[This type of behavior|Entity] [occurs|Target] [in several primate mating rituals|Circumstances].</ex>
<ex>[Craft beers|Entity] have started to [appear|Target] [in grocery stores all over the country|Place].</ex>

name: Citing
description:
A #Defendant is officially summoned to appear in #Court by an #Authority (such as the police) based on certain #Charges. Alternatively, there is often an option for the #Defendant to pay a #Fine (thereby admitting their guilt) instead of going to #Court.

<ex>[The police|Auth] had [summonsed|Target] [the wrong man|Dfnd]. [DNI|Chrg]</ex>

<ex>[Since 1989|Tim] nearly a million [summonses|Target] have been issued [to people|Dfnd] [for not paying their water bills|Chrg]. [CNI|Auth]</ex>

<ex>[The officer|Auth] [cited|Target] [him|Dfnd] [for riding a bike without a light|Chrg].</ex>

Three related frames are Notification_of_charges, Entering_of_plea, and Fining.
This frame is distinguished from Notification_of_charges in that it typically deals with less serious #Charges and/or offenses. It also involves more than just notifying the #Defendant (Accused in the Notification_of_charges frame) of the #Charges being brought against them; LUs in the Citing frame also require that the #Defendant take some form of action (go to #Court or pay a #Fine). Similarly, Citing differs from Entering_of_plea because its scenario encompasses more than the latter; Citing involves steps both before and after the #Defendant enters a Plea in answer to #Charges. Finally, this frame differs from Fining since the #Defendant (Payer in the Fining frame) does not necessarily end up paying a #Fine. He or she may go to #Court instead.

name: Civil_rights_and_duties
description: Civil_rights_and_duties

name: Claim_ownership
description:
A #Claimant asserts his or her right to possession of a piece of #Property (either real, such as land, or private).  The Claimant may be acting on the behalf of a #Beneficiary.
<ex>[The King|Claimant] [claims|Target] [this land and surrounding waters|Property].</ex>
<ex>Hoping to strike it rich, Thaddeus Gulch staked [his|Claimant] [claim|Target] by the river bed.</ex>
<ex>[I|Claimant] <supp>have</supp> [dibs|Target] [on the last piece of cake|Property].</ex>

name: Clemency
description:
An #Executive_authority exercises their power to reduce or remove negative consequences for someone who has been labeled an #Offender who participated in an #Crime.

<ex>[A Fort Worth man convicted of a robbery his brother later confessed
to committing|off] was <m>granted</m> [clemency|Target] [on December 20, 2002|zei], [by Governor Rick Perry|exe].</ex>
<ex>A Fort Worth man convicted [of a robbery his brother later confessed
to committing|cri] was <m>granted</m> [clemency|Target] on December 20, 2002, by Governor Rick Perry.</ex>


<ex>Engel represented Robert Bacon, [the first man|off] [Easley|exe] <m>gave</m> [clemency|Target] [in 2001|zei]. [INI|cri] </ex>

<ex>Ohioans will receive a blow-by-blow account of arguments before the Ohio Parole Board on whether [Cincinnatian John Byrd Jr.|off] should be executed or <m>granted</m> [clemency|Target] [for a 1983 murder|cri]. [CNI|exe]</ex>

name: Closure
description:
An #Agent manipulates a #Fastener to open or close a #Containing_object (e.g. coat, jar).  Sometimes an #Enclosed_region or a #Container_portal may be expressed. Since the #Manipulator is syntactically omissible, many verbs in this frame incorporate the #Fastener.

<ex>[Mary|Agent] [closed|Target] [her coat|Containing_object] [with a belt|Fastener].</ex>
<ex>[Mary|Agent] [closed|Target] [her coat|Containing_object] [with one hand|Manipulator].</ex>
<ex>[Mary|Agent] [buttoned|Target] [her coat .|Containing_object]</ex>

name: Clothing
description:
This frame refers to clothing and its characteristics,  including anything that people conventionally wear.  The #Wearer wears a #Garment that has a certain #Style, is made of a certain #Material, and can be otherwise characterized by a #Descriptor.  In some cases, the #Body_location (where the garment is worn) and #Subregion of the clothing may also be specified.

<ex>Claudia dressed in a [dark|Descriptor] [green|Descriptor] [cotton|Material] [DRESS|Target] clasped round her slender waist with a broad yellow belt , drank a cup of coffee and opened her neglected post .</ex>

name: Clothing_parts
description:
The #Subparts of #Clothing items worn by a #Wearer and made of a certain #Material.  The #Subpart may itself have parts, which we label #Subregion:

<ex>The shirt features a long [sleeve|Target] [with shiny gold buttons|Subregion].</ex>

name: Co-association
description: Two or more individuals have a relationship by virtue of belonging to the same organization or institution. They may or may not be personally acquainted, and may or may not have chosen to have the relationship.

name: Coaching_staff
description: Group of coaches, doctors and physical trainers that accompany a squad.

name: Cogitation
description:
A person, the #Cognizer, thinks about a #Topic over a period of time. What is thought about may be a course of action that the person might take, or something more general.

<ex>[The men|Cognizer] were [silently|Manner] [mulling|Target] [over|Target] [the proposition of committing an assassination|Topic]</ex>

name: Cognitive_connection
description:
A concept, #Concept_1, is related causally or collocationally to another concept, #Concept_2 by means of some evidence.  They may be related only under certain #Circumstances or from a certain #Point_of_view.  The two concepts may be expressed collectively as associated #Concepts.  Any cognizer is deprofiled.

<ex>[Smoking|Concept_1] is [tied|Target] [to cancer|Concept_2].</ex>

name: Coincidence
description:
A State_of_affairs (a state or event) either holds or occurs, and is presented as being causally independent of other (implicit) states or events that might otherwise have been expected to be causally related to the State_of_affairs. The Time or Place may also be mentioned.

<ex>[That they got the same answers|State_of_affairs] is just a [coincidence|Target].</ex>

name: Collaboration
description:
#Partner_1 and #Partner_2 or a group of #Partners  work together in some #Undertaking. The #Partners are taken to be of equal status even when expressed disjointly.

<ex> [CSTR|Partner_1] [actively|Manner] [collaborates|Target] [with the Departments of Artificial Intelligence  and Physics|Partner_2]. </ex>
<ex> [Tom and  the American composer Steve Riche|Partners] have [recently|Time] [collaborated|Target] [on a piece of elevator music|Undertaking].</ex>

name: Collocation_image_schema
description: A #Profiled_region is specified as entirely or largely coinciding with that of a #Ground.

name: Colonization
description:
A group of #Colonists from a #Homeland migrate to and proceed to settle in a #New_area. The #New_area then becomes their permanent home. The #New_area and #Homeland are in some way construed as being part of the same organization or system. In the case of (people from) nation-states colonizing other areas, the colony and nation-state are considered a single political entity. In the extended sense of living things in general colonizing or settling a new area, the original #Homeland must still inhabited by some of the same group. In this sense Colonization is distinct from migration or exodus.

<ex>[In the 7th century BC|tim], [Phoenicians|col] [colonized|Target] [the eastern section of Libya|new].</ex>
<ex>In the 7th century BC, [Phoenicians|hom] [colonized|Target] the eastern section of Libya.</ex>
<ex>[Finns|col] [colonized|Target] [the land|new] from the south [some 2,000 to 4,000 years ago|tim]</ex>
<ex>If a [colony|Target] [from Britain|new] was established in that large tract of Country, and if we were at war with Holland or Spain, we might very powerfully annoy either state from our new settlement.</ex>

This frame also includes metaphorical uses involving animals or plants, or abstract domains such as ideas.

<ex>[Deciduous trees such as red alder|col] [subsequently|tim] [colonized|Target] [the logged area|new].</ex>

<ex>Conservatives don't get what the left gets, which is that [the left|col] has [already|tim] [colonized|Target] and converted [whole university departments|new].</ex>

<ex>As the years progressed and adaptations occurred [new species and subspecies|col] began to [populate|Target] [the islands|hom].</ex>

name: Color
description:
