A #Color serves as a landmark in color-space, either a point-like landmark (e.g. <ment>burnt sienna</ment>) or a broader region (e.g. <ment>blue</ment>).  Especially when the #Color designates a broad region in color-space, it may be defined with a specific #Type, further specified by comparison to the color of a #Comparand, modified by a #Color_qualifier, or evaluated with a #Descriptor.  All color words are generally used to specify the color of some (physical) #Entity.
<ex>I really like that shade of [[blue|Target]|Color].</ex>
<ex>[The welts on his side|Entity] had already <m>turned</m> an [angry|Descriptor] [[red|Target]|Color].</ex>
<ex>The room was bathed in a soft [[pink|Target]|Color] [light|Entity].</ex>
<ex>They promptly set up a zillion [bright|Color_qualifier] [[vermilion|Target]|Color] [pavilions|Entity].</ex>
<ex>[His face and hands|Entity] <m>were</m> [[brown|Target]|Color] [from a life spent in the bright sun of the fields|Cause].</ex>

name: Color_qualities
description:
This frame contains words that describe specific aspects of a #Color. The #Degree to which the #Color being discussed deviates from the prototype may be marked. The description may also target a specific Aspect of color.

<ex>I love [really|Degree] [pale|Target] [yellows|Color].</ex>

name: Come_down_with
description:
A #Protagonist comes to suffer from a #Disease, often implicitly acquired from a #Source.

<ex>She [got|Target] the measles .</ex>
<ex>The virus when [acquired|Target] from environmental sources is often less severe .</ex>
<ex>I 'm afraid I 've [come down|Target] with a cold .</ex>

name: Come_into_effect
description:
A #Binding_principle, previously only existing as a concept or formulation, enters an ""active"" phase or state. Often, the enactments of rules and regulations are described with this frame.

<ex>The [new curfew laws|Binding_principle] [kicked in|Target] [last weekend.|Time]</ex>

name: Come_together
description:
In this frame a group of #Individuals meet to form a #Configuration. The #Individuals or the #Configuration may be expressed as the external argument of the predicates in this frame. In this frame, it is ambiguous whether or not the #Individuals intentionally come together.  In an alternative construal, a grammatically more prominent #Party_1 congregates with a #Party_2, expressed as an oblique phrase. If this asymmetric construal is chosen, #Purpose relates only to #Party_1.
<ex></ex>
The congregating happens in a certain #Place and at a certain #Time.
<ex></ex>
<ex>[The crowd|Configuration] [came together|Target] [in the courtyard|Place].</ex>
<ex>[The architects|Individuals] [amassed|Target] [in the lobby|Place].</ex>

name: Coming_to_be
description:
An #Entity comes into existence at a particular #Place and #Time which may take a certain #Duration_of_final_state, have a #Explanation, or be formed from #Components.

<ex>[Problems|Entity] may [arise|Target] [whenever an S1 sophont enters the game|Time].</ex>
<ex>[Mountains|Entity] [sometimes|Time] [form|Target] [in as little as a million years|Period_of_iterations].</ex>
<ex>[A new paradigm|Entity] [emerged|Target] [from the discussion of nuclear weapons|Explanation].</ex>
<ex>[New Plants|Entity] [form|Target] [from the cut veins|Components] [in two weeks|Period_of_iterations].</ex>

name: Coming_to_believe
description:
A person (the #Cognizer) comes to believe something (the #Content), sometimes after a process of reasoning. This change in belief is usually initiated by a person or piece of #Evidence. Occasionally words in this domain are accompanied by phrases expressing #Topic, i.e. that which the mental #Content is about.

<ex>[Based on the most recent census|Evidence] [I|Cognizer] have [concluded|Target] [that most Americans sleep too much|Content].</ex>

name: Coming_up_with
description:
Words in this frame have to do with a #Cognizer creating a new intellectual entity, the #Idea. These words are similar to words of physical creation such as <ment>build</ment> and <ment>make</ment>, and in some cases may be understood as metaphorically based on such words. However, the #Ideas in this frame are predominantly conceptual in nature.

Compare this frame with Achieving_first.  In that frame, the fact that the idea is new to society is emphasized, whereas Coming_up_with refers to an agentive #Cognizer using mental effort to figure something out, without any implication of the impact of the idea.

<ex>[I|Cog] 've been trying to [come up|Target] [with a plan|Idea] .</ex>

name: Commemorative
description:
This frame describes a particular compounding construction (a pattern of coinage) by which more complex words can be created by joining an #Honored_entity to a #Dedicated_type to describe a particular #Dedicated_entity which has been officially named for the #Honored_entity.  The #Dedicated_type and #Honored_entity FEs each form part of the Lexical Units (annotated on the second FE layer), and the #Dedicated_entity is the denotation of the whole.  Since each of the FEs is a part of the Lexical Unit, there is no assignment of Grammatical Function or Phrase Type.  The #Dedicated_type should (in principle) also be annotated as a LU in a separate frame.  Targets are added opportunistically to this frame in the course of annotating other frames.  For example, the Day of [Armistice Day|Target] should also be annotated in the Calendric_unit frame.

<ex>1st layer:  Turn right at the [[Jefferson Building|Target]|ded].</ex>
<ex>2nd layer:  Turn right at the [Jefferson|Honored_entity] [Building|Dedicated_type].</ex>

name: Commerce_buy
description:
These are words describing a basic commercial transaction involving a #Buyer and a #Seller exchanging #Money and #Goods, taking the perspective of the #Buyer.  The words vary individually in the patterns of frame element realization they allow.  For example, the typical pattern for the verb BUY:
#Buyer buys #Goods from #Seller for #Money.
<ex></ex>
<ex>[Abby|Buyer] bought [a car|Goods] [from Robin|Seller] [for $5,000|Money].</ex>

name: Commerce_collect
description:
Subframe of Commerce_money-transfer in which the #Seller comes to have the #Money.

<ex>[The man at the counter|Seller] [collected|Target] [payment|Money] [from Lee|Buyer] [for his dry-cleaning|Goods].</ex>

name: Commerce_goods-transfer
description: The subframe of the Commercial_transaction in which the Seller gives the Goods to the Buyer (in exchange for the Money).

name: Commerce_money-transfer
description: The subframe of the Commercial_transaction frame which involves the transfer of Money from the Buyer to the Seller (in exchange for the Goods).

name: Commerce_pay
description:
This frame involves #Buyers paying #Money for #Goods.  In this frame the #Money is the direct object, and is mapped to the theme of the transfer.

<ex>[I|Buyer] [paid|Target] [her|Seller] [$50|Money] [for a video game|Goods].</ex>

name: Commerce_scenario
description:
Commerce is a situation in which a #Buyer and a #Seller have agreed upon an exchange of #Money and #Goods (possibly after a negotiation), and then perform the exchange, optionally carrying it out with various kinds of direct payment or financing or the giving of change.

The #Seller indicates their willingness to give the #Goods in their possession to a #Buyer who would give them some amount of #Money.  The #Seller may have already decided on the amount of money that they would require, in which case it is called the Asking price.

The #Buyer also indicates their willingness to give an amount of money called an Offer to a #Seller who would give them the #Goods.

Normally the process is begun by the #Seller.  The means by which the #Seller indicates their wish to engage in an exchange are various, ranging from putting a price tag on an item on a store shelf, to advertizing, to communicating directly and specifically with a possible #Buyer.  In some cases, however, the process may be initiated by the #Buyer indicating to a possible #Seller that they would like to make an exchange.

<ex>[buyer|Target] beware.</ex>

name: Commerce_sell
description:
These are words describing basic commercial transactions involving a buyer and a seller exchanging money and goods, taking the perspective of the seller.  The words vary individually in the patterns of frame element realization they allow. For example, the typical patterns for SELL: SELLER sells GOODS to BUYER for MONEY.

<ex>[Robin|Seller] [sold|Target] [a car|Goods] [to Abby|Buyer] [for $5,000|Money].</ex>

name: Commercial_transaction
description:
These are words that describe basic commercial transactions involving a #Buyer and a #Seller who exchange #Money and #Goods.  The individual words vary in the frame element realization patterns.
For example, the typical patterns for the verbs buy and sell are:
BUYER buys GOODS from the SELLER for MONEY.
SELLER sells GOODS to the BUYER for MONEY.

<ex>[His|Buyer] [$20|Money] [transaction|Target] [with Amazon.com|Seller] [for a new TV|Goods] had been very smooth.</ex>

name: Commitment
description:
A #Speaker makes a commitment to an #Addressee to carry out some future action.  This may be an action desirable (as with <ment>promise</ment>) or not desirable (as with <ment>threaten</ment>) to the #Addressee. Some of the words in this frame allow an #Addressee to be expressed.
<ex>[You|Speaker] [promised|Target] [me|Addressee] [you'd come to my graduation|Message].</ex>
Other words cannot normally occur with an #Addressee.
<ex>[Kim|Speaker] [undertook|Target] [to finish the project by June|Message].</ex>

name: Committing_crime
description:
A #Perpetrator (generally intentionally) commits a #Crime, i.e. does something not permitted by the laws of society.

<ex>[They|Perp] [perpetrated|Target] [a felony|Cr] [by substituting a lie for negotiations|Means].</ex>

<ex>[The suspect|Perp] had allegedly [committed|Target] [the crime|Cr] [to gain the attention of a female celebrity|Purpose].</ex>

name: Commonality
description:
This frame contains words that describe a set of individuals which possess some #Commonality, generally a common attribute.

<ex>[Their|Entities] [common|Target] [enemy|Commonality] was Britain.</ex>

name: Communicate_categorization
description:
A #Speaker communicates a message stating an #Item's membership in a #Category, i.e., asserts that the #Item has the defining characteristics of the #Category. Alternatively, the message is conceived as communicated by a #Medium.

<ex>[He|Speaker] [depicted|Target] [his involvement|Item] [as merely peripheral|Category].</ex>

<ex>[The first half of the book|Medium] [portrays|Target] [Bragg's mother|Item] [as a beautiful and heartbroken woman|Category]</ex>.

name: Communication
description:
A #Communicator conveys a #Message to an #Addressee; the #Topic and #Medium of the communication also may be expressed.  This frame includes no specification of the method of communication (speech, writing, gesture, etc.).  This frame and the frames that inherit the general Communication frame can add elaboration to the #Medium in a variety of ways (<m>in French, on the radio program, in a letter</m>) or to the #Manner of communication (<m>babble, rant, shout, whisper</m>). There are also frames related to Communication that either do not inherit all of the FEs of this frame or do not inherit them in a straightforward manner (such as Conversation, in which #Communicator and #Addressee alternate roles, and are often expressed by a single, plural NP).

<ex>Let's hope [it|Communicator] did n't have time to [communicate|Target] [any of its findings|Message] [to its overlords|Addressee].</ex>

NB:  For many words in this domain (those which do not inherently ascribe cognitive/social processes to a #Communicator, position a statement within a conversation, or specify #Medium in detail), there is a metaphorical usage which maps Communication onto an alternate POV of Becoming_aware, with corresponding maps for frames related to Communication.  This metaphor is most felicitous with #Means or #Medium subjects, which are mapped onto the Evidence FE of Becoming_aware.  In many cases this metaphor maps Communication onto the Evidence frame, but not always.  Some words from the Communication domain are listed in the Evidence frame since they are deemed to be lexicalized.

<ex>[A flick of his gaze toward the doorway|Means] [told|Target] [me|Addressee] [what he really wanted|Message]. (METAPHOR)</ex>
<ex>[This painting|Medium] really [speaks|Target] [to me|Addressee]. [INI|Message] (MET) </ex>
<ex>[Putting his arm around her protectively|Means] achieved nothing but [announcing|Target] [to their captors|Addressee] [their vulnerability|Message]. (MET)</ex>
<ex><ment>It</ment> [says|Target] [a lot|Message] [that he did n't come back|Means]. [INI|Addressee] (MET) </ex>

name: Communication_manner
description:
The words in this frame describe #Manners of verbal communication.  All of them can occur with quoted expressions.

<ex>[He|Speaker] [slurred|Target] [his confession|Message].</ex>

name: Communication_means
description:
This frame concerns #Communicators communicating with each other with the aid of a #Means of communication such as a telephone.

<ex>[I|Communicator] [[faxed|Target]|Means] [him|Addressee] [a resume|Message].</ex>

name: Communication_noise
description:
A #Speaker produces a notable or unusual noise and thus communicates a #Message to an #Addressee.  This frame contains words for types of noise which can be used to characterize verbal communication.  It inherits from Communication (possibly more specifically Communication_manner) and Uses the Make_noise frame (which simply characterizes basic sounds of whatever source, including those made by animals and inanimate objects).
<ex></ex>
<ex>[""Don't treat me as a child!""|Message] [she|Speaker] [cried|Target] [scornfully|Manner].</ex>

<ex>[A writer in the Town Planning Review|Speaker] [trumpeted|Target] [that train-sheds were now obsolete|Message].</ex>

<ex>You know [he|Speaker] [yelled|Target] [at Aunt Lou|Addressee] [yesterday|Time], [because he slipped on that mat in the hall|Explanation].</ex>

name: Communication_response
description:
This frame deals with a #Speaker communicating a reply or response, a #Message, to some prior communication or action, the #Trigger.
<ex></ex>
<ex>[The landlord|Speaker] has not yet [replied|Target] [in writing|Medium] [to the tenant|Addressee] [objecting the proposed alterations|Message].[DNI|Trigger]</ex>

<ex>[""No, I do not agree with you,""|Message] [responded|Target] [another officer|Speaker] [to the CEO|Addressee]. [DNI|Trigger]</ex>

name: Communicative_context
description: This frame contains the contextual factors relevant to the communicative interaction, in particular the #Communicators (#Utterer, #Comprehender), as well as the #Place and #Time. If a pragmatic frame is evoked, this will imply the co-evocation of this non-lexical frame Communicative_Context. Following Sanders et al. (2009), several mental spaces are activated in a communicative interaction: Content, Epistemic, Speech Act and Metalinguistic spaces, as well as a Base Space of the #Utterer's reality. This frame builds on this Basic Communicative Space Network (BCSN), providing as frame elements aspects of the Speech Act Space in particular.

name: Commutation
description:
An #Executive_authority exchanges one penalty, the #Original_punishment, for another less severe one, the #New_punishment. The #Offender is who received the #Original_punishment is usually expressed as a modifier.

<ex>[On December 15, 1971|zei], [Governor Winfield Dunn|exe] conditionally [commuted|Target] [his sentence|ori] [to twenty years|new].</ex>

<ex>On December 15, 1971, Governor Winfield Dunn conditionally [commuted|Target] [his|off] sentence to twenty years.</ex>

<ex>She served about two years before [President Carter|exe] [commuted|Target] [her sentence|ori].</ex>
<ex>She served about two years before President Carter [commuted|Target] [her|off] sentence.</ex>

name: Commutative_process
description:
LUs in this frame describe a commutative operation of arithmetic, e.g. addition and multiplication, involving two numbers, labeled #Term1 and #Term2 or, collectively, #Terms. When referencing the process, the numbers can be vague and are often omitted through indefinite null instantiation. There may also be a #Calculator who applies the operation.

<ex>[Add|Target] [three|Term1] [to five|Term2].</ex>
<ex>Any kid knows [addition|Target]. [INI|Terms]</ex>

name: Commutative_statement
description:
LUs in this frame describe a stative relationship between two numbers,#Term1 and #Term2 or, collectively, #Terms, via a commutative arithmetic operation. The numbers are specifically expressed, along with the Result of the operation.

<ex>The [sum|Target] of [two and three|Terms] is [five|Result].</ex>
<ex>That's [three|Term1] [times|Target] [the amount I asked for|Term2]!</ex>

name: Compatibility
description:
#Item_1 and #Item_2 are compatible with each other if they can exist or function together in some context without problems, conflict, or other undesirable situation.  The set of #Item_1 and #Item_2 may be expressed jointly as #Items. The #Degree to which the Items are compatible may also be indicated, as may be a #Parameter along whose lines the #Items are compatible.

<ex> Make sure [your site|Item_1] is [compatible|Target] [with any browser|Item_2].</ex>
<ex>[Our software applications|Items]  are [compatible|Target]. </ex>

name: Competition
description:
This frame is concerned with the idea that people (#Participant_1, #Participant_2, or #Participants) participate in an organized, rule-governed activity (the #Competition) in order to achieve some advantageous outcome (often the #Prize).  #Rank and #Score are different criteria by which the degree of achievement of the advantageous outcome is judged.

<ex>[He and I|Participants] [played|Target] [tennis|Competition].</ex>

name: Complaining
description:
A #Complainer communicates their negative emotional reaction to some state of affairs in a #Complaint to an #Addressee. As an alternative to the specific #Complaint, the #Topic of the speaker's #Complaint may be specified. Likewise, instead of (or in addition to) the #Complainer, a #Medium may be stated.


<ex>The [top US commander in Iraq|Complainer] [complained|Target] [to the Pentagon|Add] [last winter|Time] [that his supply situation was so poor that it threatened Army troops' ability to fight|Complaint].</ex>


<ex>He said [he|Complainer] will <m>lodge</m> a [complaint|Target] [with the ACCC|Add]. [DNI|Complaint]</ex>

<ex>[On the rare occasions|Time] [I|Complainer] [complained|Target] [to him|Add] [about media bias|Topic], Peter immediately ordered up a story that included conservative objections to mainstream reports .</ex>

<ex>[The Op-Eds|Medium] were full of [gripes|Target] [about the recent tax hike|Top].</ex>

name: Completeness
description:
A #Whole, an entity with a substructure, is assessed for whether or not it has all the necessary parts that are defined for it or for an entity of its kind. The entity can be a concrete physical thing, an abstract thing, or a process with goals or sub-goals.


<ex>What happens after [the PPB investigation|who] <m>is</m> [complete|Target]? </ex>

<ex>Enter the number of days since the last [complete|Target] [backup|who] was made.</ex>

<ex>This distinguishes them from organisms in the phylum Platyhelminthes, who have only an [incomplete|Target] [digestive tract|who].</ex>

<ex>Auditors should also assess the accuracy and [completeness|Target] [of the systems and data|who].</ex>

<ex>We now have an [almost|deg] [complete|Target] [understanding|who] of the model</ex>

When the entity is a process with a goal, then what is assessed for completeness can either be the extent to which all candidate participants are involved in or affected by the process, or the stage that the process has reached. Thus the last of the above examples can either mean that all parts of the model are understood or that the model is fully understood as opposed to, for  instance, merely intuitively apprehended.

name: Compliance
description:
This frame concerns #Acts and #State_of_affairs for which #Protagonists are responsible and which either follow or violate some set of rules  or #Norms.
<ex></ex>

<ex>A lot of people suspect that [blocking savers' access to their money|Act] [violates|Target] [the new constitution's explicit ban on compulsory loans to the government|Norm].</ex>

<ex>Not that by [adhering|Target] [to the subject-before-predicate principle|Norm], [the translator of the above extract|Protagonist] has had to ignore the principle of end-weight.</ex>

name: Concessive
description:
A speaker marks a #Conceded_state_of_affairs as being or implying a contradiction to the #Main_assertion.  Some LUs specify the #Main_assertion, others the #Conceded_state_of_affairs, as referring to the preceding discourse (i.e. DNI), while yet others are conjunctions joining the two.

<ex>[Although|Target] [she had some trouble|Conceded_state_of_affairs] , [she was able to finish about two hours early|Main_assertion] .</ex>
<ex>[Nevertheless|Target] , [we did win|Main_assertion] . [DNI|Conceded_state_of_affairs] </ex>
<ex>[I wanted to come|Main_assertion] , [but|Target] [I did n't remember where the party was|Conceded_state_of_affairs] . </ex>

name: Conditional_occurrence
description:
A #Consequence is presented as occurring if the #Profiled_possibility occurs.  See Conditional_scenario for further information.

<ex>[If|Target] [you take too long|Profiled_possibility] , [the train will leave without you|Consequence] .</ex>

name: Conditional_scenario
description:
In this scene, two mutually exclusive possibilities are presented, the #Profiled_possibility and the #Opposite_possibility, each of which has a consequence associated with it, the #Consequence (associated with the Profiled_possibility) and the #Anti_consequence (associated with the #Opposite_possibility).  Usually, the #Consequence and #Anti_consequence are also mutually exclusive, but in some cases (especially with ""even if"") the same #Consequence results regardless of whether one considers the #Profiled_possibility or the #Opposite_possibility. Neither of the possibilities is asserted and neither can simply be merged with a factual understanding of the world. Both possibilities are presented as uncertain, and the #Profiled_possibility may be further characterized with a neutral stance towards it, or with a doubtful, negative stance, depending on the specific lexical unit introducing the conditional and what verb forms are used in the #Profiled_possibility.
<ex></ex>

<ex>[If|Target] [you read caerfully|Profiled_possibility], [you 'll see the letters are swapped|Consequence].</ex>
<ex>[Unless|Target] [you read carefully|Profiled_possibility] , [you wo n't understand what I said|Anti_consequence] .</ex>

The most common use of lexical units connected to the Conditional_scenario is for prediction; in this case the conditionals pair up possibilities with predicted consequences. Subtypes of this use include, but are not limited to:
<ex></ex>
(1) contingencies:
<ex>[If|Target] [it rains|Profiled_possibility], [the ceremony will be under the tent|Consequence].</ex>

(2) conditional promises (usually when making a deal):
<ex>[If|Target] [you will wait with reasonable patience|Profiled_possibility] , [I will explain|Consequence]</ex>

(3) threats (which are inherently conditional):
<ex>[If|Target] [any boy says anything to Weeks about it|Profiled_possibility], [I will cane him.|Consequence]</ex>

(4) hypotheticals, especially when a different choice was made in the past and one imagines it would lead to a different outcome:
<ex>[If|Target] [I had elected to stay there|Profiled_possibility], [I probably would not have become homeless five years later|Consequence].</ex>

(5) descriptions of general rules of the world:
<ex>[You only get shingles|Consequence] [if|Target] [you have had chickenpox|Profiled_possibility].</ex>

(6) descriptions of the characteristics of individual entities or persons that have an effect under certain circumstances:
<ex>[If|Target] [Joey says you're in|Profiled_possibility], [you're in|Consequence].</ex>

<ex></ex>
<m>Speech act conditionals:</m>
<ex></ex>
Lexical units of these frames can also be used in a pattern called a ""Speech Act conditional"".  In this case, the conditional presents a statement that is relevant to the conversation if the #Profiled_possibility holds.

<ex>[Just ask for Bob|Consequence] [if|Target] [you need anything|Profiled_possibility].</ex>

The relevance of the statement is a #Consequence of the #Profiled_possibility, but there is no distinct alternative intended, so this usage does not normally allow distancing verb forms (see Dancygier and Sweetser 2005: 114-115). As shown in the above example, we annotate the potentially relevant statement as #Consequence.  This is based on an analysis of the filler of the #Consequence as metonymically expressing a message similar to ""it is relevant to say the following: ..."".  Such cases should be tagged with the clause-level tag ""Speech act"".  Thus in the following example, it is relevant for the speaker to explain the situation by saying ""no, she's not my wife"" if the other person is wondering about that possibility:

<ex>[In case|Target] [you're wondering|Profiled_possibility], [no she's not my wife|Consequence].</ex>
<ex></ex>
<m>Metalinguistic conditionals:</m>
<ex></ex>
In addition, conditionals can be used to talk about the actual encoding of a message and usually encode a strong opinion about the appropriateness or inappropriateness of a description, often in contrast to someone else's contrary opinion. Such sentences should be tagged ""Metalinguistic"", as in the following:

<ex>[If|Target] [that's not success|Profiled_possibility], [I don't know what is|Consequence].</ex>
<ex></ex>
<m>Epistemic conditionals:</m>
<ex></ex>
Finally, conditionals can be used to profile a reasoning process.  While all conditionals mark the connection from a hypothetical situation to an associated conclusion, many conditionals specifically highlight this process of thinking about the connection, especially when the reasoning is cooccurring with speaking, and most obviously when reasoning from effects to causes. In such cases as the following, we mark the clause as ""Epistemic"":

<ex>[If|Target] [the lights are on|Profiled_possibility], [then somebody is home|Consequence].</ex>

Many sentences are vague about exactly to what degree they profile the reasoning process, so sentences like the following can be legitimately labeled ""Epistemic"" or not:

<ex>[If|Target] [you believe that what you are doing is right|Profiled_possibility] [then you can't compromise|Consequence].</ex>

<ex></ex>
<m>Special constructions:</m>
<ex></ex>
Conditionals interact significantly with ellipsis constructions, particularly because they often occur in parallel structures in which different possibilities are being contrasted, or cases in which there is a contrast between what is always true and what is only conditionally true.  In these cases, the #Profiled_possibility and the #Consequence or #Anti_consequence may be abbreviated under the same conditions that apply to ellipsis in the rest of the language.  See the following examples:

<ex>She would visit for at least a week and, [if|Target] [necessary|Profiled_possibility], [an additional day or two|Consequence].</ex>

In these examples, ""an additional day or two"" is understood as ""she would stay an additional day or two"", based on the immediately preceding sentence.  This is a general construction that allows a finite sentence that is parallel to an immediately adjacent clause to be abbreviated just to the content in addition to or contrasting with the adjacent clause. Since it must be interpreted as a full clause and occurs in exactly the places a clause is expected, we actually annotate the PT of the #Consequence as ""Sfin"" in these cases. The adjective ""necessary"" in the #Profiled_possibility, however, is not licensed by a general construction that allows an adjective like necessary to be used arbitrarily in the kinds of places a clause would be found. Therefore, in this case, we consider the adjective to represent a separate valence with PT ""AP"".

name: Condition_symptom_relation
description:
A #Patient has a #Medical_condition that can be understood by its #Symptoms. This frame has been constructed to list all the ways to speak of relating a #Patient, a #Medical_condition, and #Symptoms, including LUs that are also related to much more general frames like Causation (e.g. cause.v).

<ex> [Neurally mediated syncope|Medical_condition] is the[the most common|Frequency] [cause|Target] of [syncope|Symptom].</ex>

<ex>[Tietze Syndrome and Costochondritis Tietze syndrome|Medical_condition] [manifested|Target] [by painful swelling of one or more costochondral articulations|Symptom]</ex>

name: Conduct
description:
An #Agent acts in a certain #Manner either generally or under some particular #Circumstances. The conduct may also be directed specifically towards an #Affected_party.

<ex> [He|Agent] pledges to  [conduct|Target] himself  [with honesty and humility|Manner].</ex>
<ex> This year [they|Agent] have [behaved|Target] themselves [particularly impudently|Manner].</ex>
<ex> His appearance was as   immaculate as ever and [his|Agent] [bearing|Target]
[composed and dignified|Manner]. </ex>

name: Configuration_relation
description: Configuration_relation

name: Confirmation_of_attention
description: Confirmation_of_attention

name: Confronting_problem
description:
An #Agent becomes involved in an #Issue which has negative consequences for them. The #Agent will normally respond to resolve the #Issue.

<ex>[I|Agent] [confronted|Target] [both issues|Issue].</ex>

name: Connecting_architecture
description:
An entity is integrated into a building as a #Part of a (possibly unexpressed) #Whole which may refer to the whole building or merely to a sub-part of the building.  The #Part itself connects locations within the building to each other, #Connected_locations. If a particular point of view is adopted in the context of real or imagined motion, then one of the locations can be construed as #Goal and the other as #Source.

<ex>It was of great interest to me to see the star signs of Taurus the Bull and Leo the Lion on the [[staircase|Part]|Target] [to the upper Palace|Goal].</ex>

<ex>All visitors may use the [[elevator|Part]|Target] [between the Main Level and the Upper Level|cl] instead of the main staircase</ex>

<ex>The [[window|Part]|Target] [into the garden|Goal] was open.</ex>

name: Connectors
description:
The #Connector is an artifact created to affix a #Connected_item or to bind onto a #Fixed_location and is primarily so used.  A more specific #Use may also be specified.  Certain words in this frame (e.g. <ment>bond, chain</ment> in the phrase <ment>in chains</ment>) indicate specifically that the #Connector is being used to immobilize something.  #Connectors have a wide variety of physical forms:  long, thin, and flexible for tying (<ment>ropes, bonds, withies</ment>); solid, with a shape corresponding to holes in the entities to be connected (<ment>bolts, nails, pegs</ment>); and liquid (<ment>glues, adhesives, pastes</ment>).
<ex>A waterproof [[adhesive|Target]|Connector] should be used for this exterior job.</ex>
<ex><x>[His|Item] [[bonds|Connector]|Target]</x> had to be <gov>loosened</gov> before they could be cut.</ex>
<ex>She <gov>jerked</gov> <x>on [His|Connected_item] [neck|Loc] [[rope|Target]|Connector]</x> again, to keep his attention.</ex>
<ex>I think they <gov>cut</gov> <x>his [bike|Use] [[chain|Target]|Connector]</x> with bolt cutters.</ex>

name: Conquering
description:
This frame describes a #Theme losing its autonomy and perhaps sustaining material damage as the result of a successful invasion on the behalf of a #Conqueror.

<ex>[The Spaniards|Conqueror] [conquered|Target] [the Incas|Theme] [with both the Cross and the arquebus|Instrument]</ex>

<ex>He said that the aim had been the [takeover|Target] [of the Soviet government|Theme] [by ""advocates of swift privatization""|Conqueror]</ex>

<ex>[The Romans|Theme] [fell|Target] [to the Goths|Conqueror] [in 410 AD|Time].</ex>

<ex>[Bright Star campaign forces|Conqueror] [captured|Target] [the garrison town of Kajo Kaji|Theme]</ex>

name: Contacting
description:
A #Communicator (whose Location may be indicated) directs a #Communication to an #Addressee at a particular #Address.  Note that no actual successful communicative act is implied, only the successful completion of acts which would establish the communication.  (In other words, Mari can e-mail Jon without Jon ever reading it.) NB:  The #Address or #Location_of_protagonist may be a virtual address, such as an e-mail or telephone number.

<ex>[Disgruntled voters|Com] [phoned|Target] [Congressman Neil|Add] [at his Washington residence|Address] [with complaints about the recent increases in corporate welfare|Communication].</ex>
<ex>[She|Com] tried to [call|Target] [from the payphone down the street|Location_of_protagonist].</ex>

name: Contact_image_schema
description: A #Profiled_region occupies the space in contact with the #Ground.

name: Containers
description:
This frame covers entities which are prototypically conceived of and created to fulfill the function of containing--i.e. #Containers  that contain objects or substances, the #Contents.  This can be expressed as a complement , and includes potential or intended contents.   A #Container may also have an #Owner, a current #Relative_location, #Material from which it is constructed, a method of #Construction, and a #Type.  Note the connection between words in this frame and those in the Filling, Emptying, and Fullness frames.
<ex>a [[bag|Target]|Container] [of popcorn|Contents]</ex>
<ex>[underwear|Contents] [[drawer|Target]|Container]</ex>
<ex>[Chuck's|Owner] [[suitcase|Target]|Container]</ex>
<ex>[the [suitcase|Target]|Container] [in Chuck's office|Rel_loc]</ex>
<ex>[straw|Mat] [[basket|Target]|Container]</ex>
<ex>[woven|Cons] [[basket|Target]|Container]</ex>
<ex>[Erlenmeyer|Type] [[flask|Target]|Container]</ex>

name: Container_focused_placing
description:
An #Agent or #Cause affects a #Goal location by moving a #Theme, but without necessarily filling or covering it.

This frame is for Inheritance purposes.

name: Container_focused_removing
description:
An #Agent or #Cause partially or totally changes the state of a #Source object, towards having less of the #Theme.

This frame is primarily for Inheritance.

name: Containing
description:
In this frame a #Container holds within its physical boundaries the #Contents.
<ex>[The box|Container] [holds|Target] [three hundred pictures|Contents].</ex>

name: Containment_scenario
description: In this situation, a #Container has within it some #Contents.  The #Container has an #Interior, a space which is potentially empty, but instead is occupied with the #Contents.

name: Contingency
description:
The answer to one open question, the #Outcome, is dictated (partially or completely) by the answer to another open question, the #Determinant, i.e. if the answer to the #Determinant is known, the answer to the #Outcome can be predicted.  The #Degree of predictive power and the #Circumstances under which the dependency holds can also be expressed.

<ex>[Economic policy|Outcome] is [partially|Degree] a [function|Target] [of cultural values|Determinant].</ex>
<ex>Well, [[that|Target]|Outcome] [depends|Target] ... [DNI|Determinant]</ex>
<ex>[In Mediaeval times|Circumstances], [status|Outcome] was [dependent|Target] [on birth|Determinant].</ex>

name: Continued_state_of_affairs
description:
A #State_of_affairs has held and continues to hold up to the #Reference_occasion.

<ex>[[To date|Target]|ref], [the Department already has numerous requests for new systems to be developed|soa].</ex>

<ex>[SAGE has no activities planned|soa] [[as of yet|Target]|ref].</ex>

<ex>PBGC guarantees the benefit [that you had earned|soa] [up to|Target] [the date of plan termination|ref]</ex>

<ex>I think that [she 's|soa] [[still|ref]|Target] [in her office|soa] .</ex>

name: Contrary_circumstances
description:
An #Event takes place despite the existence of an #Adversity that would otherwise support #Contrary_circumstances or results.
<ex></ex>
<ex>[He finished the race|Event] [despite|Target] [his ankle breaking|Adversity].</ex>

name: Contrition
description:
An #Experiencer feels bad about a choice, an #Action, or a failure to do something, which they now consider to have been a mistake or wrong. The emotional state of the #Experiencer may be showing in gestures or facial expressions, viz. an #Expressor.

<ex>[Smithers|Experiencer] did not [repent|Target] [of his crime|Action].</ex>
<ex>It is God who rejoices at the [repentance|Target] [of his sinner|Experiencer].</ex>

name: Control
description:
A #Controlling_entity, #Controlling_situation, or #Controlling_variable control a #Dependent_entity, #Dependent_situation, or #Dependent_variable. The latter, dependent, element or some aspect of it is not just influenced, but determined by the controlling element.

<ex>Can [you|cone] [control|Target] [the robot|depe]?</ex>
<ex>Although [you|cone] may not be able to [control|Target] [every situation|deps], you can control your reaction.</ex>
<ex>[Students|cone] do not <m>have</m> [control|Target] [over the temperature of the heating water|depv].</ex>
<ex>Everyone knows that [the price of oil|conv] [controls|Target] [the price of asphalt|depv].</ex>

name: Controller_object
description:
This frame contains items which, when manipulated, alter the function of some device, internal or external.

<ex>This [[button|Target]|Control] [makes the radio turn on|Use].</ex>

name: Convey_importance
description:
Through a  #Message, a #Speaker (sometimes encoded metonymically by a #Medium) communicates the relative importance of the state of affairs denoted by the #Message.


<ex>[Reid|Speaker] [emphasized|Target] [that he and Dean meet every month|Message].</ex>
<ex>Above all , [Mr Tsongas|Speaker] [stressed|Target] [the need for his message to be heard|Message].</ex>
<ex> [Professor Perkin|Speaker] has [stressed|Target] [how favourable Britain 's situation was|Message] .</ex>
<ex>[The courts|Speaker] have [repeatedly|Iterations] [stressed|Target] [that the making of an order is discretionary|Message].</ex>
<ex>[""The whole Muslim society should respect these rights,""|Message] [he|Speaker] [stressed|Target].</ex>
<ex>[The panelists|Speaker] [stressed|Target] [to an audience of about 100 at North Dakota State University's Memorial Union|Addressee] [that people of different religions in this community need to talk - and find out they're not all that different|Message].</ex>

name: Convoy
description:
A #Convoy consists of several #Vehicles which move together to transport #Cargo from a Source to a Goal.

<ex>A [[convoy|con]|Target] [of several dozen vehicles|veh] was stopped at the border for several hours while border guards inspected their cargo.</ex>

<ex>Trained gunmen hijacked a [medical supply|car] [[convoy|con]|Target] headed for the city.</ex>

<ex>The [southbound|dir] [[convoy|con]|Target] [of two vans and several armored vehicles|veh] arrived safely 10 hours after it had departed.</ex>

name: Cooking_creation
description:
This frame describes food and meal preparation.  A #Cook creates a #Produced_food from (raw) #Ingredients.  The #Heating_instrument and/or the #Container may also be specified.

<ex>[Caitlin|Cook] [baked|Target] [some cookies|Food] [from the pre-packaged dough|Ingredients].</ex>

name: Corporal_punishment
description:
Blend of the Rewards_and_punishments and Cause_harm frames, in which the #Agent performs some action intended to cause bodily harm to the #Evaluee for some #Reason.  The #Reason is some action or state of the #Evaluee, and may even include difficult to detect states like beliefs.

<ex>[The Sheriff|Evaluee] [flogged|Target] [him|Agent] [for his crimes|Reason].</ex>

name: Correctness
description:
A particular piece of #Information is evaluated for its accuracy.  The #Degree of correctness may also be expressed.  The #Source of information may also metonymically stand in for the #Information.

<ex>Is your reputation at risk due to [incorrect|Target] [information|inf]?</ex>
<ex>If your dealership service people make such [totally|deg] [wrong|Target] [claims|inf], I would be uncomfortable trusting their warranty claims too.</ex>
<ex>All users must verify the [correctness|Target] [of their own information.|inf]</ex>
<ex>We found [all of his information|inf] to <m>be</m> [right|Target].</ex>

name: Corroding
description: In this frame the #Patient, an inorganic item, undergoes a chemical process which renders it less useful, desirable or stable. <ex></ex> <ex> [The bike|Patient] [rusted|Target].  </ex><ex>[The metal|Patient] [corroded|Target] [into a mass of slime|Result].</ex> <ex>[The bikes|Patient] [rusted|Target] [from their former beauty|I-state].</ex>

name: Corroding_caused
description: In this frame, the #Patient, an inorganic item, undergoes a chemical process caused by another entity, which renders it less useful, desirable or stable.  The process may or may not be under the control of an #Agent. <ex></ex> <ex>[The metal|Patient] was [corroded|Target] [by the water|Cause].  </ex><ex>[Acid rain|Cause] [corroded|Target] [the metal|Patient] [into a mass of slime|Result].</ex>

name: Corruption
description: Corruption

name: Cosmetics
description: Cosmetics

name: Cotheme
description:
This frame contains words that necessarily indicate the motion of two distinct objects. The #Theme is typically animate and is expressed the same way a Self-mover is expressed in the Self-motion frame--i.e. as the subject of a target verb. The #Cotheme may or may not be animate and is typically expressed as a direct object or an oblique. #Source, #Path, #Goal, and the other frame elements common to motion words also regularly occur with the words in this frame.
<ex></ex>
<ex>[She|Theme] [accompanied|Target] [him|Cotheme] [in the ambulance|Mode_of_transportation] [to Hollywood Memorial Hospital|Goal].</ex>

<ex>[Police|Theme] [persue|Target] [teenage joyrider|Cotheme] [across three counties|Path].</ex>

<ex>[My|Theme] [pursuit|Target] [of academic superiority|Cotheme] shows that I was still striving to be the person my parents wanted me to be.</ex>

name: Count
description: Count

name: Counterattack
description:
An #Assailant physically attacks a #Victim (which is usually but not always sentient), causing or intending to cause the #Victim physical damage. The attack is a response to an earlier attack by the #Victim on the current #Assailant (or by actors associated with the #Assailant or #Victim).

A #Weapon used by the #Assailant may also be mentioned, in addition to the usual #Place, #Time, #Purpose, #Explanation, etc.  Sometimes a location is used metonymically to stand for the #Assailant or the #Victim, and in such cases the #Place FE will be annotated on a second FE layer.

<ex>Are [we|Asl] [counterattacking|Target] [them|Victim] [just to keep them off balance|Purp]?</ex>

name: Court_examination
description:
A #Questioner asks a #Witness (or defendant) questions in the context of a court procedure.
<ex>[We|Questioner] 'd like to [cross-examine|Target] [the witness|Witness] if we can.</ex>

name: Craft
description:
A  particular #Activity, performed conventionally or habitually by more than one #Practitioner  within a #Culture, is described  in terms of its method.


<ex>One lived-in cabin also had a grassy roof, as if the [craft|Target] [of thatching|Act] had died out locally</ex>

name: Create_physical_artwork
description:
A #Creator creates an artifact that is typically an iconic #Representation of an actual or imagined entity or event. The #Representation may also be evocative of an idea while not based on resemblance.

<ex>[Diagrams|Representation] must be [clearly|Manner] [drawn|Target] [on construction paper|Location_of_representation]. [CNI|cre]</ex>

<ex>[I|cre] [took|Target] [his picture|Representation] and told him that if it came out well I would make him a copy.</ex>

<ex>[In about 1305 and 1306|Time] [Giotto|cre] [painted|Target] [a notable series of 38 frescoes|Representation].</ex>

name: Create_representation
description:
A #Creator  produces a physical object which is to serve as a #Representation of an actual or imagined entity or event, the #Represented.


<ex>[Epstein|cre] saw the machine-man and [carved|Target] [him|Represented] [in shiny metal|Material].</ex>

<ex>[Picasso|cre] [drew|Target] [some violent looking birds|Represented].</ex>

<ex>Towards the end of his life, [Munch|Creator] [painted|Target] [himself|Represented] [as a ghost|Depictive_of_represented].</ex>

<ex>Dan Grant was the model for Norman Rockwell when [the artist|Creator] [painted|Target] [him|Represented] [as ""The Barefoot Boy""|Role] for a Depression-era Coca Cola calendar.</ex>

<ex>[There|Place] [the Finnish artist|Creator] [sketched|Target] [him|Represented], [creating a stunning portrait|Depictive].</ex>

name: Creating
description:
A #Cause leads to the formation of a #Created_entity.

<ex>[Dr. Frankenstein|Creator] [created|Target] [a monster|Created_entity].</ex>

name: Crime
description: During her stay at a #Place, the #Tourist may be the victim of a #Crime.

name: Crime_scenario
description: A (putative) #Crime is committed and comes to the attention of the #Authorities.  In response, there is a Criminal_investigation and (often) Arrest and criminal court proceedings.  The Investigation, Arrest, and other parts of the Criminal_process are pursued in order to find a #Suspect (who then may enter the Criminal_process to become the Defendant) and determine if this #Suspect matches the #Perpetrator of the #Crime, and also to determine if the #Charges match the #Crime.  If the #Suspect is deemed to have committed the #Crime, then they are generally given some punishment commensurate with the #Charges.

name: Criminal_investigation
description:
This frame describes the process that involves the inquiry and determination by an authority, the #Investigator, of the circumstances surrounding an #Incident perpetrated by a #Suspect.

<ex>[The police|Investigator] are [investigating|Target] [the bank's reported loss of several thousand dollars from their downtown branch's top security vault|Inc]. [DNI|Sus] </ex>
<ex>[Authorities|Investigator] are [investigating|Target] [several murders|Inc]. [DNI|Sus]</ex>

name: Criminal_process
description:
A #Suspect is arrested by #Authorities on #Charges related to an #Offense, then is arraigned as a #Defendant.  If at any time the #Defendant pleads guilty, then the #Defendant is sentenced, otherwise the #Defendant first goes to trial. During trial, the #Defense and #Prosecution present arguments on behalf of and against the #Defendant, respectively. If the #Jury comes up with a guilty verdict at the end of the trial, the #Defendant is sentenced.  In the end, the #Defendant is either released or is given a Sentence by a #Judge at the sentencing.

<ex></ex>

The Core roles in this frame and its subframes include #Authorities, #Charges, #Court, #Defendant, #Defense, #Judge, #Jury, #Offense, #Prosecution, and #Suspect.
Non-Core roles include #Place, #Time, #Victim, and #Witness.

name: Crowd
description: Group of people, the #Fans, that support a sports team. The crowd watches the games in stadiums or elsewhere wearing uniforms and flags of their teams.

name: Crowd_reactions
description: This scene depicts how the #Crowd reacts to the match.

name: Cure
description:
This frame deals with a #Healer treating and curing an #Affliction (the injuries, disease, or pain) of the #Patient, sometimes also mentioning the use of a particular #Treatment or #Medication. This frame differs from Medical_intervention in that this frame deals only with cases in which the #Patient is cured of the #Affliction, not just treated for the #Affliction.
<ex></ex>
<ex>[Isis|Healer] then [cured|Target] [Re|Patient] [by reciting a spell|Treatment].</ex>

<ex>Another student became convinced that [God|Healer] was going to [heal|Target] [the clergyman|Patient] [of his cancer|Affliction].</ex>

name: Custom
description:
A #Behavior is classified as entrenched for a #Protagonist or a #Society. The #Behavior may be associated with a particular #Domain of experience and described with a #Descriptor. This indicates that the #Behavior is commonly performed by the #Protagonist or members of the #Society.

<ex>It is an [old|Descriptor]  [Jewish|Society] [custom|Target]. </ex>
<ex>He was unaware of the [Japanese|Society] [custom|Target] [of waiting until the giver had departed|Behavior]. </ex>
<ex> The [ancient|Descriptor] [tradition|Target] [of swan-upping|Behavior] has been taking place on the river Thames.</ex>
<ex>Smithers thought that [hunting lions|Behavior] was just another [native|Society] [custom|Target] </ex>
<ex>Marko showed great respect for the [social|Domain] [customs|Target] [of his people|Society].</ex>
<ex> When I reply to debates , it is [my|Protagonist] [custom|Target] [to have heard all the speeches that have been made|Behavior]. </ex>

name: Cutting
description:
An #Agent cuts a #Item into #Pieces using an #Instrument (which may or may not be expressed).

<ex>At the ceremony, [the CEO|Agent] [cut|Target] [the red ribbon hanging across the main entrance|Item] [into a glorious confetti|Pieces].</ex>

name: Cycle_of_existence_scenario
description: An Entity comes into being, exists for some time, and ceases to be.

name: Cycle_of_life_and_death
description: A #Protagonist is born or sprouts, lives, dies, and then is dead.

name: Damaging
description:
An #Agent affects a #Patient in such a way that the #Patient (or some #Subregion of the #Patient) ends up in a non-canonical state.  Often this non-canonical state is undesirable, and some lexical units (marked with the Negative semantic type) specifically indicate that the #Patient is negatively affected.  Some lexical units of this frame indicate by what means the #Patient is altered (e.g., scrape.v) and in some cases give some indication of the detailed effect on the #Patient (e.g., score.v, chip.v), and in other cases, both are specified (tear.v). For another set of lexical units, the action and its result are much less specified (e.g., damage.v).

Compare this frame with Destroying, Cause_to_fragment, and Render_nonfunctional.

<ex>[That idiot|Agent] just [dented|Target] [my car|Patient]!</ex>
<ex>[Some ne'er-do-wells|Agent] [defaced|Target] [the Park's wall|Patient] [with spray paint|Instrument] [to show their anger at local natural resources allocation policy|Purpose].</ex>
<ex>Please don't [damage|Target] [the goods|Patient].</ex>

name: Daring
description:
An #Agent performs some #Action which is considered imprudent.  This frame is distinct from Attempt in that the danger that the #Agent puts themselves in by performing the #Action is profiled.  The danger is not spelled out, but generally the #Action has a possibility or likelihood of causing social or physical harm to the #Agent.

<ex>[I|Agent] [risked|Target] [taking another look|Action].</ex>

name: Dead_or_alive
description:
A #Protagonist is in the dynamic, maintained state of being alive or has exited this state.

<ex>[Frank's|Protagonist] [dead|Target] [body|Figure] was apalling.</ex>

name: Death
description:
The words in this frame describe the death of a #Protagonist.  A #Cause of death may also be expressed obliquely.
<ex></ex>
<ex>The machine was not switched off, but [Mr. Lavelle|Protagonist] [died|Target] [of natural causes|Explanation], police said.</ex>

<ex>To avenge the [death|Target] [of a son|Protagonist] is not hasty work, if he is to be honored.</ex>

name: Deception_end
description: A #Deceiver succeeds or fails in causing a #Victim to have a misunderstanding about a #Topic.

name: Deception_scenario
description: Deception is a scenario in which a #Deceiver attempts to make it such that a #Victim comes to an incorrect understanding about a #Topic. This may be done by presenting a misleading #Phenomenon to the #Victim, or by concealing the existence of items which the #Victim may be interested in. Note that the #Victim is not necessarily aware of the (possible) existence of the #Topicor items related to it.

name: Deception_success
description: A Deceiver successfully causes a Victim to end up with incorrect beliefs about a Topic. The Victim comes to these beliefs from perceiving a Deception.

name: Deciding
description:
A #Cognizer makes a #Decision, which may be about an entity or a course of action.

How (and whether) this frame is distinct from Choosing is currently up for debate.

<ex>[Mo|Cognizer] [decided|Target] [to quit the program|Decision].</ex>

name: Defending
description:
A #Defender responds to an #Assailant's attack on a #Victim by directly, and usually violently, countering it.

<ex>[Samantha|def] [stalwartly|man] [defended|Target] [the gateway|vic] [from the wraiths|assail], [crouching low over Stephen's prone form|dep].</ex>

name: Degree
description:
LUs in this frame modify a gradable attribute and describe intensities at the extreme positions on a scale.

<ex>She is [very|Target] [brave|Gradable_attribute].</ex>

<ex>It is [that|Target] [simple|Gradable_attribute]!</ex>

<ex>The feuds are [so|Target] [vicious|Gradable_attribute] because the stakes are so low.</ex>

<ex>The plant is [totally|Target] [red|Gradable_attribute]  without the slightest hint of green.</ex>

name: Degree_of_processing
description:
A #Material has been processed (generally industrially) to some #Degree in order to make it more useful for some (usually implicit) function.  In some cases, an #Alterant is used to process the #Material.

<ex></ex>

name: Delegation
description: Committe that represents a #Country in a sports event. It is composed of the athletes and coaching staff.

name: Delimitation_of_diversity
description:
An #Item which encompasses characteristics or types whose diversity is indicated by adducing a #Limit1 and a #Limit2 which differ considerably from each other.  In some cases, the #Limit2 and #Limit1 are construed together as #Limits.  Alternatively, the values of a particular #Variable for the #Item and its #Limits may be profiled.

<ex>[Prices|Item] [range|Target] [from 10 to 20 dollars|Limits].</ex>
<ex>Prices range from 10 to 20 [dollars|Variable].</ex>

name: Delimited_state_scenario
description: A #State (often an ongoing process) is ongoing for some period of time.

name: Delivery
description:
A #Deliverer hands off a #Theme to a #Recipient or (more indirectly) a #Goal location, which is accessible to the #Recipient.


<ex>[The staff of Ebags|del] [delivered|Target] [the umbrella|Theme] [well ahead of schedule|Time].</ex>

<ex>In each class [a dove|del] flew in and [delivered|Target] [a red rose|Theme] [to Ginny|rec].</ex>

<ex>The Pontifical Delegation for the [delivery|Target] [of the Icon of the Kazan Mother of God|Theme] will arrive tomorrow. </ex>

name: Deny_or_grant_permission
description:
In this frame, an #Authority allows a #Protagonist to know (in some way) that they may or may not engage in an #Action. For lexical units of this frame marked with the semantic type ""Negative"", e.g., authorize.v, the #Authority has the power to tell the #Protagonist not to do something, but does not do so. It is assumed that if the #Protagonist engages in the #Action without permission, then the #Authority will punish the #Protagonist in some way, at least with disapproval; if the #Authority grants permission, however, the #Authority is agreeing not to impose a punishment on the #Protagonist for performing the #Action.


<ex>[The police officer|Authority] [forbid|Target] [me|Protagonist] [from turning around|Action] .</ex>
<ex> [My mother|Authority] [okayed|Target] [me|Protagonist] [to go to the movies with Simon|Action] . </ex>

<ex> [The teacher|Authority] <m>gave</m> [the children|Protagonist] [permission|Target] [to eat their lunch outside|Action]. </ex>

<ex>[The Church|Authority] had [sanctioned|Target] [for recital after Mass|Circumstances] [a special prayer to St. Michael|Action].</ex>

name: Departing
description:
An object (the #Theme) moves away from a #Source. The #Source may be expressed or it may be understood from context, but its existence is always implied by the departing word itself.

<ex>[The plane|Theme] [leaves|Target] [at seven|Time].[DNI|Source].</ex>

<ex>[His|Theme] [departure|Target] [from the dock|Source] was delayed by hundreds of tearful farewells.</ex>

<ex>[We all|Theme] [exited|Target] [the room|Source] [slowly|Speed].</ex>

name: Deserving
description:
The existence of a #State_of_affairs is sufficient reason for taking an #Action . The agent who is justified in taking the suggested #Action is not part of the immediate scene, however.

<ex>[The underwater sequences|State_of_affairs] [warrant|Target] [the price of the admission alone|Action].</ex>

<ex> '[Desperate situations|State_of_affairs] [call|Target]  [for desperate measures|Action] ,"" said Mr Eames grandly.</ex>

name: Desirability
description:
This frame concerns an #Evaluee being judged for its quality, i.e. how much it would probably be liked.  In many cases, the #Evaluee is implicitly judged good or bad relative to other instances of its type. The #Evaluee's desirability is determined by one or more #Parameters, which are scalar properties of the #Evaluee. The evaluation may also explicitly be relativized to a set of #Circumstances, a #Comparison_set of entities that belong to the same class as the #Evaluee, or an #Affected_party. The #Degree of goodness or badness may also be expressed.

Note: With some targets, desirability is conventionally aligned with quantity, i.e., GOOD is MORE.

<ex>[The view|Evaluee] was  [astonishing|Target].</ex>
<ex>[On clear days|Circumstances], [the view|Evaluee] was [excellent|Target].</ex>
<ex>The book is [astounding|Target] [in its scope|Parameter].</ex>
<ex>The games have been [awful|Target] [for the team|Affected_party].</ex>

name: Desirable_event
description:
A particular #State_of_affairs is desirable.  The #State_of_affairs may be required to achieve a #Purpose.  A set of #Circumstances may be specified under which the assessment of desirability holds.


<ex>[You|sta] [should|Target] [take the doses about 12 hours apart and at the same time each day|sta].</ex>
<ex> [If the metal is seriously rusted or warped|cir], [it|sta] [should|Target] [be repaired or replaced with a chimney top damper|sta].</ex>
<ex>[To ensure that|pur], [you|sta] [should|Target] [have no CLASSPATH set|sta].</ex>

name: Desiring
description:
An #Experiencer desires that an #Event occur.  (Note that commonly a resultant state of the #Event will stand in for the #Event.)  In some cases, the #Experiencer is an active participant in the #Event, and in such cases the #Event itself is often not mentioned, but rather some #Focal_participant which is subordinately involved in the #Event. <ex></ex>Generally, the use of a word in this frame implies that the specific #Event has not yet happened, but that the #Experiencer believes that they would be happier if it did.  Sometimes the #Time_of_event, #Purpose_of_event, or the #Location_of_event are mentioned without the explicit mention of the #Event.
<ex>[I|Experiencer] only [wanted|Target] [one piece of candy|Foc].</ex>
<ex>[The company|Exp] <m>was</m> [eager|Target] [for him|Foc] [to leave as soon as possible|Event].</ex>
<ex>[Susan|Exp] [really|Degr] [wishes|Target] [that you 'd listen to her|Event].</ex>

name: Destiny
description:
An #State_of_affairs will come to hold with respect to a #Protagonist at some future time. The #Protagonist is not conceived of as having control over whether the #State_of_affairs will hold: obscurely related previous actions or circumstances, or some hidden power may have already determined that it will occur.

<ex>[Exile|soa] <m>was</m> [his|pro] [fate|Target] and he triumphantly turned it into the fruit of his life.</ex>

<ex>One could say that it <m>was</m> [Indonesia's|pro] [destiny|Target] [to initiate the decolonization process|soa].</ex>

<ex>[The sun's|pro] ultimate [fate|Target] <m>is</m> [as a white dwarf, a dense, cold core the size of the earth|rol].</ex>

<ex>At the time it did not appear that [greatness|soa] <m>was</m> <m>in</m> [her|Protagonist] [stars|Target].</ex>

<ex>Nine for [mortal men|Protagonist] , [doomed|Target] [to die|State_of_affairs] .</ex>

<ex>This seemingly [predestined|Target] [meeting between a creator and the model he has pursued all his life|State_of_affairs] suggests a kind of miracle . </ex>

name: Destroying
description: A #Destroyer (a conscious entity) or #Cause (an event, or an entity involved in such an event) affects the #Patient negatively so that the #Patient no longer exists.  <ex>[An asteroid|Cause] [obliterated|Target] [the dinosaurs|Patient].</ex>

name: Detaching
description:
The Detaching frame covers two situations: a scene in which somebody causes one thing to be physically detached from something else; or a scene in which somebody causes two things to be disconnected from each other. In the first, the frame includes an #Agent who detaches an #Item from a #Source, creating an asymmetric relationship between the #Item and the #Source. In the second, the #Agent attaches two #Items to each other, where each serves as a #Source relative to the other, creating a symmetric relationship between the two #Items. Note in both cases, after the removal of the connector, the #Items that were formerly attached re-appear as the two separate or potentially separate entities that they were throughout.

<ex>[They|Agent] finally [unchained|Target] [me|Item] [from my desk at work|Source] and I'm leavin town.</ex>
<ex>[Before adding a new area of color|Time], [he|Agent] [detached|Target] [the canvas|Item] [from the stretcher|Source] and laboriously scraped away the old paint in that spot.</ex>
<ex>[She|age] [unhooked|Target] [the leash|ite] [from Patty's collar|sou], and pulled her up on the couch.</ex>

name: Detaining
description: The #Authorities hold a #Suspect under suspicion of having committed a crime (#Charges). The #Holding_location and period of detention (#Duration) may also be specified. <ex>[The police|Authorities] [held|Target] [Mr. Smith|Suspect] [in the slammer|Holding_location] [on charges of killing his lawyer|Charges].</ex>

name: Detonate_explosive
description:
An #Agent causes an #Explosive device to explode.

<ex>[Who|Agent] [detonated|Target] [that bomb|exp]?</ex>

name: Differentiation
description:
Words in this frame have to do with a #Cognizer being aware (or not being aware) of the difference between two #Phenomena, which may be expressed jointly or disjointly.

<ex>It is very difficult for [people|Cognizer] to [visually|Means] [distinguish|Target] [between living and non-living things|Phenomena] [from such a great distance|Circumstances] .</ex>

name: Difficulty
description:
An #Experiencer has an easy or difficult time carrying out an #Activity. The ease or difficulty associated with the #Activity seems to often be associated with a prominent participant. However, we consider this impression to be due to the syntax and pragmatics of the relevant sentence constructions and employ no special FE for such participants. The #Degree of ease or difficulty is often specified as well as a set of #Circumstances. A #Parameter may be mentioned that indicates in which respect the #Activity is judged to be easy or difficult.
<ex></ex>
Unmarked LUs of this frame indicate that something is easy, while LUs of this frame that mean the opposite of easy are marked with the semantic type ""Negative"", as in difficult.a, arduous.a, and a bitch.n.

<ex>(1) [John|Activity] <m>is</m> [easy|Target] [to please|Activity].</ex>
<ex>(2) It <m>is</m> [easy|Target] [to get Alex annoyed|Activity].</ex>
<ex>(3) [Smithers|Activity] is [very|Degree] [tough|Target] [for me|Experiencer] [to please|Activity].</ex>
<ex>(4) [VWs|Activity] are [easy|Target] [to repair|Activity].</ex>
<ex>(5) [The dating of western sculpture|Activity] is [difficult|Target].</ex>
<ex>(6) [In that kind of wind|Circumstances] [the course|Activity] is [physically|Parameter] [very|Degree] [tricky|Target].</ex>
<ex>(7) [The last question on the exam|Activity] <m>was</m> [hard|Target]. </ex>
<ex>(8) The last one was a [hard|Target] [question|Activity] [to answer|Activity]. </ex>

name: Dimension
description:
This frame concerns  words that express an #Object's position on a scale, its #Measurement, with respect to some attribute, its #Dimension.  #Locus,  identifying the sub-region of the #Object where the #Dimension is measured, may also be expressed.

<ex>[The tower|Object] is [10 feet|Measurement] [tall|Target].</ex>

<ex>[The  new vase|Object] is [5 cm|Measurement] in [circumference|Target] [at the top|Locus].</ex>

Adjectives in this frame <ment>must</ment> appear with a measurement expression like <ment>5 cm</ment>.

Note the tagging of  <ment>six feet</ment> on the GF and PT layers in the following sentence.

<ex>[The woman|Object] was [six feet|Measurement] [tall|Target].</ex>

The GF of <ment>six feet</ment> is Dep and the PT is NP.

name: Dining
description: It describes buildings and food services offered to the #Tourist.

name: Direction
description:
This frame covers the basic uses of direction words like the adverbs east, up, and forward.  These are used either to talk about a direction of facing (e.g., facing outward, pointing left, looking downward, turn east) or to talk about actual or metaphorical motion (went up, traveling due north).  Lexical units of this frame typically have a semantic type that refers to the means of determining the direction (e.g. forward.adv has the semantic type Landmark_front, meaning that ""forward"" is defined with respect to the direction from the center of some entity to its front, however defined).  Nevertheless, some words like way.n and direction.n are used exactly when normal means of specifying direction are not available, and obligatorily occur with some other means of specifying the direction (""that way"", ""the same way"", ""the direction she went"").

This frame is most frequently used to describe the motion of something along the #Path from the #Landmark, which is normally implicitly identified as the location of the viewpoint:

<ex>We went [[north|Path]|Target] . [DNI|Landmark]</ex>

In such cases, a #Distance from the #Landmark can also be given:

<ex>After she was knocked on the head , it seemed like everything had moved [three feet|Distance] <m>to</m> the [left|Target] . [DNI|Landmark]</ex>

It can often be used for direction of facing, which is not compatible with the #Distance frame element:

<ex>Look [[left|Path]|Target] and you 'll see it . [DNI|Landmark] </ex>

Although rare for certain lexical units (e.g., upward.adv), most words in this frame are commonly used in a fictive motion pattern to identify locations that can be reached by moving in the indicated way from the #Landmark:

<ex>The book was unreachable, [10 feet|Distance] [[up|Path]|Target] on the shelf. [DNI|Landmark]</ex>
<ex>[[East|Target]|Path] [of Mt. Diablo|Landmark] the Sierras rise majestically above the Central Valley.</ex>
<ex></ex>

In this fictive motion case, the #Domain and the #Independent_variable are both spatial, and should be marked as metaphorical.

Note this differs from members of the Directional_locative_relation frame (e.g., above.prep), which can only be used for relative static positions, and not for facings or for directions of motion:

<ex>??? The book faced [above|Target] the door .</ex>
vs.
<ex>The book faced [upward|Target] .</ex>

A potential point of confusion is that the Directional_locative_relation frame is also used for cases in which adverbs like east.adv, etc. are followed by ""of"", since such expressions can only be used of static relative positions and not facings:

<ex>??? I faced [east|Target] of the mountains .</ex>

Another potential point of confusion is that nouns referring to directions can be used for facings if they are preceeded by the word ""to"".  Since this use of to.prep can be found with a broader class of words like side.n, we interpret this sense of to.prep as mapping relative postitions (belonging to the Directional_locative_relation frame) to true Directions, in the sense of this frame.  This applies to expressions like ""to the east"", as well as ""to both sides"" and ""to the rear"".  In the future, we may add these as multi-word members of the frame.

In the following case, the #Domain is ""potency"" and the #Independent_variable is, as usual, time; again, the example should be marked as metaphorical.

<ex></ex>
<ex>They decided to rerate the medication [downward|Target] [in potency|Domain] .</ex>
<ex></ex>

In mathematical terms, all of these uses can be understood as a #Path, made up of a set of positions in some N-space #Domain (by default spatial, or metaphorically, other domains), being determined as a function of a #Landmark (which may be incorporated and is usually implicit) and some one-dimensional #Independent_variable (time, or, metaphorically, other domains).  The #Domain and/or the #Independent_variable are normally incorporated in the basic definition of the target; thus, for example, up.adv, by default, indicates the #Domain is space, and time is the #Independent_variable. From a linguistic point of view, we consider these literal spatio-temporal uses to be basic, and other cases, where space is replaced by some other kind of quantity, is to be understood as metaphorical.

name: Directional_locative_relation
description:
A #Figure is located relative to a (presumably more easily located) #Ground, asserting that the #Figure lies (approximately) on line from the #Ground whose direction is established by semantic types of the particular LUs.

<ex>[The plane landed|Figure] [10 miles|Distance] [due|Directness] [north|Target] [of Lake Travis|Ground] in an empty field .</ex>

name: Direct_fouls
description: An #Infractor acts carelessly, reckelessly or using excessive force against his #Opponent. In football, such fouls usually lead to a direct free kick.

name: Disability
description: A #Condition of a physical, sensory, mental and/or intellectual nature that, in interaction with various barriers, can obstruct an #Individual's full and effective participation in society on equal terms with other people.

name: Disaster_scenario
description: This frame covers the large scenario for characterizing disasters, including the occurrence of particular types of disasters and the range of responses to disasters.

name: Discursive_deixis
description: Discursive_deixis

name: Discussion
description:
Two (or more) people (the #Interlocutors, also encodable as #Interlocutor_1 and #Interlocutor_2) talk to one another. No person is construed as only a speaker or only an addressee. Rather, it is understood that both (or all) participants do some speaking and some listening--the process is understood to be symmetrical or reciprocal.  This frame differs from the Chatting frame in that the #Interlocutors have a particular question that they are attempting to decide or understand.

<ex>[I|Interlocutor_1] would rather [discuss|Target] [politics|Topic] [with anyone but him|Interlocutor_2].</ex>

<ex>[World leaders|Interlocutors] met to [discuss|Target] [global warming|Topic] [on the coldest day of the year.|Time]</ex>

name: Disease
description: During her stay at a #Place, the #Tourist may get sick.

name: Disembarking
description:
A #Traveller leaves from or dismounts a #Vehicle.

<ex>[The passengers|tra] [disembarked|Target] [in Southampton|pla].</ex>

<ex>They then informed the passengers that, if the aircraft were to leave the runway, [they|tra] would likely be [deplaning|Target] [through the rear cabin doors|Path].</ex>

name: Disgraceful_situation
description:
An implicit cognizer judges that a particular #State_of_affairs for which a #Protagonist is responsible is socially unacceptable.

<ex>He called it a [disgraceful|Target] [situation|soa]. [INI|Protagonist]</ex>

<ex>To my mind it was undoubtedly the [most utterly|deg] [shameful|Target] [act the chess world had witnessed since 1485|soa]. [INI|Protagonist]</ex>

<ex>It is not at all [shameful|Target] [for a man|pro] [to allow himself to be ruled by others|soa].</ex>

<ex> We are grateful to Mr. Mattick for bringing this [disgraceful|Target] [building|soa] and its vile nuisance to the attention of the Henley District . [INI|Protagonist]</ex>

<ex>[That comparison|soa] <m>is</m> [shameful|Target] [because it is comparing apples and oranges|exp]. [INI|Protagonist]</ex>

name: Dispersal
description:
An #Agent or a #Cause disperses or scatters #Individuals from the #Source,a relatively confined space, to a the #Goal_area, a broader space.

<ex>[She|Agent] [scattered|Target] [his ashes|Individuals] [in the bay|Goal_area].</ex>

name: Distance_scenario
description: This frame abstracts over various viewpoints on the specification or description of #Distance.  #Distance may either be precisely specified as a #Count of some standard #Unit (as in <ment>meters</ment> or <ment>inches</ment>), or may be described by the #Degree that it differs from expectation (as in <ment>near</ment> or <ment>far</ment>).

name: Distant_operated_IED
description:
A improvised explosive device, the #Bomb, is rigged to detonate when it receives a signal, typically by a wire that leads to a trigger. The trigger may be operated directly by the #Detonator, in which case the weapon is known as a CWIED (command wire IED). Or, the triggering mechanism may be activated wirelessly, such as by a cell phone. In this case, the weapon is called an RCIED (remote control IED).

<ex>These photographs were taken in the wake of a [[CWIED|Bomb]|Target] attack on the British.</ex>

<ex>The purpose of this device is to prevent an [[RCIED|Bomb]|Target] from detonating.</ex>

name: Distinctiveness
description:
A #Feature of an #Entity serves to distinguish the #Entity from other members of its type which have a different value for the #Feature.  Note that the #Entity is often implicit.

<ex>His [distinctive|Target] flowing [gait|Feature] and skill with the rapier set him apart from his fellows.</ex>
<ex>[The swinging axe-kick|Feature] was [characteristic|Target] [of Xena|Entity].</ex>

name: Distributed_abundanced
description: There is a #Location and an abundant or large #Theme.  The #Location and #Theme are largely coextensive, i.e. occupying the same area.

name: Distributed_position
description:
This frame involves a static (primarily spatial) relationship between a #Location and a #Theme, in which the #Theme is located in many or all subregions of the #Location, and is thus construable as covering it. The #Time when the covering configuration holds, and the #Subregion of the #Location that is involved may, optionally, be indicated.

<ex>[By Summer|Time], [weeds|Theme] [dotted|Target] [the field|Location] .</ex>
<ex>[The papers|Theme] [around|Target] [my office|Location] were too messy .</ex>
Prepositional and verb targets of this frame differ in the ways they can participate in forming sentences; one of the most important differences is that prepositions may modify the entire sentence to describe the event (the #Theme) as distributed over the #Location.
<ex>[Puddles were rippling|Theme] [all over|Target] [the roof|Location] .</ex>

Some members of this frame specifically indicate that the configuration is attractive or unattractive; this is indicated by the semantic types Positive_judgement and Negative_judgement respectively.  Some of the non-verb LUs of the frame (esp. around.prep) refer to multiple possible positions that might be occupied by a single #Theme, often accompanied by ""somewhere"":

<ex>I hope [my wallet|Theme] <m>is</m> [around|Target] [here|Location] ([somewhere|Region_quantification]) .</ex>

These same LUs may refer a vague sequence of locations occupied by a single #Theme:

<ex>[I|Theme] kept <m>walking</m> [around|Target] [my apartment|Location] .</ex>

All or virtually all of the verbs used statically in this frame can also occur in the frame Filling, producing pairs such as the following:

<ex>Filling: Pat [covered|Target] the table with flowers.</ex>
<ex>Distributed_position: [Flowers|Theme] [covered|Target] [the table|Location].</ex>
<ex></ex>
Please note: <ment>adorned</ment>, <ment>covered</ment>, etc are in the Abounding_with frame because of the point of view shift.
<ex></ex>
<ex>[The tree|Location] was [studded|Target] [all over|Subregion] [with soft dark fruit|Theme].</ex>

name: Diversity
description:
A #Group is described as having members which are similar or dissimilar to each other.  The #Degree of similarity may also be expressed.  Some of the nouns in this frame are transparent (e.g. <ment>range.n</ment>) whereas others denote the scale of diversity (<ment>diversity</ment>); <ment>variety.n</ment> is usable both ways but is normally transparent.

<ex>The [diversity|Target] [of students here|Group] is to be applauded . [INI|Dimension]</ex>
<ex>A [[range|Group]|Target] [of answers|Group] were proposed .</ex>

name: Documents
description:
Words in the frame refer to any #Document that has a legal status or conventional social significance.  Some #Documents empower the #Bearer of the #Document to execute the #Right.  Others indicate the #Obligation of the #Bearer.  Still others show the identity or #Status of the #Bearer.

<ex>They got [their|Bearer] [marriage|Status] [[licence|Target]|Document] [from Canada|Issuer].</ex>

name: Dodging
description:
A #Dodger acts to avoid an oncoming moving #Bad_entity.
<ex>[Mo|Dodger] [dodged|Target] [ the flower pot that Larry threw in disgust|Bad_entity].</ex>

The motion is relative, since the #Dodger may be moving.
<ex>Jogging through the dense woods, [Mo|Dodger] [dodged|Target] [the low branches|Bad_entity] .</ex>

name: Domain
description:
A #Predicate  is said to apply in a particular #Domain. The understanding of the relation between #Domain and #Predicate  depends on the nature of the #Predicate. When the #Predicate is a complete proposition, then a #Domain adverbial also functions as a topic restrictor. Sentences with topic restrictors often come in pairs.  When the #Predicate is a simple predicate, there is no notion of topic restriction on the sentence level.


<ex>The Normal College is [[geographically|Target]|Domain] [adjacent to the University of North Wales|Predicate].</ex>
<ex>[[Geographically|Target]|Domain], [Britain is a group of island off the mainland of Europe|Predicate].  [[Culturally|Target]|Domain] , [it has always been linked to the continent|Predicate] .</ex>
<ex>[[Socially|Target]|Domain] and demographically [the period has been dominated by two factors -- the fall in the size of families and the increase in the expectation of survival to retirement , the effects of which are still far from having exhausted themselves |Predicate].</ex>

name: Dominate_competitor
description:
An #Agent, by virtue of strength or forcefulness, controls, rules, or strongly influences some #Patient in some #Situation.

<ex>[The fireballing righthander|age] looked poised to [dominate|Target] [the Yankees|Patient] yet again, striking out seven straight batters during one stretch</ex>

name: Dominate_situation
description:
