An #Emitter emits a #Beam of light from a #Source, along a #Path, and/or towards a #Goal.  Essentially, this frame denotes the (semi-)fictive motion of the the #Beam.
<ex>Avoid allowing [light|Beam] to [shine|Target] [into neighbors' gardens|Goal].</ex>
<ex>[Clear yellow sunlight|Beam] [shone|Target] [through the window-panes|Path].</ex>
<ex>She thinks [the sun|Emit] [shines|Target] [out of his backside|Src].</ex>
<ex>...when [the candles|Emit] [shine|Target] [out|Src].</ex>
<ex>[It|Beam] [shines|Target] [in my eyes|Goal]. ('It' is both Beam and Emitter, though only one will show up in the display.) </ex>
<ex>...[light|Beam] [shines|Target] [down|Path] [on the world|Goal].</ex>
<ex>[The moonlight|Beam] [shone|Target] [off the fields|Path].</ex>
<ex>[The candlelight|Beam] [glinted|Target] [from pearls and rubies|Src].</ex>

name: Likelihood
description:
This frame is concerned with the likelihood of a #Hypothetical_event occurring. The #Hypothetical_event is its only core frame element.

<ex>It <m>is</m> [likely|Target] [that he'll arrive late|Hypothetical_event].</ex>

Notice that in the case where a noun phrase is the subject of the Support Verb, that NP is also tagged as #Hypothetical_event.

<ex>[He|Hypothetical_event] <m>is</m> [likely|Target] [to arrive late|Hypothetical_event].</ex>

name: Limitation
description:
An #Entity that would be expected to have a characteristic to a certain degree (typically based on comparison to other entities of the same type) instead has a more limited degree of that characteristic.

<ex>The [limitations|Target] on the theory's applicability made it unpopular in its time.</ex>

<ex>Are there any undocumented [limitations|Target] on the use of this machine?</ex>

name: Limiting
description:
An #Agent or #Cause limits a #Range_of_options to having a certain #Characteristic. The #Characteristic may be that only certain types of the #Range_of_options may be acceptable, or (in the case of a plural or mass #Range_of_options) that only certain cardinalities or quanties are acceptable. Alternatively, the #Degree to which the #Range_of_options is limited may be mentioned.

<ex>[His choices in life|cau] have [limited|Target] [his opportunities|ran] [severely|deg].</ex>

<ex>[Treatment|ran] was [limited|Target] [to one pill per day|cha]. [CNI|age]</ex>

name: Languages
description: Languages

name: Linguistic_meaning
description:
A linguistic #Form has a particular #Meaning, possibly restricted to a particular #Textual_location.
Some linguistic #Forms, nouns and nominal expressions, also can refer to an object in the real or an imagined world, a #Referent.

<ex>[""Unicorn""|Form] [denotes|Target] [a mythological horse with a horn on its head|Referent].</ex>

<ex>[In art|Textual_location], [the word ""oeuvre""|Form] [means|Target] [""the collected works of an artist.""|Meaning]</ex>

name: Literary_musical_cinematic_genre
description: Literary_musical_and_cinematic_genre

name: Lively_place
description:
A #Location is characterized by a high amount of (often goal-oriented) #Activity, or metonymically, with #Individuals who are engaged in the activity.

<ex>[The park|Location] was [abuzz|Target] [with people|Individuals].</ex>

name: Living_conditions
description:
An #Experiencer must cope with some #Condition for a prolonged period, usually against his or her will.

<ex>[Americans|Experiencer] [live|Target] [in fear|Condition].</ex>

name: Locale
description:
This frame contains general locale word.  Words in this frame designate relatively stable bounded ares of the world which have permanent #Relative_locations with respect to other locales, and thus are useful as permanent landmarks.

<ex>This is a [pleasant|Descriptor] [[area|Target]|Locale].</ex>

This frame is used only for those general location words that do not have a more specific frame.  It is inherited by Locale_by_use, which has to do with places that are named according to their intended use, or some habitual use, such as factory.n, dance floor.n, village.n, field.n.  It is also inherited by Locale_by_event, which covers places that are names according to some event which took place there, such as concerts, battles, and meteor impacts.

name: Locale_by_characteristic_entity
description:
A #Locale is characterized by the type of entity associated with the #Locale. Some words specifically denote regions characterized by the individuals who typically live or work there. Typcial such #Characteristics include ethnicity, national origin, language, and other shared cultural traits.

<ex>This neighborhood started out as a [Russian|cha] [[enclave|loc]|Target].</ex>

<ex>A twenty-minute walk will take you to the [Dutch-speaking|cha] [[quarter|loc]|Target] [of the city|Container_possessor].</ex>

name: Locale_by_collocation
description:
A #Profiled_region is identified as being the region where an #Entity is located.

<ex>State [your|Entity] [[location|Profiled_region]|Target].</ex>

<ex>I can't get a lock on [their|Entity] [[position|Profiled_region]|Target].</ex>

name: Locale_by_event
description:
A place defined in terms of an event which occurred (or will occur) there.
<ex>[Woodstock, NY|Locale] <m>was</m> the [site|Target] [of the most important rock concert of 1969|DefEvnt].</ex>
<ex>[Our|DefEvnt] [meeting|DefEvnt] [site|Target] was chosen for its solitude.</ex>

In the second example, the event FE is labeled with two labels, because the two words do not form a syntactic constituent; the first would be GF Genitive PT Possessive, and the second, GF Dependent and PT NP.

name: Locale_by_ownership
description:
A place defined by an #Owner.

<ex>Get off [my|Owner] [property|Locale]!</ex>

name: Locale_by_use
description:
Geography as defined by its use.

<ex>You must land in the next [[airfield|Locale]|Target], as this one is currently having difficulties.</ex>
<ex>The new [sports|Use] [[complex|Target]|Locale] was the tallest building on campus, oddly enough.</ex>
<ex>[[Cities|Locale]|Target] [of the Northeast|Container_possessor] tend to be dingier.</ex>

name: Locale_closure
description:
A building or location that can be sealed to prevent entrance, the #Locale, ceases to be open for use.

<ex>[That park|loc] [closed|Target] last year.</ex>

name: Locating
description:
A #Perceiver determines the #Location of a #Sought_entity within a #Ground.

<ex>[Kim|Perceiver] [found|Target] [his hat|Sought_entity] [on the far side|Location].</ex>

name: Location_in_time
description:
The word(s) in this frame detail a particular moment in time.These often occur with demonstratives such as this and that.

<ex>[Late|Relative_time] that [[day|Target]|Focal_time], [1776|Whole], America declared sovereignty.</ex>

name: Location_of_light
description:
A perceptible #Figure shows up against a #Ground location due to #Light shining on/from it, its salience possibly dependent on a #Cause_of_shine.

<ex>[The grass|Fig] [glistened|Target] [with dew|Shine].</ex>
<ex>Still [glowing|Target] [from the forge|Shine]...</ex>
<ex>[The oily mud|Fig] [gleamed|Target] [wetly|Shine] [under his feet|Grnd].</ex>
<ex>[Something|Fig] was [shimmering|Target] [on the shore|Grnd].</ex>
<ex>[The quartz|Fig] [glowed|Target] [with a fitful, internal light|Lit].</ex>
<ex>[The walls|Fig] [glowed|Target] [in the sun|Grnd].</ex>
<ex></ex>


Note that in this last example, the PP 'in the sun' is both the #Ground on the primary FE layer and #Light on the secondary layer.


<ex></ex>
This frame is similar to the frame Light_movement; however, in Location_of_light, #Light is conceived as stationary, while in Light_movement, light is conceived as traveling linearly outward from a light source, via a path, to whatever objects are illuminated.
<ex></ex>

In both of these light-related frames, there is a very consistent metaphorical conception of emotions as shining in eyes or forth from eyes, including the associated pattern of eyes shining with an emotion.  The sense in such cases is that the eyes (or the muscles and features around the eyes) are in such a configuration as to saliently convey an emotion.  In this metaphor, emotion is conceived as a light-source, with the amount of emotion described as amount of light, temporal patterns of intensity of emotion are patterns of light intensity, properties of the #Figure which produce the emotion are described in terms of properties of light-producing objects--thus ""glinting"", associated literally with light on hard, smooth, cold objects like stones, is used to describe the eyes of someone expreriencing a ""hard cold"" emotion like hatred, while ""sparkling"", associated with beauty, is used to describe the eyes of someone experiencing a ""beautiful"" emotion like amusement or excitement.  In both frames, such sentences should be tagged with the metaphor tag to differentiate them from literal sentences like ""His eyes glistened with tears.""

<ex>[Her eyes|Figure] [glinted|Target] [with hatred|Cause_of_shine].</ex>
<ex>I saw a [light|Light] [in her eyes|Figure] at the mention of cookies.</ex>

name: Location_on_path
description: A #Figure (fictively or literally) occupies a position within a #Profiled_region related to a #Ground.

name: Locative_deixis
description: Locative_deixis

name: Locative_relation
description:
A #Figure is located relative to a #Ground location.

<ex>[The cat|Fig] <m>is</m> [on|Target] [the mat|Grnd].</ex>
<ex>[The kitchen, with its breakfast / snack bar,|Figure] [adjoins|Target] on one side while the dining area adjoins on the other side. [DNI|Ground]</ex>
<ex>[The president's plane landed|Fig] [in|Target] [Washington|Ground].</ex>

This frame is used for LUs that do not belong in daughter frames, either because they are too general to have any particular image schema associated with them (e.g., <ment>here.adv</ment>), or because we do not (yet) have a specific frame with the correct image schema (e.g., <ment>inland.a</ment>).

Prepositions, adverbs, and spatial adjectives that act as targets in this frame and its descendants cooccur with a number of constructions that may supply extra information and should be annotated as extrathematic frame elements.  The location of the #Figure may be further specified by its #Distance from the #Ground along a vector implied by the targets image schema, or the #Direction in which the #Figure lies from a reference location (generally, the deictic center).  In cases where both seem to cooccur, the #Distance actually modifies the #Direction, as seen in the following example:

<ex>[This pup|Figure] was lying abandoned, [350 feet down|Direction] [at|Target] [the bottom of an Arizona canyon|Ground].</ex>

There is no sense in which the #Distance is measured using the schema for at.prep ('350 feet at the bottom of the canyon' doesn't mean the right thing at all); rather the distance is measured using the schema for down.adv, and is thus considered a modifier of the #Direction FE.

In some very specific situations, prepositions, adjectives, and nouns can be used with a copula to describe the whole #Profiled_region where a #Figure is or could be, as in the following:

<ex>[[Inside|Profiled_region]|Target] [my wallet|Ground] is where I put it .</ex>
<ex>[[Outside|Profiled_region]|Target] [your blind date's door|Ground] seems like the worst place in the world .</ex>

name: Locative_scenario
description: A #Figure is located with respect to a #Ground, whose location is (generally) better known. This is accomplished by identifying the #Figure as within a #Profiled_region--a shape defined by an Image Schema, located at, on, or in the #Ground, and scaled by context. Alternatively, a group of #Figures is described within a symmetrical #Profiled_region located simultaneously with respect to each of the #Figures.

name: Lodging_scenario
description: A #Host provides a #Residence for a #Lodger to temporarily stay.

name: Lose_possession
description: Subframe of Transfer in which the #Donor begins by possessing a #Theme and finishes by not possessing the #Theme.

name: Lose_possession_scenario
description: This is the Frame which binds together the initial state of the #Donor possessing the #Theme, the transfer, and the final state of the #Donor not possessing the #Theme.

name: Losing
description:
This frame describes a situation in which an #Owner loses his or her #Possession.  The #Owner may have failed to keep ownership of their #Possession (i.e. robbery or gambling) or may have unintentionally misplaced their #Possession.
<ex>[I|Owner] [misplaced|Target] [my watch|Possession].</ex>
<ex>[He|Owner] [lost|Target] [his wedding ring|Possession] [while playing cards|Means].</ex>

name: Losing_it
description:
An #Protagonist goes from a default state of mental and emotional equilibrium into a temporary state of disequilibrium, often a state of anger. The #Protagonist's behavior is portrayed as deeply affected. An #Explanation for the change of state may be given. Likewise, #Actions that the #Protagonist takes as a result of their new emotional state may be expressed. Both #Explanations and #Actions may be introduced just as coordinated clauses. The lexical units also are frequently accompanied by expressions of an #Affected_party.
This frame is populated by many lexical units that are based on the emotion-heat/pressure metaphor.  Note also that many phrases with equivalent meaning to targets of this frame are compositional, e.g. 'go insane', which we treat as the LU insane.a (of the Mental_property frame) plus the inchoative support go.v.

<ex>[You|Protagonist] [totally|Degree] [flipped|Target] [out|Target] [on our waiter|Affected_party] [because of the mix-up with the bill|Explanation].</ex>

name: Losing_someone
description:
This frame describes a #Sufferer who experiences the loss of someone through death.  The LUs in this frame imply a strong emotional connection between the #Sufferer and the #Deceased.
<ex>[She|Sufferer] [lost|Target] [her husband|Deceased] [in the war|Explanation].</ex>

name: Losing_track_of
description: This non-lexical frame describes a scenario in which a #Perceiver fails to keep sight of a #Theme.

name: Losing_track_of_perceiver
description:
This frames describes a #Theme who evades the sight of a #Perceiver.  The focus of this frame is the #Theme, which appears in subject position.  This frame contrasts with the opposing perspective in Losing_track_of_theme, where the #Perceiver is the subject and the #Theme is the object.
<ex>[The burglar|Theme] [lost|Target] [the police|Perceiver] [as the thief turned the corner|Explanation].</ex>

name: Losing_track_of_theme
description:
This frames describes a #Perceiver who fails to keep sight of a #Theme.  The focus of this frame is the #Perceiver, which appears in subject position.  This frame contrasts with the opposing perspective in Losing_track_of_perceiver, where the #Perceiver is the object and the #Theme is the subject.
<ex>[The police|Perceiver] [lost|Target] [the burglar|Theme] [as the thief turned the corner|Explanation].</ex>

name: Luck
description:
A #State_of_affairs is evaluated as good (or bad), against a background assumption that previously, the #State_of_affairs was thought to be unlikely to occur. The #State_of_affairs holds for a particular #Protagonist.

<ex>[He|Protagonist] is a [lucky|Target] [gambler|Role].</ex>

name: Make_acquaintance
description:
#Individuals first encounter each other and make introductions at a particular #Time, #Place, or #Context. The #Individuals may have known of each other before making introductions. The #Individuals may  be separately construed as #Individual_1 and #Individual_2. In some cases, there is a #Explanation of the circumstances which lead to the #Individuals' meeting.


<ex>Impressed when [he|ind1] first [met|Target] [Nixon|ind2], he had always thought of him as an intelligent man, and believed that Nixon would take a stand for civil rights</ex>

<ex>[We|ind1] [met|Target] [each other|ind2] [in the university|pla], worked in the same city and came to KSU together! </ex>

<ex>[Horatio Nelson and Emma Hamilton|inds] first [met|Target] [in Naples|pla] [in September 1793|tim]</ex>

<ex>Her name was Jenny and [I|ind1] [met|Target] [her|ind2] [through an online dating service|int].</ex>

name: Make_agreement_on_action
description:
Two (or more) people (the #Parties, also encodable as #Party_1 and #Party_2) negotiate an agreement. Both sides are construed as making a commitment to assume an #Obligation--the process is understood to be symmetrical or reciprocal. Instead of a specific mention of the #Obligation, a #Topic expression may be used to indicate the domain covered.

<ex>So far , [we|par1] have [agreed|Target][to cede 100km of coastline to Kiribati|Obligation] . [DNI|par2] </ex>

<ex>At common law, [the parties|pars] could <m>make</m> an [oral|med] [agreement|Target] [to submit a dispute to arbitration|obl] and such oral agreement would be valid.</ex>

name: Make_cognitive_connection
description:
Using #Evidence, which may or may not be expressed, a #Cognizer recognizes or proves that #Concept_1 is associated causally or collocationally with another concept, #Concept_2.  These may be expressed collectively as associated #Concepts.

<ex>[Our professor|Cognizer] [linked|Target] [monarchy and feudalism|Concepts].</ex>

name: Make_compromise
description:
Two (or more) people (the #Parties, also encodable as #Party_1 and #Party_2) come to an agreement committing them to carrying out an #Obligation. The agreement is construed as non-ideal for both parties but necessary to end a dispute. The process is understood to be symmetrical or reciprocal. Instead of a specific mention of the #Obligation, a #Topic expression may be used to indicate the domain covered.

<ex>No [arms|Topic] [compromise|Target] [between the two parties|Parties] is expected before the end of 2012.</ex>

<ex>So [you|Party_1]'ll [compromise|Target] [with us|Party_2] [to continue the project for at least another year|Obligation]?</ex>

name: Make_noise
description:
A physical entity, construed as a point-#Sound_source, emits a #Sound.  This includes animals and people making noise with their vocal tracts. Sometimes the sound itself is referred to with a nominal expression, in which case it is called the #Sound. #Manner expressions may also be relevant in this frame, if they describe properties of the sound as such.  A path-schema can be overlaid on the simple noise-making scene, adding a #Location_of_protagonist and/or a #Path.

This frame does not cover scenarios where objects create sound by coming into forceful contact with one another or rubbing against each other. Such scenarios are covered by the Impact and Friction frames. The current frame also does not cover cases where an animate Agent or a natural Force or Cause causes a single Source or several Sources (moving or rubbing against each other) to make noise. Such scenarios are  covered by the Cause_to_make_noise, Cause_impact, and *Cause_friction frames (the last of which is not yet in FrameNet). Cases where the major emphasis of the portrayed scene is on the motion of a Theme, with sound emission only an accompaniment, are covered by the Motion_noise frame. Likewise, cases where the Sound itself is portrayed as moving through space are not covered in this frame but rather in Sound_movement. Finally, all nouns used to evoke Sounds have been placed in the Sounds frame. We have done this because these nouns do  not denote sound emission/production events but only the Sound itself (*The siren's blare occurred right on time).

name: Making_arrangements
description:
An #Agent performs a series of unspecified tasks to plan for an #Event to take place at a #Scheduled_time and #Place.

<ex>[I|Agent]'ve [arranged|Target] [a breakfast meeting|Event] [for you|Bene] [tomorrow morning|Scheduled_time] [with Mr. Huntsberger|Event].</ex>

<ex>[Kevin and Beth|Agent] [organized|Target] [the graduate student conference|Event] [this year|Scheduled_time].</ex>

name: Making_faces
description:
An #Agent makes a particular facial expression, generally in response to some #Internal_cause (generally an emotional state).  Sometimes the #Body_part involved in the expression is mentioned in lieu of the #Agent.

<ex>[His|Agent] [eyes|Body_part] [smile|Target], but his lips do not.</ex>

name: Manipulate_into_doing
description:
A #Manipulator gets his #Victim to perform a #Resulting_action against what their better judgment would have been at the time. The means by which the #Manipulator overcomes or bypasses the #Victim's resistance to act need not be linguistic expression.  In some cases, the #Goods may stand in for a #Resulting_action of the #Victim giving the #Manipulator the #Goods.
<ex></ex>
<ex>Are you trying to tell me that [Ace|Manipulator] [blackmailed|Target] [you|Victim] [into becoming his lover|Resulting_action]?</ex>

<ex>[Stephanopoulos|Manipulator] [skillfully|Manner] [cajoles|Target] [him|Victim] [into keeping quiet|Resulting_action].</ex>

name: Manipulate_into_shape
description:
An #Agent manipulates a #Theme so that it ends up in a particular shape or configuration denoted by a #Resultant_configuration.

<ex>[She|Agent] [molded|Target] [the playdough|Theme] [into a ball|Resultant_configuration].</ex>

name: Manipulation
description:
The words in this frame describe the manipulation of an #Entity by an #Agent.  Generally, this implies that the #Entity is not deeply or permanently physically affected, nor is it overall moved from one place to another.

<ex>[Ian|Agent] [squeezed|Target] [Mara's hand|Entity].</ex>
<ex></ex>

A number of lexemes listed in this frame also occur in the Cause_motion frame (for example, <ment>push, yank</ment>).  Only the non-motion uses of these words belong in this frame, e.g., combinations such as <ment>push at, push on, yank at</ment>.

name: Manner
description:
A #Manner describes general or specific characteristics of an event in one of three ways:  First, it can refer to how a #Comparison_event transpires, absent the influence of an entity (e.g. ""the way you talk""). Second, it can refer to how a #Salient_entity conducts, performs, or otherwise participates in a #Comparison_activity (e.g. ""her manner of speaking""). Thirdly, the #Manner can describe a #Foreground_event by relating the #Foreground_event to a #Manner_descriptor (e.g. ""written (in) a silly way"", ""written the way I do"").
<ex></ex>
<ex>[He completed the task|Foreground_event] <m>in</m> a [fervent|Manner_descriptor] [[manner|Target]|Manner]. </ex>
<ex>I love the [smooth|Manner_descriptor] [[way|Target]|Manner] [that you talk|Comparison_event].</ex>
<ex>[Paul played soccer|Foreground_event] <m>in</m> a [[way|Target]|Manner] [that reminded me of my brother's playing|Manner_descriptor].</ex>
<ex>Much about a person can be determined from the [[manner|Target]|Manner] [one eats their meals|Comparison_event].</ex>
<ex> [His|Salient_entity] [[way|Target]|Manner] [of addressing people|Comparison_activity] <m>is</m>[ quite rude|Manner_descriptor].</ex>

This frame is unusual in requiring a modifying relative clause for the FE #Comparison_event, and also allowing a relative clause to serve as a #Manner_descriptor.  The LU way.n, when definite, may be modified by a relative clause meaning ""in the same manner that...""; the relative clause in such cases is annotated as #Comparison_event:

<ex>[I did it|Foreground_event] the [way|Target] [she did|Comparison_event].</ex>

name: Manner_of_life
description:
An #Experiencer actualizes a certain pattern of behavior, a #Lifestyle, which persists for a significant period of time in the #Experiencer's life and is recognized as part of his character or normal routine. The #Lifestyle is not necessarily realized intentionally, and may just be the result of circumstance.

<ex>[He|Experiencer] [lived|Target] [a hedonistic life|Lifestyle] [before he settled down|Time].</ex>
<ex>[When she graduated|Time], [she|Experiencer] had to [live|Target] [extremeley|Degree] [frugally|Manner] because there were no jobs.</ex>

name: Manufacturing
description:
A #Producer produces a #Product from a #Resource for commercial purposes.
<ex> They [produced|Target] [only half of the units|Product] [after an injunction to follow the environmental policy|Circumstances].</ex>

name: Margin_of_resolution
description:
The #Outcome of a contest is described in terms of the #Margin between what would be required for victory and the actual #Outcome.


<ex>The Basque nationalists won a [narrow|Target] [victory|Outcome] in the regional elections on Sunday.</ex>


<ex>It was a major victory for workers, and a [decisive|Target] [defeat|Outcome] for the Tory.</ex>

name: Mass_motion
description:
A #Mass_theme, generally made up of many individuals, moves from a #Source to a #Goal with some #Path.

<ex>[Emails from so-called Nigerian princes|Mass_theme] [flooded|Target] [inboxes|Goal] [all over the US|Area].</ex>

name: Mathematical_relationship
description:
A mathematical expression #Expression_1 has a relationship with another mathematical expression #Expression_2.  This relationship may be of equality, inequality, or near-equality.  The #Type of the equation may be specified.  Senses of LUs in this frame that are not overtly mathematical should be placed in Contigency.

<ex>The [FORMULA|Target] of [a line|Type] can be given in slope-intercept form</ex>

<ex>The equation for a line is [y|Expression_1] [EQUALS|Target] [mx + b|Expression_2]</ex>

name: Means
description:
An #Agent makes use of a #Means (either an action or a (system of) entities standing in for the action) in order to achieve a #Purpose.

(This frame may be broadened to include non-agentive intermediate actions.)

<ex>The primary [means|Target] [of gas detection|Purpose] <m>is</m> [mass spectroscopy|Means] .</ex>
<ex>[They learned of the attack|Purpose] [by|Target] [monitoring the allied communications channels|Means] .</ex>

name: Means_of_transportation
description: Vehicles that may be used by the #Tourist while visiting a place.

name: Measurable_attributes
description:
An #Entity has a particular scalar #Attribute with a value exceeding a contextually-specified or generally-understood standard. Except where there is a difference in FEs, we place all adjectives related to measurable quantities in this frame. Note that when an adjective appears with a quantity expression (e.g., <ment>6 feet long</ment>), it belongs to the Dimension frame.

<ex>[That ladder|Entity] is [really|Degree] [tall|Target].</ex>

<ex>After his back injury, he won't lift [heavy|Target] [boxes|Entity].</ex>

name: Measures
description: An #Entity is measured in some (implicit) #Attribute by quantifying the #Count of a particular #Unit whose value for the #Attribute is known.  LUs and constructions whose meanings inherit from Measures are used in a relatively small, delimitable set of constructions.  They may be complements of particular lexical constructions (a <ment>length</ment>of 20 ft., <ment>measures</ment> 20 ft.) or parts of non-lexical constructions (including Transparent Noun constructions and Measurement_plus_adjective and Measurement_plus_PP).

name: Measure_area
description: This transparent noun frame is concerned with #Units for measuring the #Area of regions.<ex>Hillary lives in the middle of [10|Count] [[acres|Unit]|Target] [of wheat|Occupant].</ex><ex>Paul owns [20|Count] [[hectares|Target]|Unit] [of land|Area].</ex>

name: Measure_by_action
description:
This frame involves words that provide a measure for some undelimited (mass) #Entity by referring to an #Event that a prototypical quantity (or duration) of the #Entity stereotypically participates in.  The #Entity is not necessarily a physical entity, but may instead be an undelimited type of event (such as a noise, or an activity).


<ex>He put two [[splashes|Target]|Event] [of cologne|Entity] on his face.</ex>
<ex>Sorry--there's only [two|Count] [[bites|Target]|Event] [of cake|Entity] left.</ex>
<ex>Add a [[pinch|Target]|Event] [of salt|Entity].</ex>

name: Measure_duration
description:
This frame contains (transparent ) nouns that are #Units of measurement for time. The frame elements are #Count, #Unit and #Process.

<ex>The final total was 606, scored in only [10|Count] [[hours|Unit]|Target] [of excellent batsmanship|Process].</ex>

In this frame, we will NOT annotate deictic, calendric uses of nouns like week, month, etc. as in ""next week, this month, in the 21st century"".

name: Measure_mass
description: This frame is concerned with nouns that denote #Units of measurement for masses. The Frame Elements are #Unit, #Count,  and #Stuff.<ex>Jelena bought [three|Count] [[kilos|Unit]|Target] [of apples|Stuff].</ex><ex>Add [a|Count] [[pound|Unit]|Target] [of sugar|Stuff].</ex>

name: Measure_of_distance_and_length
description:
This frame is concerned with #Units of measurement for distance and linear extent. These #Units are used to be appropriately precise about a distance or length measure by specifying a #Count for a standardly understood #Unit.

<ex>We only have to go [two|Count] [[miles|Target]|Unit] before we get to the coast .</ex>

When nouns of this frame are used to specify the linear extent of some #Stuff, there are a number of constructions for expressing the #Stuff, including transparent noun constructions (1) and (2) and prenominal modifiers (3).

<ex>(1) The shirt is made from [12|Count] [[miles|Unit]|Target] [of pure cotton|Stuff].</ex>
<ex>(2) [81|Count] [[miles|Unit]|Target] [of dyke|Stuff] are still visible from this point.</ex>
<ex>(3) The manufacturer gave the entire airplane a [3|Count] [[millimeter|Target]|Unit] [coating|Stuff] of the sealant.</ex>

name: Measure_scenario
description:
An #Entity has a particular #Value for an #Attribute which may be described in several different ways, including:
<ex></ex>
#Degree of deviation from the #Value expected for the kind of #Entity seen in a particular instance, or in comparison to some other explicit comparison set.
<ex></ex>
Absolute quantification in terms of the number of #Counts of a particular #Unit which equal the #Value for the #Attribute.

name: Measure_volume
description:
This frame is concerned with nouns that denote #Units of measurement for volumes. The Frame Elements are #Unit, #Count,  #Stuff, and #Size. The frame will be split soon into container-derived volumes (box, bottle etc.) and pure volumes (gallon, quart). For the moment we tag things as follows:
<ex>Greg drank [two|Count] [2 liter|Size] [[bottles|Unit]|Target] [of lemonade|Stuff].</ex>
<ex>Sue drank [two|Count] [[liters|Unit]|Target]
[of beer|Stuff].</ex>
This frame necessitated the introduction of  the GF: Quant and the PT: Num used for expressions such as  the following:
<ex>two [cups|Target] of coffee</ex>
<ment>FE: #Count, GF: Quant, PT: Num</ment><ex></ex>
Note that we treat cardinal numbers and ""a"" (= 1) in the same way.
<ex>a [cup|Target] of coffee</ex>
<ment>FE: #Count, GF: Quant, PT: Num</ment><ex></ex>
For the present, we prefer not to annotate ""many cups of coffee""
<ex>many [cups|Target] of coffee</ex>
<ment>FE: #Count, GF: Quant, PT: Adj</ment><ex></ex>

name: Medical_conditions
description:
Words in this frame name medical conditions or diseases that a patient suffers from, is being treated for, may be cured of, or die of.  The condition or disease may be described in a variety of ways, including the part or area of the body (#Body_part) affected by the condition (e.g. liver cancer, cardiovascular disease), the #Cause of the condition (e.g. bacterial meningitis, viral pneumonia), a prominent #Symptom of the condition (e.g. asymptomatic stenosis, blue ear disease), the #Patient or population (originally) affected by the condition (e.g. bovine tuberculosis, juvenile diabetes), or the (proper) #Name used to identify the condition (e.g. Munchausen Syndrome, Lou Gehrig's Disease).  Annotation in this frame is done in respect to the name of the condition or disease.

<ex>John died of  [pancreatic|Body_P] [cancer|Target].</ex>

name: Materials_used_in_healthcare
description:
This frame includes words for medical instruments--i.e. #Instruments designed for  an institutional function or #Purpose.

<ex><gov>Use</gov> <x>the[[stethoscope|Target]|Inst]</x> [to check his lungs|Purpose].</ex>

name: Medical_interaction_scenario
description:
A #Patient interacts with one or more #Medics (doctors, nurses, and/or EMTs with a responsibility for the #Patient's health) so that the #Medics can determine the health status of the #Patient and maintain or restore the #Patient's health as necessary.
<ex></ex>
Usually, the #Patient has an #Affliction, a medical problem that motivates or necessitates their coming into the care of a #Medic. At a minimum, the #Patient has a single interaction with a #Medic, but usually the #Patient has a relationship with the #Medic or group of medical professionals who either have responsibility for helping them with their specific #Affliction or for their health in general. Medical interactions normally take place at a #Medical_center (a hospital or doctor's office), but in cases where the #Patient suffers a sudden catastrophic #Affliction, the #Patient may be taken into the care of EMTs, who act as their #Medic until reaching a medical center.
<ex></ex>
In some cases, the #Body_system that has a problem is mentioned in place of the #Affliction.

<ex>[Her|Medic] three [cardiac|Body_system] [[patients|Target]|Patient] take up all her time.</ex>
<ex>[Our doctors|Medic] <m>provide</m> the best [healthcare|Target] on the planet.</ex>

name: Medical_intervention
description: Procedural or Medicine based #Interventions are used on a #Patient to attempt to alleviate a #Medical_condition. These interventions can have a #Frequency_of_success as well as #Side_effects.  This frame differs from Cure in that this frame deals only with attempts to alleviate a #Medical_condition, whereas Cure deals with situations in which the Affliction or #Medical_condition has been cured.

name: Medical_professionals
description:
This frame includes words that name medical professionals and is closely related to the Medical_specialties frame. The FE #Type characterizing a #Professional's sub-specialty may also be expressed.

<ex>Ralph is a [[paediatrician|Target]|Prof].</ex>
<ex><x>[Paediatric|Type] [[oncologists|Target]|Prof]</x> <gov>treat</gov> children with leukemia.</ex>

name: Medical_specialties
description:
This frame includes words that name medical specialties and is closely related to the Medical_professionals frame.  The FE #Type characterizing a sub-are in a #Specialty may also be expressed.
<ex>Ralph <gov>practices</gov> <x>[paediatric|Type] [[oncology|Target]|Spec]</x>.</ex>

name: Medium
description:
Words in this frame describe a relationship in which an #Item is expressed through a #Text.
<ex>[The act of murder is rampant|Item] [in|Target] [the Bible|Text].</ex>

<ex>[In|Target] [his State of the Union Address|Text], [President Bush committed our nation to achieving three great goals of our time|Item].</ex>

<ex>[Linnaeus|Item] [in|Target] [his writings|Text] [often|Frequency] [quotes his great predecessor|Item].</ex>

name: Meet_specifications
description:
An #Agent or #Entity becomes sufficient enough to meet a #Standard.  Alternatively, an action or occurrence can be thought of as #Event that fulfills a #Standard.  In this frame, the #Agent, #Entity, or #Event can be conceptualized as being on a scale where a change of value or circumstances brings it in line with the position of the #Standard on the scale.
<ex>[This paper|Entity] does not [meet|Target] [the requirements for graduation|Standard].</ex>
<ex>Will [Ben|Agent] [fulfill|Target] [his obligation to Margaret |Standard]?</ex>

name: Meet_with
description:
In this frame #Party_1 meets with #Party_2 at a prearranged #Time and #Place.  If expressed, #Purpose only applies to #Party_1.  The #Purpose of the meeting is usually discussion over a certain topic.
<ex>[I|Party_1] [met with|Target] [my professor|Party_2] [to talk about my midterm|Purpose].</ex>

name: Meet_with_response
description:
A #Trigger elicits a #Response.  The #Response may either be some kind of action meant to address the #Trigger event or an expressed judgment of the #Trigger event.
<ex>[Our proposal|Trigger] [met|Target] [with harsh criticism|Response].</ex>

name: Membership
description:
A #Member is semi-permanently part of a socially constructed #Group.


<ex>[Victor|mm] <m>is</m> [part|Target] [of the Red Crescent|Group]</ex>

name: Member_of_military
description:
A #Person is a member of an organized military organization belonging to a nation-state or similar body. The military membership may be part-time, but is considered a job. This is in opposition to combatants who may be loyal to a particular cause but are not part of the military arm of a government.

<ex>The British at one point had an occupying army of over a million [well-trained|Descriptor] [[soldiers|Person]|Target].</ex>

<ex>After 9/11 she decided to become a [full-time|Contract_basis] [[airman|Person]|Target]</ex>.

<ex>[US|Loyal_side] [[soldiers|Person]|Target] have fought in the region for the past twenty years with no end in sight.</ex>

name: Memorization
description:
A #Cognizer applies oneself to commit a #Pattern to memory, so that the #Cognizer would recognize future examples of the #Pattern or be able to reproduce it.


<ex>[A gaggle of students|cog] were [frantically|man] [memorizing|Target] [the answers|pat] [out in the hall|pla].</ex>
<ex>It is possible to [memorize|Target] [by rote|mea] and at the same time have a full grasp of the underlying meaning. [CNI|cog] [INI|pat]</ex>

This frame differs from Education_teaching in that the #Cognizer is construed as acting alone, with no indication of an interacting individual that provides guidance.

name: Memory
description:
This frame is concerned with #Cognizers remembering and forgetting mental #Content.

<ex>[John|Cognizer] [forgot|Target] [everything|Content] [about his uncle|Topic].</ex>

name: Mental_activity
description: In this frame, a #Sentient_entity has some activity of the mind operating on a particular #Content or about a particular #Topic.  The particular activity may be perceptual, emotional, or more generally cognitive.  This non-lexical frame is intended primarily for inheritance.

name: Mental_property
description:
The adjectives and nouns in this frame are all based on the idea that mental properties may be attributed to a person (#Protagonist) by a (usually implicit) #Judge  on the basis of that person's #Behavior, as broadly understood.  Though on a conceptual level these words always attribute mental properties to people, they may be applied to #Protagonist's #Behaviors as well, with the understanding that the #Behavior is revealing a (usually temporary) property of the #Protagonist responsible for it. For example, while we may speak of a <ment>stupid person</ment>, we may also speak of a <ment>stupid thing to say/do/think</ment>. In addition, we may mention both the #Protagonist and the #Behavior, as in <ex>It was [stupid|Target] of me to do that.</ex> Some of the words in this frame also have slightly different uses, in which there is a constituent expressing the #Practice with respect to which the mental property holds of the #Protagonist, as in:
    <ex>She is [astute|Target] [at math|Practice].</ex>
While #Practice expressions do not co-occur with #Behavior expressions, they seem sufficiently different semantically to warrant a distinct frame element (FE) name. Also, while the FE #Behavior usually occurs in sentences expressing judgments that are based on specific events, #Practice occurs in sentences that are about general capabilities. In addition to the frame elements which are expressed, there is an understood judge (usually the speaker) in the background who forms the opinion of the #Protagonist's mental properties, judging the #Protagonist or the #Protagonist's #Behavior to be <ment>stupid</ment>, <ment>brilliant</ment>, etc.

name: Mental_stimulus_exp_focus
description:
An #Experiencer has an emotion as caused by a [Stimulus|Stimulus] or concerning a #Topic.

<ex>I fall asleep hours later to the sound of their [engrossed|Target] [murmuring|Expressor].</ex>

<ex>[Most of these great lords|Experiencer] are [downright|Degree] [infatuated|Target] [with Italy|Stimulus].</ex>

name: Mental_stimulus_stimulus_focus
description:
A #Stimulus serves to bring about an emotion of mental stimulation in an #Experiencer.

<ex>You will not easily find a [more|Degree] [absorbing|Target] [box-set of piano discs|Stimulus].</ex>

<ex>[New classes of free radical|Stimulus] are [particularly|Degree] [interesting|Target] [to chemists|Experiencer].</ex>

name: Mention
description:
A #Communicator or #Medium briefly references something in a #Message, in which only a subpart of the full content is profiled.

<ex>[The General Secretary|Communicator] [mentions|Target] [some of them|Specified_content] [in his report|Medium].</ex>

<ex>[The Queen 's Speech|Medium] also [mentions|Target] [the importance of making sure that Iraq complies with United Nations resolutions|Message].</ex>

<ex> When [Barack Obama's name|Specified_content] was [mentioned|Target], boos filled the room. [CNI|Communicator]</ex>

name: Military
description: Some #Possessor, either a nation, institution, or private individual, controls a #Force whose primary functions to defend the #Possessor (or, in the case of an institution or individual, some area of land significant to them) and to carry out offensive actions for the #Possessor.  The #Domain of operation of the #Force may be expressed.

name: Military_operation
description:
The military #Force of a #Possessor (either a nation, institution, or private individual) conducts large-scale activities in a #Area to accomplish military or combined military/non-military goals.

<ex>These groups are known to have carried out attacks on [international coalition forces|Force] [operating|Target] [in Afghanistan|Area].</ex>

<ex>[Anti-piracy|opp] [operations|Target] will continue while new strategies are developed.</ex>

This frame construes the operation asymmetrically: the #Force acts with respect to military and political entities in the target #Area. Compare this to (usually, but not always, lower-level and violent) military actions that can be understood symmetrically (<m>war</m>, <m>battle</m>, <m>encounter</m>, <m>engagement</m>, etc).

name: Mining
description:
A #Miner attempts to obtain a desirable #Resource, rocks and minerals, located in a #Place being mined, by digging or tunneling in the ground.

<ex>[They|Miner] [mine|Target] [diamonds|Resource] [in Africa|Place].</ex>

name: Misdeed
description:
A #Wrongdoer engages in a #Misdeed.

<ex>[You|wro] have [sinned|Target] for the last time, Stephen!</ex>

name: Money
description:
#Money is a medium used for exchanging goods and services. It is in most cases issued by a government (its #Creator) in the form of coins and banknotes. Particular amounts of it may have a designated or planned #Use, or may have come from some #Origin.

<ex>The [[money|Target]|mon] [for our daughter's college education|Inherent_purpose] is currently earning interest in a savings account.</ex>

<ex>The entire project ended up being funded with [Swiss|cre] [[funds|Target]|mon].</ex>

<ex>The use of [paper|Material] [[money|Target]|mon] really caught on in Europe in the 1700s</ex>

name: Morality_evaluation
description:
In this frame an #Evaluee is described by a (usually implicit) #Judge with respect to the morality or rightness of his or her #Behavior.

<ex>That was [very|Degree] [righteous|Target] [of you|Evaluee] [to help him|Behavior].</ex>

name: Motion
description:
Some entity (#Theme) starts out in one place (#Source) and ends up in some other place (#Goal), having covered some space between the two (#Path). Alternatively, the #Area or #Directionin which the #Theme moves or the #Distance of the movement may be mentioned.

<ex>[That kite you see just to the right of his head|Theme] was [moving|Target] [around|Area] [pretty fast|Speed] but the camera seemed to catch it ok.</ex>

<ex>There are several accounts of [the stench|Theme] [drifting|Target] [to shore|Goal] [from the ships in the middle of the river|Source]</ex>

<ex>[Dust particles|Theme] [floating|Target] [about|Area] made him sneeze uncontrollably.</ex>

<ex>[The grill|Theme], unsecured, [rolled|Target] [a few feet|Distance] [across the yard|Path].</ex>

<ex>[The swarm|Theme] [went|Target] [away|Direction] [to the end of the hall|Goal].</ex>

The frames that inherit the general Motion frame add some elaboration to this simple idea.  Inheriting frames can add Goal-profiling (<ment>arrive, reach</ment>), Source-profiling (<ment>leave, depart</ment>), or Path-profiling (<ment>traverse, cross</ment>), or aspects of the manner of motion (<ment>run, jog</ment>) or assumptions about the shape-properties, etc., of any of the places involved (<ment>insert, extract</ment>).
A particularly complex area in the vocabulary of Motion is the depiction of the relation of Vehicles to the Theme.  In some cases, no separate Theme is expressed:

<ex>The plane [flew|Target] over the city.</ex>

In this case, the sentence is annotated in Self_motion.  When the Vehicle is profiled as being operated by a Driver, the sentence is annotated in the Operate_vehicle frame:

<ex>Don't try to [fly|Target] an F-16 without training!</ex>

This is very similar to the Bringing frame which covers cases where the Vehicle is necessarily involved, but the movement of the #Theme (something carried by the Vehicle) is profiled:

<ex>It's scary [flying|Target] hundreds of people over thousands of miles of ocean every day.</ex>

Some of the same vocabulary is also used to describe the situation where Passengers Ride_vehicle or Operate_vehicle (each of these a perspective on Use_vehicle):

<ex>I [flew|Target] to Chicago on the red-eye.</ex>
<ex>I [flew|Target] my plane across the Canadian border</ex>

Finally, there are cases where, despite the use of similar vocabulary, there is no self-propelled Vehicle involved at all:

<ex>The ball [flew|Target] over the fence.</ex>

This last type is annotated in the simple Motion frame.

name: Motion_directional
description:
In this frame a #Theme moves in a certain #Direction which is often determined by gravity or other natural, physical forces. The #Theme is not necessarily a self-mover.

<ex> [The paper|Theme] [fell|Target] [to the floor|Path].</ex>
<ex> [The girl|Theme] [dropped|Target] [13 stories|Distance] [to her death|Result].</ex>

name: Motion_noise
description:
This frame pertains to noise verbs used to characterize motion.  Motion_noise verbs take largely the same #Source, #Path and #Goal expressions as other types of Motion verbs.

<ex>[The reception doors|Thm] [banged|Target] [open|Result].</ex>
<ex>[Guillemots and razor bills|Thm] [whirred|Target] [rapidly|Spd] [out to sea|Goal].</ex>
<ex>[The limousine|Thm] [purred|Target] [forwards|Path] [into the traffic|Goal].</ex>
<ex>[Loose guns|Thm] [rumbled|Target] [all over the ship's deck|Area] .</ex>
<ex>[The train|Thm] [clanged|Target] along [for over a thousand miles|Dist].</ex>

name: Motion_scenario
description: This frame binds together the various parts of movement, from setting out, to traveling, to arriving.

name: Moving_in_place
description:
A #Theme moves with respect to a #Fixed_location, generally with a certain #Periodicity, without undergoing unbounded translational motion or significant alteration of configuration/shape.

<ex>[It|Theme] [vibrated|Target] [from the wind|Explanation].</ex>

name: Namesake
description:
An #Entity shares a name with its #Namesake. Note that the shared name is not a frame element as it cannot be directly expressed as an argument of the target lexical units in this frame.



<ex>[Alberta's|Entity] [namesake|Target] caught in royal scandal</ex>
<ex>[ [namesake|Target]|Namesake] caught in royal scandal</ex>
<ex>Instead, the [eponymous|Target] [character|Entity] is a mildly retarded woman, Martha (Winger), whose simplistic view on life places her in ethically compromising positions. [DNI|Namesake]</ex>
<ex>[He|Namesake] is [my|Entity] [namesake|Target], one amongst the many described in my homepage, and is much better qualified to write a page like this.</ex>

name: Name_conferral
description:
This  frame contains words that talk about how Speakers name Entities.

<ex>They drove through [an area|Entity] [nicknamed|Target] [Sniper's Alley|Name]</ex>
<ex>[His parents|Speaker] [named|Target] [him|Entity] [Winston|Name] [after the British prime minister|Name_source].</ex>


In this frame we will ignore uses of words like baptize and christen that don't clearly bring out the name conferral but talk about the meaning of baptism etc. as a sacrament:

<ex>They christened  the child on December 4th.</ex>
<ex>Method was baptized into the church soon thereafter.</ex>
<ex>Cyril was baptized as  a Methodist.</ex>

name: Natural_disaster
description: The words in this frame indicate some #Natural_disaster that may occur at some #Place and affect a #Victim.

name: Natural_features
description:
The #Locale is a geographical location as defined by shape.  This frame includes natural geographic features, including land/ice forms and bodies of water.

<ex> We climbed up the [rock|Constituent_parts] [[cliff|Target]|Locale].</ex>

name: Natural_phenomena
description: A #Natural_phenomenon is a non-artificial event that occurs without human interference. This type of phenomenon can influence human life and is related, for example, to epidemics, weather conditions, natural disasters, etc. The #Phenomenon can occur in a specific #Place and #Time, in addition to having a specific #Duration. The #Manner as it occurs, the #Rate or #Frequency of occurrences can also be mentioned.

name: Needing
description:
The speaker believes that some state of affairs or entity (the #Requirement) must be present in order to cause some other dependent state of affairs to occur (the #Dependent).  In the typical case, the #Cognizer desires the occurrence of the #Dependent and so also desires the obtainment or occurrence of the #Requirement.

<ex>[I|cog] [need|Target] [one more bolt|req]. [DNI|dep]</ex>
<ex>[I|cog] [need|Target] [one more nail|req] [to finish building the cabinet|dep].</ex>
<ex>[In order to complete the treaty|dep], [the United States|cog] will [require|Target] [several more diplomats|req].</ex>
<ex>[He|cog] [needs|Target] [everyone to leave his office|req] [to finish his work|dep].</ex>

name: Negation
description:
This frame models the semantic contribution of negation, in which the profiled content of the #Negated_proposition is asserted to contrast incompatibly with a corresponding #Factual_situation, which is normally implicit.  The #Negated_proposition and the #Factual_situation share non-focal content, on the basis of which they correspond, and contrast in a subset of their content, the focal content, established with reference to a set of focus constructions not described here.  (The focus of negation is often conveyed intonationally in spoken English; in text, however, negative focus must be derived inferentially from contextual reference. A subset of focus constructions will be annotated in the constructicon.)
<ex></ex>
While the semantics of negation are quite different from the semantics belonging to most frames, at a minimum, our modeling of the concept using frame semantic tools can be viewed as a practical attempt to label a problem and annotate examples that may inform further research.
<ex></ex>
Negation can be evoked verbally (analytic or synthetic) or nominally. Negators include ""not"", ""no"", ""never"", and negational affixes, such as those used on inflected verbs in synthetic verbal negation (wasn't, isn't, haven't).

<ex>[It 's|Negated_proposition] [not|Target] [far from here|Negated_proposition] . [INI|Factual_situation]</ex>
<ex>[She 's|Negated_proposition] [not|Target] [smart|Negated_proposition] , [she 's sly|Factual_situation] .</ex>

name: Negative_conditional
description:
An #Anti_consequence is presented as not occurring if the #Profiled_possibility occurs.

<ex>[Unless|Target] [we try harder|Profiled_possibility] , [we 're gonna lose an opportunity here|Anti_consequence] .</ex>

name: Network
description:
A set of entities of the same or similar types (#Nodes) are linked to each other by #Connections to form a #Network allowing for the flow of information, resources, etc.

<ex>For the most part, [the Interstate System|net] <m>is</m> a [connected|des] [network|Target] [of highways|Connections] bounded by the Canadian and Mexican borders, the Gulf of Mexico, and the Atlantic.</ex>

<ex>Through [our|pos] [worldwide|des] [[network|Target]|net] [of representatives and agents|Nodes], Lozenger Inc.  was able
to serve customers in countries around the globe.</ex>

name: Noise_makers
description:
The #Noise_maker is an artifact used to produce sound, especially for musical effect.

<ex>The [church|Grnd] [[bells|nm]|Target] rang</ex>
<ex>The [car|Grnd] [[alarm|nm]|Target] went off again</ex>
<ex>I have never played an [acoustic|tp]  [[guitar|nm]|Target].</ex>
<ex>Each artist personally owns a Steinway and has chosen to perform on the [Steinway|Creator] [piano|Target] professionally</ex>

name: Non-commutative_process
description:
LUs in this frame describe a non-commutative process (as opposed to a generic statement) of arithmetic, e.g. subtraction and division, involving two numbers, labeled #Term_1 and #Term_2.  Because of the non-commutative nature of these processes, #Term_1 and #Term_2 are not separated on a grammatical basis but rather on a mathematical basis (see FE definitions). When referencing the process, the numbers can be vague and are often omitted through indefinite null instantiation.

<ex>[I|Calculator] [divided|Target] [x|Term_1] [by y|Term_2].</ex>

name: Non-commutative_statement
description:
LUs in this frame describe a non-commutative statement of arithmetic, e.g. subtraction and division, involving two numbers, labeled #Term_1 and #Term_2.  This frame contrasts with Arithmetic_non-commutative_process in that the statement frame emphasizes the relationship between the terms in combining to form some #Result.

<ex></ex>Because of the non-commutative nature of these processes, #Term_1 and #Term_2 are not separated on a grammatical basis but rather on a mathematical basis (see FE definitions). When referencing the process, the numbers can be vague and are often omitted through indefinite null instantiation.

name: Non-gradable_proximity
description:
A #Figure is characterized as near the #Ground, according to some contextually given scale. Many lexical units of this frame additionally specify in which direction relative to the #Ground one can find the #Figure (under.prep, north.adv), or directions from the #Ground from which the #Figure is excluded (e.g. beside.prep excludes the vertical and front/back axes); for specifications of direction, see the semantic types attached to the lexcial units.  Members of this frame that make reference to an absolute, earth-based grid (e.g. <ment>north</ment>, <ment>south</ment>, etc.) imply a geographic scale of proximity, and so are frequently not paraphrasable as ""near"".


<ex>She <ment>put</ment> [her shoes|Figure] [under|Target] [the table|Ground] .</ex>
<ex>[Michael Jackson|Figure] <m>was</m> [right|Distance] [next to|Target] [me|Ground] !</ex>
<ex>[Down|Direction] [by|Target] [his left foot|Ground] <m>was</m> [a little grenade|Figure] .</ex>
<ex></ex>
The subset of LUs that inherently pick out a particular direction (e.g. <ment>north</ment>, <ment>behind</ment>) may occur with a specification of a #Distance in that direction from a #Ground at which the #Figure may be found, while LUs that pick out two or more directions of relevance from a #Ground (e.g. <ment>beside</ment>) can only characterize the general accessibility of the #Figure relative to the #Ground.
<ex>[30 miles|Distance] [north|Target]</ex>
<ex>[right|Accessibility] [beside|Target] my leg</ex>

This frame is intended to cover a limited set of productive metaphor cases in which allegiance is expressed as a Devotee standing to one side or behind an Allegiance_holder:

<ex>[I|Figure] <m>stand</m> [beside|Target] [what I said to him|Ground] .</ex>
<ex>[They|Figure] will <m>stand</m> [right|Accessibility] [next to|Target] [me|Ground] in the fight against homophobia .</ex>

This frame is not intended for metaphorical cases of quantity specification:

<ex>There was [above|Target] 500 kg of cocaine in the shipment .</ex>

This frame does not cover the multitude of other metaphorical cases like ""next to impossible"", ""under consideration"", ""under his rule"", ""beside himself"", ""beside the point"".

name: Noncombatant
description:
This frame contains words that denote people who are not participating in a military #Conflict.

<ex>[Jones|Person] <m>was</m> a [noncombatant|Target] [in WWII|con].</ex>

<ex>News comes in every day of [[civilians|Person]|Target] getting caught up in military operations.</ex>

name: Notability
description:
An entity is considered worthy of mention for their ability or influence among some #Type of similar entities. The entity need not be well-known or famous, though if it is, it may be stated by its #Name only. Their worth may be restricted to a #Time or #Place.

<ex>[Dali|Name] is one of the [great|Target] [artists|Type] [of the 20th century|Time].</ex>

name: Notification_of_charges
description:
The judge or other court officer (the Authority) informs the #Accused of the #Charges against him/her, i.e. the alleged actions and the relevant laws.
<ex></ex>
<ex>[The board|Accused] has been [accused|Target] [by the federal court|Arraign_authority] [of making decisions based on narrow agendas and meddling where it shouldn't|Charges].</ex>

<ex>[The police|Arraign_authority] [charged|Target] [a young nurse|Accused] [with four murders|Charges].</ex>
Compare to: Citing.

name: Nuclear_process
description:
An #Initial_element is converted into a #Final_element via a process of decay, fusion, or fission which changes the number or type of hadrons (protons or neutrons) in the nucleus of the atoms that make up the #Element.

<ex>[5.5 percent of nucleii|Element] [decay|Target] [from tritium|Initial_element] [to He3|Final_element] [in a year|Period_of_iterations] .</ex>

name: Objective_influence
description:
An #Influencing_entity, an #Influencing_situation, or an #Influencing_variable has an influence on a #Dependent_entity, #Dependent_situation,  or a #Dependent_variable.
<ex></ex>

Compare to Subjective_influence. Words in Objective_influence are used to make claims about correlations in the world, where words in Subjective_influence are used to explain emotional impacts made on cognizers.


<ex>More and more doctors realise that [diet|infs] can [influence|Target] [disease|deps].</ex>

<ex>Our subject is the body clock; how [it|infs] [influences|Target] [our physiology and behaviour|deps] and how it interacts with the rhythms in our environment.</ex>

<ex>But it is more likely that [a physical restraint|infe] [influenced|Target] [the swirling liquids|depe].</ex>

<ex>It claimed, perhaps hollowly, that [NT|infe] had yet to [impact|Target] [its business|deps].</ex>

<ex>[This kind of elementary boo-boo|infs] would certainly [impact|Target] [video speed|depv].</ex>

name: Obligation_scenario
description: Under some, usually implicit, #Condition a #Duty needs to be fulfilled by a #Responsible_party. If the #Duty is not performed, there may be some undesirable social #Consequence for the #Responsible_party. This #Consequence may or may not be stated overtly.

name: Obscurity
description:
An #Entity is obscure, unnotable, and in general little-known. In the case of an eventive #Entity, lack of fame entails a large number of people not being aware of the event's occurence; in the case of a concrete #Entity, including humans, lack of fame entails non-awareness of existence.

<ex>[Geoffrey Rush|Entity] <ment>was</ment> [little|Target] [known|Target] [outside his native Australia|Place] [when he soared to international prominence|Time].</ex>

name: Obviousness
description:
A #Phenomenon is portrayed with respect to the #Degree of likelihood that it will  be perceived and known, given the (usually implicit) #Evidence, #Perceiver, and the #Circumstances in which it is considered.  For several of the LUs, such as <ment>visible, audible, etc.</ment>, the type of the #Evidence is fixed by the targets themselves being a perceptual experience.

<ex>It<m>'s</m> [abundantly|deg] [obvious|Target] [that we'll need to spend more time on public perception|phe].</ex>
<ex>Are you certain that [the shovel|phe] <m>was</m> [visible|Target] [from the door of the apartment|loc]?</ex>
<ex> I think they miss [some of the important impacts of the work that|phe] <m>are</m> not [visible|Target] [just from looking at the vote tally|evi].</ex>
<ex>[That the defense will declare a mistrial regardless|phe] <m>is</m> [quite|deg] [evident|Target] [from their consistent obstructionist tactics|evi].</ex>
<ex>[In late July 2000|tim] [it|phe] <m>was</m> [barely|deg] [visible|Target] [to the unaided eye|per].</ex>

name: Occupy_rank
description:
This frame is about #Items in the state of occupying a certain #Rank within a hierarchy.

<ex>[He|Item] [ranks|Target] [second|Rank] [in his class|com] [in mathematics|dim].</ex>

name: Offenses
description:
Words in this frame describe acts in violation of a legal code.

<ex>[He|Perpetrator] was accused of [[hijacking|Offense]|Target] [a tour bus full of people|Victim].</ex>

name: Offering
description:
An #Offerer indicates that he or she is able and willing to give a #Theme to a #Potential_recipient. In the absence of further qualifications, it is often understood that the #Potential_recipient accepts the #Theme.

<ex>[The host|Offerer] [graciously|Manner] [offered|Target] [us|Potential_recipient] [food and drink|Theme].</ex>

name: Offshoot
description:
This frame refers to a part of an organization that becomes separate from the main body. The part is usually partially or even wholly autonomous, and may eventually become larger than the body from which it originated.
<ex>Methodism is an an [offshoot|Target] of the Church of England</ex>

name: Omen
description:
One phenomenon, the #Predictive_phenomenon is an indication of the future or current (but still uncertain) existence of another phenomenon, the #Future_phenomenon. There is no Cognizer present on the scene, in distinction to the Expectation frame where a Cognizer takes (the equivalent of) #Predictive_phenomenon as evidence for (the equivalent of) #Future_phenomenon. Many words in this frame also allow a slightly different understanding, whereby #Predictive_phenomenon provides clues as to the good or bad #Outcome of an expected #Future_phenomenon. Instead of #Future_phenomenon an #Interested_party that will be involved in the #Future_phenomenon may be mentioned. In both construals, the two phenomena are asymmetrical and consequently they have no joint syntactic realization.

<ex>  [Such potential|Predictive_phenomenon] [augurs|Target]
[well|Outcome]  [for the 1990s|Future_phenomenon] </ex>
<ex>[Its appearance|Predictive_phenomenon] <m>was</m> an
[ill|Outcome] [omen|Target]. </ex>
<ex>[Cold-blooded words|Predictive_phenomenon] do not necessarily [betoken|Target] [a callous nature|Future_phenomenon].</ex>
<ex>I wish I could say [my success|Predictive_phenomenon]  [bodes|Target] [well|Outcome] [for him|Interested_party].</ex>

name: Ontogeny
description:
An #Entity develops from a #Prior_state to a #Post_state.  The #Entity can also be represented by an entity-denoting adjective which is labeled #Domain as shown in the first example below.   NOTE: This frame is not intended for the evolution of an entire species, but rather the development of a single organism.
<ex></ex>
<ex>Yesterday we learned about [neural|Domain] [development|Target].</ex>
<ex></ex>
<ex>Sherman studies [nervous system|Entity] [development|Target] [in toddlers|Organism].</ex>
<ex></ex>
<ex>The researchers were studying the [development|Target] [of hair cells|Entity]. </ex>
<ex></ex>
<ex>[This small bud|Entity] will [grow|Target] [into a flower|Post_state] [someday soon|Time].</ex>

name: Openness
description:
A #Useful_location is accessible to some (possibly generic) #Theme despite a potential #Barrier, or is not accessible because of the #Barrier.

<ex>I left [the door to the lobby|Barrier] [open|Target] [for you|Theme].</ex>
<ex>I left the door [to the lobby|Useful_location] [open|Target] for you.</ex>

name: Operate_vehicle
description:
The words in this frame describe motion involving a #Vehicle and someone who controls it, the #Driver. Some words normally allow the #Vehicle to be expressed as a separate constituent.
<ex>[Tim|Driver] [drove|Target] [his car|Vehicle] [all the way across North America|Path].</ex>
<ex>[Tom|Driver] [paddled|Target] [my canoe|Vehicle] [across the Canadian border|Path].</ex>
Other words in this domain are based on the names of vehicles, and do not normally allow the #Vehicle to be expressed as a separate constituent.
<ex>[The group|Driver] [biked|Target] all the way across the country.</ex>
However, a separate #Vehicle constituent can occur if it adds information not included in the verb.
<ex>[Tim|Driver] [biked|Target] across the country [on an old 10-speed|Vehicle].</ex>

name: Operate_vehicle_scenario
description: This frame describes an #Operator interacting with a #Vehicle to transport him/herself (and possibly others) from a #Source to a #Goal. The three primary stages are preparation for canonical operation, operation of the vehicle proper, and bringing the vehicle back to a state of rest, where it may continue to move but not in its typical fashion.

name: Operating_a_system
description:
An #Operator manipulates the substructure of a #System such that the #System performs the function it was created for.

This frame differs from the Using frame in that this frame does not profile the purpose of an agent but rather their manipulation of an entity (#System/Instrument). In the case of using, the Agent need not manipulate the Instrument at all, as in: <ment>Mrs. Adams used the room as a place to hang the family laundry to dry</ment>.


<ex>This true story of domestic bliss was related to me by [a friend of mine|Operator] [who|Operator] for a time [operated|Target] [a bar|System] [in San Francisco|Place].</ex>

<ex>A California man has plead guilty to federal charges that [he|Operator] [ran|Target] [a pyramid scam which defrauded nearly 7000 investors.|System]</ex>

name: Operational_testing
description:
A #Tester uses a concrete or conceptual #Product in order to determine either whether it works or to find out how well or in which manner it works. The #Tester may have particular #Unwanted_characteristics in mind that they are specifically looking for. The operational test may also be carried out under a particular set of #Circumstances that are typically relevant to the functioning of the #Product.

<ex>[Sun|Tester] has (hopefully) already [tested|Target] [it|pro] [for compliance|des].</ex>
<ex>[The Velcro hook and loop closure system|pro] has been [tested|Target] [under wet conditions|Circumstances] and retains its holding power after 10,000 open and close functions. [CNI|tes] [INI|unw]</ex>
<ex>[Roe|tes] revisited the compound and [tested|Target] [it|pro] [as a mosquito repellent|fun].</ex>

name: Opinion
description:
A #Cognizer holds a particular #Opinion, which may be portrayed as being about a particular #Topic.

<ex>[John|cog] [thinks|Target] [that it looks better back|opi] .</ex>
<ex>Well, [my|cog] [[opinion|Target]|opi] [about that|top] is none of your business. </ex>

<ex>[What|opi] <ment>'s</ment> [your|cog] [take|Target] [on the recent oil crisis|top] ?</ex>

<ex>[Your|cog] [view|Target] [of Smithers|top] [as an excellent secretary|opi] is not shared by the rest of the UN.</ex>

name: Opportunity
description:
An #Agent has a choice of whether or not to participate in some Desirable_event because of an #Opportunity, a situation not completely under the #Agent's control and usually of a limited duration.

<ex>It would be pleasant in the [opportune|Target] [absence|Opportunity] of the clergyman to have a dance . [DNI|Desirable_situation]</ex>

<ex>[Her|Agent] [[opportunities|Target]|Opportunity] [to apply to a good school|Desirable_situation] are then limited .</ex>

<ex>Now was [their|Agent] big [[chance|Target]|Opportunity] ! [DNI|Desirable_situation]</ex>

name: Optical_image
description:
This frame describes non-artifact #Images resulting from an interation between light and some kind of matter, usually a #Source entity.

<ex>I could see [John's|Source] [[silhouette|Target]|Image] in the corner as I entered the dimly lit room.</ex>

name: Ordinal_numbers
description:
An #Item is picked out either by the order in which the members of a set would be encountered by an implicit cognizer, or by the order in which the members of a set participate in an event or state which serves as the #Basis_of_order. The former case usually involves a #Starting_point for going through the set, while the latter involves a #Basis_of_order, which is normally an event that the #Item along with other members of its #Comparison_set has participated in.  Note that #Item should be annotated on a second layer, except in cases when the noun structure the ordinal participates in is predicative.

<ex>The [first|Target] [car|typ] [from the left|sta] <ment>is</ment> a Magosix.</ex>
<ex>[The first car from the left|ite] is a Magosix.</ex>
<ex>[Barney|Item] <m>was</m> only the [second|Target] [Asian student|Type] [at my college|bas].</ex>
<ex>[Felix|ite] <m>was</m> the [first|Target] [of my cats|com] [to realize that human food was tastier|bas].</ex>
<ex>Felix was the [first|Target] [of my cats|typ] to realize that human food was tastier.</ex>

name: Organization
description:
This frame describes intentionally formed human social groups (here termed #Organizations) with some definite structure and #Members.  They may be relatively informal, consisting only of a group of individuals who are aware of who is and who is not a fellow member, or they may be complex and long-lasting, such as the Roman Catholic Church or the Conservative Party.

<ex>[Lucien|Members] is in the [[brotherhood|Organization]|Target].</ex>

name: Organização_da_conversa
description: Este frame refere-se á organização dos turnos de uma conversa, durante os quais um dos participantes (#Comunicadores) assume, seguindo determinadas regras, o papel de #Enunciador, enquanto o outro #Comunicador (ou demais #Comunicadores) assume o papel de #Compreendedor.

name: Organization_of_conversation
description: This frame covers the organization of conversational turns, during which the participants in a conversation (the Communicators), according to certain rules, change turns, one assuming the role of Utterer and the other(s) the role of Comprehender(s), alternately.

name: Origin
description:
An #Entity began its existence in the context of a #Origin, which can be a place,  culture, time period, text, etc.

<ex>The [Christian|Origin] [origin|Target] [of this quote|Entity] <ment>is</ment> [from Isaiah 22|Origin].</ex>

<ex>[Dinosaurs|Entity] [originated|Target] [from Antarctica|Origin]?</ex>

<ex></ex>

name: Others_situation_as_stimulus
description:
An #Experiencer feels an emotion as evoked as an #Other.

<ex>[One|Experiencer] might [pity|Target] [the frail old man in East Berlin|Other].</ex>

<ex>She appealed for [compassion|Target] [for sufferers|Other].</ex>

<ex>[I|Experiencer] [feel|Target] [for women who also long to have children but can't|Other].</ex>

name: Out_of_existence
description:
An #Entity has ceased to exist.

<ex>[Theses termites|Entity] are [history|Target].</ex>

<ex>[Hillary|Entity] is [toast|Target] [after Texas and Ohio|Time].</ex>

<ex>[They|Entity] are [gone|Target] [because you killed them all|Explanation].</ex>

name: Pardon
description:
An #Authority excuses an #Offense that an #Offender has committed, with the effect of ending or preventing any punishment.


<ex>President Ford [pardoned|Target] [her|off] [after it came to light she was being held in Japan as an ""enemy alien"" and was secretly working to subvert the broadcasts|tim] [DNI|fen] </ex>

<ex> [President John Quincy Adams|aut] <m>granted</m> [them|off] a [pardon|Target] and remission of the fine. [DNI|fen] </ex>

name: Partiality
description:
This frame has to do with the bias or lack of bias of a #Judge making an assessment concerning two or more #Sides. The #Sides may stand opposed to each other in a dispute or be alternatives in a situation of choice. The #Domain in which the #Judge is partial or impartial may be expressed as well as the #Degree of bias or lack thereof.  In sentences in this frame one may also find expressions of #Manifestation_of_bias, i.e. expressions that tell us how the #Judge's bias is realized.

<ex>[The judge|Decision_maker] made a [biased|Target] [decision|Manifestation_of_bias].</ex>

name: Grammatical_person
description: Grammatical_person

name: Participation
description:
An #Event with multiple #Participants takes place. It can be presented either symmetrically with #Participants or asymmetrically, giving #Participant_1 greater prominence over #Participant_2. If the #Event is engaged in intentionally, then there is typically a shared #Purpose between the #Participants. It is, however, possible that an expressed #Purpose only applies to #Participant_1.


<ex>MATAC looks forward to [your|par1] [participation|Target] [in helping promote telework in the Mid-Atlantic region|eve].</ex>

<ex> FOAP provides [participants|Target] with comprehensive clerical skills. [DNI|eve]</ex>
<ex> FOAP provides [participants|par] with comprehensive clerical skills. </ex>


<ex>[Our eight-year-old son|par1] <m>was</m> [recently|tim]
[peripherally|deg] [involved|Target] [in an incident which resulted in him being threatened with the strap|eve].</ex>

<ex>A New York press agent must scramble when [his major client|par1] <m>becomes</m> [embroiled|Target] [in a huge scandal|eve].</ex>

<ex>[In his time as a first-team all-league player|Time], [Rife|Participant_1] <m>was</m> [in|Target] [on 86 solo tackles|Event].</ex>

name: Partitive
description:
A #Subset is profiled against the #Group it belongs to. The #Subset may consist of a single member. Frequently, the #Group is actually a generic sample of a full population, and the #Subset is  representative of the relative proportion.

<ex>[Of|Target] [all scenes that evoke rural England|Group], [this|Subset] is one of the loveliest.</ex>

<ex> As of 5:30 p.m. Moscow time, [23|Subset] [out|Target] [of|Target] [46 miners stranded in the Zapadnaya-Kapitalnaya mine|Group] have been rescued</ex>

<ex>[1.5|Subset] [out|Target] [of|Target]  [10 respondents|Group] preferred Shrub over Ferry</ex>

name: Part_edge
description:
This describes a part_whole relationship where the #Part provides the boundary between the #Whole and what is not that object.  The #Part can exist along a continuum of width.  It can be modified by an #Orientation that specifies the particular portion of the edge of a #Part_prop which describes a property of the #Part.

<ex>We came to the [southern|Orientation] [[edge|Part]|Target] [ of the town |Whole] . </ex>

name: Part_inner_outer
description:
This frame concerns #Parts of objects that are defined relative to the center or edge of the object.  The #Part is a part of the #Whole and the #Part_prop describes a property of the #Part.

<ex>She discarded the [[exterior|Part]|Target] [of the walnut|Whole].</ex>
<ex> She preferred a sparse [church|Whole] [[interior|Part]|Target] . </ex>

In cases where the [Target|Target] is an adjective, it has a special relationship with the noun that it modifies such that a phrase which is a syntactic argument of the noun is semantically available to fill the argument structure of the adjective, as in ""the [outside|Target] [row|Part] [of the class|Whole]""<ex>The [inner|Target] [shelf|Part] [of the bookcase|Whole] was lying on the floor.</ex>

name: Part_ordered_segments
description:
In this frame a #Part is part of a larger #Whole comprised of parts that are ordered. The #Parts can be ordered temporally (first to last and vice versa) or vertically (down to up and vice versa).  The #Part can be modified by the #Part_prop or the number of the part can be given by #Ordinality.
<ex></ex>
<ex> I sat through the [first|Ordinality] [interminable|Part_prop] [[act|Part]|Target] [ of the play |Whole] . </ex>
<ex> Tess finished a [ dissertation|Whole] [[chapter|Part]|Target] . </ex>
<ex>The [first|Ordinality] [[level|Part]|Target] [of rock|Whole] consisted of sediment from the Neolithic period.</ex>
<ex>The [last|Ordinality] [[layer|Part]|Target] [of sediment|Whole] was also the thickest.</ex>

name: Part_orientational
description:
In this frame, there is a #Part of a #Whole in which the #Part is defined with respect to the canonical or inherent orientation of the #Whole. In cases where the [Target|Target] is an adjective, it has a special relationship with the noun that it modifies such that a phrase which is a syntactic argument of the noun is semantically available to fill the argument structure of the adjective, as in

<ex>the [front|Target]  [row|Part] [of the class|Whole] </ex>

<ex>The [top|Target]  [shelf|Part] [of the bookcase|Whole] was lying on the floor.</ex>

<ex>The [[bottom|Part]|Target] was missing.</ex>

<ex>[My|Whole] [left|Target]  [hand|Part] was numb.</ex>

<ex>He rested on the [cliff|Whole][[top|Part]|Target]</ex>

name: Part_piece
description:
This frame is concerned with transparent nouns denoting a #Piece of a #Substance. Also present is #Piece_prop which is a property of the #Piece, e.g. relating to its size.

<ex>Kim ate a [tiny|Piece_prop] [[morsel|Piece]|Target] [of cake |Substance]</ex>.

name: Part_whole
description:
This frame is concerned with nouns denoting a part or parts of a #Whole entity . The #Part is not defined relative to the #Whole's orientation, center, or edge and is not ordered.  We also annotate properties of the #Part, e.g. relating to its size.

<ex>Kim forgot a [large|Part_prop] [[part|Part]|Target] [of the story|Whole].</ex>

<ex>Abby ate only the [top|Orientation] [[half|Part]|Target] [of the cake|Whole].</ex>

name: Passing
description:
An #Agent physically transfers a #Theme to a #Recipient. The #Agent is not under control of the #Theme's motion after the initial input of energy.

Compare with Bringing and Sending. In the former, the Carrier is in constant control (even physical contact) with the Theme. In the latter, the Sender plans the motion of the Theme and places it in circumstances such that it travels along the specified path (or to the specified goal), but under the power of a separate individual.

<ex>[Pat|Agent] [passed|Target] [me|Recipient] [the ball|Theme].</ex>

name: Passing_off
description:
An #Agent acts in such a way as to cause others to think that an #Item is an instance of a particular kind of #Simulated_entity.

<ex>[He|agt] had, under the name of Armitage, [passed|Target] [her|Item] [off|Target] [as a member of one of
the most distinguished families of the capital|Simulated_entity].</ex>

<ex>He undoubtedly believes you are [the impostor|agt] [who|agt] [palmed|Target] [himself|Item] [off|Target] at Bar Harbor
[as the Baron von Kissel|Simulated_entity].</ex>
